In the case of services that use radioelectric spectrum, whether free or paid, they must have the respective concession to use radioelectric spectrum and its corresponding radioelectric channel assignment. Authorization or license to provide an audiovisual communication service regulated in this law shall be independent from the concession, authorization or license that, as applicable, is necessary to provide the telecommunications service that transports the carrier signals of audiovisual content, which shall be governed by the telecommunications legislation in force. The Institute, in case of doubt as to whether information is of public character or is subject to one of the exceptions, must make the criterion of publicity prevail. The Institute may extend the period of reserve for five additional years at the request of the obligated entities, who will act ex officio or at the request of an interested person, as long as it is justified that the causes that gave origin to its classification subsist. When the period of reserve concludes the information shall be public, without need of prior agreement or resolution, and the confidential information that it still contains must be protected. The Institute shall keep a public registry of the information that is declassified. It shall correspond to the Institute to keep the centralized registry of the indices of reserved information, which shall be at the disposal of the public. In case of discrepancy about the classification of information between the private party and an obligated entity or between obligated entities, the Institute shall resolve. Against the denial of delivery of reports, of direct consultation, rectification, updating, confidentiality or suppression of personal data, the interposition of the appeal shall proceed before the Institute. The guidelines that the Institute issues for the creation or generation of data and archives, as well as for the preservation thereof, shall contain the following aspects: criteria on the identification and monitoring of the data and documents from the moment they are created or received; mechanisms that permit the adequate administration, cataloging, preservation and protection of the information according to its nature; mechanisms for the preservation and maintenance of the information that obeys minimum standards in matters of archival science; the training of officials in techniques of archival science; the organization of the information in such a way that it facilitates the direct consultation of private parties; the use of technologies that allow the efficient and effective safeguarding of public information. The obligated entities shall be guided by the guidelines and observations that, on the particular, the Institute issues.

It constitutes a communication offense the commission, through a medium of communication, of a fact classified as an offense by the Penal Code or by special laws. The proceeding that corresponds in case of communication offenses is governed by this law, with the penalties provided in the Penal Code or in the respective special law. The offenses provided for by the first paragraph of article 19 of this law, unless it concerns defamation and insult, shall be punished in accordance with the provisions of the Penal Code or of the special laws that correspond. The circumstance of being carried out through means of communication shall be considered as an aggravating circumstance in accordance with what article 50 of the Penal Code provides. In the case of defamation committed through the media of communication, the offended person may request, in addition to compensation for damages in accordance with what is provided by letters B), C), D) and E) of article 105 of the Penal Code, the setting of a sum by way of reparation. This may not exceed ten percent of the amount of compensation fixed.

Publication or dissemination with omissions or errors, whose entity shall be assessed by the Judge, shall give rise to its repetition (article 12). Are subjects of the offenses provided in article 19 of this law the author of the communication and eventually the responsible of the medium of communication. When the identity of the author of the questioned broadcast or journalistic article (informative version or commentary) is not notoriously known, the responsible editor or the responsible director of the medium of communication must reveal it. For those purposes, the director of every organ of communication is obliged to collect the name and other identifying data of the authors of commentaries or informative reports that are disseminated by that organ. Excluded from such requirement are those persons who participate accidentally in programs that include the intervention of the public or when it concerns interviews broadcast in live transmission and the publication of classified ads or similar. The responsible of the medium of communication who, by fault or intent, does not reveal the name and other identifying data of the author of the journalistic short piece (informative report or commentary) object of the criminal complaint shall be sanctioned with the penalty provided in article 197 of the Penal Code. When the complaint falls upon expressions made in non-printed media of dissemination of thought and whenever the complainant could not provide an authentic version of the same, the court shall require it from the responsible of the medium involved who must provide it within the peremptory term of forty-eight hours. For these purposes, the non-printed media of dissemination of thought must preserve a reproducible version of their broadcasts for the term of ten calendar days.

Schedules of protection for children and adolescents.- The schedule of protection for children, girls, and adolescents shall be from 6:00 a.m. until 10:00 p.m., every day of the week. The audiovisual contents and advertising emitted in said schedule must be suitable for all audiences. Outside the referred schedule, programs not suitable for all audiences must be duly signaled.

(Protection schedules).- The protection schedule for children and adolescents is established every day of the week from 6:00 to 22:00. The programs, the advertising messages and the self-promotion broadcast in this schedule by all audiovisual communication services, shall be suitable for all audiences and shall favor the educational objectives that such media allow to develop. It shall be avoided, in the aforementioned schedule, the exhibition of programs that promote attitudes or violent, morbid, criminal, discriminatory or pornographic conducts, or foster esotericism, games of chance or bets. Without prejudice to the information of the facts, the programming broadcast during the protection schedule for children and adolescents must not include: A) Images with excessive violence, understood as explicit violence used in a disproportionate or reiterated manner, especially if it has manifest results of injuries and death of persons and other living beings (murders, tortures, rapes, suicides or mutilations). B) Ghastliness, understood as the presentation of ostensibly cruel conducts or that exalt cruelty, or that abuse suffering, panic or terror, or that exhibit corpses or results of crimes in an open and detailed manner. C) Apology, exaltation or incitement of violence and violent conducts, of crime or criminal conducts. D) Pornography, understood as the exhibition of materials, images or sounds of sexual acts, or their reproductions, with the purpose of provoking the sexual excitation of the receiver. E) Exhibition of scenes with explicit, obscene or degrading sexual acts, or of elements of sadomasochistic practices. F) Apology, exaltation or incitement to pornography, sexual exploitation or sexual crimes. G) Exhibition of explicit and abusive consumption of legal and illegal drugs. H) Apology, exaltation or incitement to drug consumption or to drug trafficking. I) Presentation as successful or positive of persons or characters addicted to drugs or who participate in drug trafficking. J) Contents that make apology, promote or incite acts or discriminatory or racist conducts.

Authorization of use of radioelectric spectrum and assignment of radioelectric channels.- The services for the diffusion of audiovisual content that use the radioelectric spectrum, whether free or onerous, must have, in addition to the license for the provision of the service of audiovisual content diffusion, the respective authorization for use of the radioelectric spectrum and the corresponding assignment of radioelectric channel. (Very serious infractions).- Very serious infractions shall be: A) The provision of audiovisual content diffusion services without having the corresponding license. Create the Registry of Audiovisual Content Diffusion Services, which shall be managed by the Regulatory Unit of Communications Services (URSEC) and in which information of the holders of the respective licenses will be included, in the form that will be determined by the regulation. Obligations.- The holders of services for the diffusion of audiovisual content must comply with the following obligations: B) Provide the information that, with due foundation, the authorities request in the fulfillment of their respective tasks.

Art. 342. Whoever habitually excites, favors or facilitates the debauchery or corruption of minors of twenty-one years, of one or the other sex, or even occasionally of minors of sixteen years, shall be punished by imprisonment of five to ten years and a fine of 500 to 25,000 DA.

Whoever distributes, offers for sale, displays to the public or possesses with a view to distribution, sale or display, for propaganda purposes, leaflets, bulletins and handbills of a nature to harm the national interest, shall be punished by imprisonment of six months to 3 years and a fine of 3,600 DA to 36,000 DA. When the leaflets, bulletins and handbills are of foreign origin or inspiration, the imprisonment may be increased to 5 years. The court may, moreover, in both cases, pronounce the deprivation of the civil rights referred to in Article 14 of this Code.

Art. 145. — Is considered an outrage and punished as such, the fact by a person of denouncing to the public authorities an infraction that she knows did not exist or of producing a false proof relating to an imaginary infraction, or of declaring before the judicial authority to be the author of an infraction that she has neither committed, nor contributed to commit.

Whoever, by any means whatsoever, has made a calumnious denunciation against one or several individuals to officers of justice or of administrative or judicial police, or to authorities having the power to act upon it or to seize the competent authority or again to the hierarchical superiors or to the employers of the denounced, is punished by imprisonment of six months to five years and a fine of 500 to 15,000 DA; the trial court may, in addition, order the insertion of its decision, integrally or by extract, in one or several newspapers and at the expense of the convicted.

Art. 425. — Whoever, with the help of false news, slanderous rumors or other fraudulent maneuvers, takes by surprise or diverts the votes of the members of a general assembly of workers or a council of workers, determines one or several members of these assemblies to abstain from voting, is punished with imprisonment of one month to one year and a fine of 600 to 2,000 DA or with only one of these two penalties. The offender may, moreover, be struck with the prohibition of one or more of the rights mentioned in Article 14.

Is punished with imprisonment for a term of ten to twenty years, any guardian, any custodian by function or by quality of a piece of information, object, document or process which must be kept secret in the interest of national defense or whose knowledge could lead to the discovery of a national defense secret who, without intent of treason or espionage, has: 1° Destroyed, subtracted, allowed to be destroyed or allowed to be subtracted, reproduced or allowed to be reproduced; 2° Brought or allowed to be brought to the knowledge of an unqualified person or the public. The penalty is imprisonment for a term of five to ten years if the guardian or the custodian has acted through clumsiness, imprudence, inattention, negligence or non-observance of regulations. Is punished with imprisonment for a term of five to ten years any person other than those referred to in Article 66 who, without intent of treason or espionage: 1° Assures, being without quality, the possession of a piece of information, object, document or process which must be kept secret in the interest of national defense or whose knowledge could lead to the discovery of a national defense secret; 2° Destroys, subtracts, allows to be destroyed or allows to be subtracted, reproduces or allows to be reproduced such a piece of information, object, document or process; 3° Brings or allows to be brought to the knowledge of an unqualified person or the public such a piece of information, object, document or process, or has extended its dissemination. Is punished with imprisonment of one to five years whoever, without intent of treason or espionage, has brought to the knowledge of an unqualified person or the public a military information not made public by the competent authority and whose disclosure is manifestly of a nature to harm national defense. Is punished with imprisonment for a term of ten to twenty years, whoever: 6° Communicates to an unqualified person or makes public information relating either to measures taken to discover and arrest the authors and the accomplices of crimes or offenses defined in sections I and II of the present chapter, or to the progress of prosecutions and of investigation, or to debates before the courts of judgment. However in time of peace, the authors of the infringements provided for in paragraphs 3°, 4° and 6° above, are punished with imprisonment of one to five years and with a fine of 3,000 to 70,000 DA.

Whoever, working in any capacity in an enterprise, has, without having been authorized therefor, communicated or attempted to communicate to foreigners or to Algerians residing in foreign countries secrets of the enterprise where he works, is punished by imprisonment of two to five years and a fine of 500 to 10,000 DA. The maximum of the penalty provided for by the two preceding paragraphs is obligatorily incurred if it concerns secrets of the manufacture of arms and munitions of war belonging to the State.

Is punished by imprisonment of two months to two years and a fine of 500 to 10,000 DA or by one of these two penalties only, whoever: either by speeches delivered in public places or meetings; or by the sale, the offering for sale, or the offering, even non-public, or by the exhibition, the posting or the distribution on the public way or in public places, or by distribution at home, the sending under band or under envelope, closed or not closed, to the post office or to any distribution or transport agent, of books, writings, printed matter, advertisements, posters, drawings, images and emblems; or by the publicity of medical or so-called medical offices; has provoked abortion, even though the provocation has not been followed by effect.

The threat to set fire to or to destroy, by the effect of a mine or of any explosive substance, the objects enumerated in Articles 401 and in the first paragraph of Article 402 is punished with imprisonment of two months to two years and a fine of 500 to 1,000 DA.

Art. 440. — Are punished with imprisonment of at least ten days and at most two months and a fine of 50 to 500 DA or with only one of these two penalties, those who outrage by words, gestures, threats, writings or drawings not made public, or else by sending objects of any kind with the same intention, any citizen charged with a public service ministry, in the exercise or on the occasion of the exercise of his functions.

Is punished with imprisonment of two months to one year and a fine of 500 to 2,000 DA anyone who, by gestures, words, writings or by any other means, publicly proceeds to the solicitation of persons of one or the other sex with a view to provoking them to debauchery. The attempt is punished with the same penalties as the consummated offense.

Is punished with imprisonment for a term of ten to twenty years, whoever: 1° has, by hostile acts not approved by the Government, exposed Algeria to a declaration of war; 2° has, by acts not approved by the Government, exposed Algerians to undergo reprisals; 3° maintains with the agents of a foreign power intelligences of a nature to harm the military or diplomatic situation of Algeria or its essential economic interests.

Whoever, working in any capacity in an enterprise, has, without having been authorized therefor, communicated or attempted to communicate to foreigners or to Algerians residing in foreign countries secrets of the enterprise where he works, is punished by imprisonment of two to five years and a fine of 500 to 10,000 DA. The maximum of the penalty provided for by the two preceding paragraphs is obligatorily incurred if it concerns secrets of the manufacture of arms and munitions of war belonging to the State.

Any person who has committed a public outrage to decency is punished with imprisonment of two months to two years and a fine of 500 to 2,000 DA. When the public outrage to decency has consisted in an act against nature with an individual of the same sex, the penalty is imprisonment of six months to three years and a fine of 1,000 to 10,000 DA.

Art. 448. — Are punished with a fine of 50 to 200 DA and may, moreover, be punished with imprisonment for at most ten days, those who display or cause to be displayed on the public way or in public places posters or images contrary to decency. The judgment of conviction shall order, notwithstanding all avenues of appeal, the suppression of the incriminated object(s), which, if it is not voluntary, shall be carried out ex officio and without delay at the expense of the convicted person.

Whoever, in bad faith and outside the cases provided for by Article 137, opens or suppresses letters or correspondences addressed to third parties, is punished by imprisonment of one month to one year and a fine of 500 to 3,000 DA or by one of these two penalties only.

The threat to set fire to or to destroy, by the effect of a mine or of any explosive substance, the objects enumerated in Articles 401 and in the first paragraph of Article 402 is punished with imprisonment of two months to two years and a fine of 500 to 1,000 DA.

Art. 144. — Is punished by imprisonment of two months to two years and a fine of 500 to 5000 DA whoever, with the intention of attacking their honor, their decency, towards a magistrate, a public functionary, a commander or agent of the public force, either by words, gestures, threats, sending or delivery of any object, or by writing with an intention not rendered public. When the outrage towards one or several magistrates or juror-assessors is committed at the hearing of a court or of a tribunal, the imprisonment is of one to two years. In all cases, the jurisdiction may, in addition, order that its decision be posted and published under the conditions that it determines, at the expense of the convicted, without these costs being able to exceed the maximum of the fine provided above.

Any allegation or imputation of a fact that undermines the honor and consideration of persons or of the body to which the fact is imputed is defamation. The direct publication or by way of reproduction of this allegation or of this imputation is punishable, even if it is made in a dubitative form or if it targets a person or a body not expressly named but whose identification is made possible by the terms of the speeches, shouts, threats, writings or printed matter, placards or posters incriminated.

Anyone who, by means of a threat, written or verbal, of revelations or of defamatory imputations, extorts or attempts to extort either the delivery of funds or valuables, or the signature or delivery of the writings enumerated in Article 370, and thus is guilty of blackmail, is punished with imprisonment of one to five years and a fine of 500 to 20,000 DA. The offender may, moreover, be struck for at least one year and at most five years with the prohibition of all or part of the rights mentioned in Article 14.

Art. 463. — Are punished with a fine of 5 to 20 DA and may, moreover, be punished with imprisonment for three days at most; 2° Those who, without having been provoked, utter against someone non-public insults.

Whoever is guilty of false testimony in criminal matters, either against the accused or in his favor, is punished by imprisonment of five to ten years.

Anyone who habitually incites, favors or facilitates the debauchery or corruption of minors of twenty-one years, of either sex, or even occasionally of minors of fifteen years, is punished with imprisonment of two to five years and a fine of 500 to 25,000 DA. The attempt of the offenses referred to in this article is punished with the penalties provided for these offenses.

If the offenders were carrying weapons visible or concealed or if the ballot has been violated, the penalty is imprisonment for a term of five to ten years.

Article 30 Propagation or dissemination of false or distorted news through Information and Communication Technologies Whoever, using Information and Communication Technologies, social networks or mobile applications, publishes or disseminates information that is false, distorted or of any other nature that deliberately produces alarm, fear, panic or distress in the population, or in a group or sector of it, to a person or to his or her family, a penalty of three to five years of imprisonment and three hundred to five hundred day-fines shall be imposed. If the publication or dissemination of the information harms the honor, prestige or reputation of a person or his or her family, a penalty of two to four years of imprisonment and one hundred fifty to three hundred fifty day-fines shall be imposed. If the publication or dissemination of the information incites discrimination, hatred and violence for racial, religious, political, economic and social status reasons or endangers economic and social stability, public order, sovereign security or public health, a penalty of five to ten years of imprisonment and five hundred to eight hundred day-fines shall be imposed. The same penalty shall be imposed on necessary cooperators, accomplices or any other person who facilitates or favors the commission of this crime. This penalty shall be increased up to two thirds for persons who organize, finance, carry out, collaborate and/or facilitate the creation or massive dissemination of the information mentioned above by the means and forms described in the first paragraph of this Article.

Records retention and protection of data (1) A service provider shall keep all traffic data and subscriber information as may be prescribed by the relevant authority for the time being responsible for the regulation of communication services in Nigeria. (2) A service provider shall, at the request of the relevant authority referred to in subsection (1) of this section or any law enforcement agency - (a) preserve, hold or retain any traffic data, subscriber information or related content, or (b) release any information required to be kept under subsection (1) of this section (3) A law enforcement agency may, through its authorised officer, request for the release of any information in respect of subsection (2) (b) of this section and it shall be the duty of the service provider to comply. (4) Any data retained, processed or retrieved by the service provider at the request of any law enforcement agency under this Act shall not be utilized except for legitimate purposes as may be provided for under this Act, any other legislation, regulation or by an order of a court of competent jurisdiction. (5) Anyone exercising any function under this section shall have due regard to the individual’s right to privacy under the Constitution of the Federal Republic of Nigeria, 1999 and shall take appropriate measures to safeguard the confidentiality of the data retained, processed or retrieved for the purpose of law enforcement. 23. (1) It shall be the duty of every service provider in Nigeria to comply with all the provisions of this Act and disclose any information requested by any law enforcement agency or otherwise render assistance howsoever in any inquiry or proceeding under this Act. (2) Without prejudice to the generality of the foregoing, a service provider shall, at the request of any law enforcement agency in Nigeria or at its own initiative, provide assistance towards - (a) the identification, apprehension and prosecution of offenders; (b) the identification, tracking and tracing of proceeds of any offence or any property, equipment or device used in the commission of any offence; or (c) the freezing, removal, erasure or cancellation of the services of the offender which enables the offender to either commit the offence or hide or preserve the proceeds of any offence or any property, equipment or device used in the commission of the offence. (a) ESTABLISHMENT.—Not later than 180 days after the date of the enactment of this Act, the Secretary of State shall, in coordination with the Secretary of Defense, the Director of National Intelligence, the Broadcasting Board of Governors, and other relevant departments and agencies, establish a Center for Information Analysis and Response (in this section referred to as the “Center”). The purposes of the Center are— (1) to lead and coordinate the collection and analysis of information on foreign government information warfare efforts, including information provided by recipients of information access fund grants awarded under subsection (e) and other sources; (2) to establish a framework for the integration of critical data and analysis on foreign propaganda and disinformation efforts into the development of national strategy; and (3) to develop, plan, and synchronize, in coordination with the Secretary of Defense, the Director of National Intelligence, the Broadcasting Board of Governors, and other relevant departments and agencies, whole-of-government initiatives to expose and counter foreign information operations directed against United States national security interests and proactively advance fact-based narratives that support United States allies and interests. (b) FUNCTIONS.—The Center shall carry out the following functions: (1) Integrating interagency efforts to track and evaluate counterfactual narratives abroad that threaten the national security interests of the United States and United States allies. (2) Collecting, integrating, and analyzing relevant information, including intelligence reporting, data, analysis, and analytics from United States Government agencies, allied nations, think-tanks, academic institutions, civil society groups, and other nongovernmental organizations. (3) Developing and disseminating fact-based narratives and analysis to counter propaganda and disinformation directed at United States allies and partners.

The IMC shall establish a license fee schedule for various classes of broadcasting licenses that shall be payable annually by the licensees. In establishing the level of annual payment for licence, the IMC shall consider prevailing and projected market conditions. Annual license fees shall be collected by the Executive Office. Licensed audiovisual media services shall present an annual report to IMC, which shall include information concerning programme and action in compliance with license conditions, along with a detailed financial report and such other information as provided for by Law. For the breach of license conditions, code of conduct and other legal acts in accordance with the present Law, the IMC may issue a written warning or impose one or more of the following sanctions to the licensees: impose a fine of not less than one thousand (1000) Euro and not more than one hundred thousand (100.000) Euro; terminate or refuse the continuation of broadcasting license.

A broadcasting license shall be required for exercising broadcasting in Kosovo according to the provisions of this Law, which shall be issued by the IMC. Licenses shall not be used and be transferable without prior authorization and written approval of the IMC. Relevant broadcasting equipment shall be confiscated from anyone who is operating without a valid broadcasting license. Such a broadcasting entity cannot appeal to the Appeals Board.

Applications for broadcasting licenses shall be made to the IMC in accordance with the provisions of this Law and procedures to be established and published by the IMC. The Executive Office shall maintain a register of broadcasting licenses, including applicable conditions for each license. The register shall be available for public inspection. Independent Media Commission shall be an independent body for regulation, management, and oversight of the broadcasting frequency spectrum. IMC shall regulate the rights, obligations and responsibilities of natural and legal persons that provide audio and audiovisual media services. The IMC shall monitor audiovisual media services and may initiate and receive complaints with regard to a failure to comply with its conditions of license, code of conduct and other legal acts in accordance with the present Law. The IMC shall investigate complaints for alleged breaches of license conditions, code of conduct and other legal acts in accordance with this Law. The IMC shall, through the Executive Office, provide a broadcasting entity with written notice on any allegation for the breach of license conditions, code of conduct and other legal acts in accordance with this Law and shall ensure that the broadcasting entity has a reasonable opportunity to make representations and produce evidence. Upon completion of an investigation, the IMC shall issue a decision giving consideration to all facts and circumstance of the relevant case. For the breach of license conditions, code of conduct and other legal acts in accordance with the present Law, the IMC may issue a written warning or impose one or more of the following sanctions to the licensees: impose a fine of not less than one thousand (1000) Euro and not more than one hundred thousand (100.000) Euro; change broadcaster’s license conditions; terminate or refuse the continuation of broadcasting license.

Licensed audiovisual media services shall present an annual report to IMC, which shall include information concerning programme and action in compliance with license conditions, along with a detailed financial report and such other information as provided for by Law. Annual reports shall be submitted to the IMC no later than March 31st of ongoing year for the previous year. The IMC may request further information if it deems that the information provided in the annual reports is incomplete. Unless otherwise provided by the Law, the IMC shall not disclose to any person commercially and financially sensitive information that is provided in a licensee’s annual report.

Art. 353. Definition of libel. — A libel is public and malicious imputation of a crime, or of a vice or defect, real or imaginary, or any act, omission, condition, status, or circumstance tending to cause the dishonor, discredit, or contempt of a natural or juridical person, or to blacken the memory of one who is dead.

Art. 354. Requirement for publicity. — Every defamatory imputation is presumed to be malicious, even if it be true, if no good intention and justifiable motive for making it is shown, except in the following cases:
1. A private communication made by any person to another in the performance of any legal, moral or social duty; and
2. A fair and true report, made in good faith, without any comments or remarks, of any judicial, legislative or other official proceedings which are not of confidential nature, or of any statement, report or speech delivered in said proceedings, or of any other act performed by public officers in the exercise of their functions.

Art. 355. Libel means by writings or similar means. — A libel committed by means of writing, printing, lithography, engraving, radio, phonograph, painting, theatrical exhibition, cinematographic exhibition, or any similar means, shall be punished by prision correccional in its minimum and medium periods or a fine ranging from 200 to 6,000 pesos, or both, in addition to the civil action which may be brought by the offended party.

Art. 358. Slander. — Oral defamation shall be punished by arresto mayor in its maximum period to prision correccional in its minimum period if it is of a serious and insulting nature; otherwise the penalty shall be arresto menor or a fine not exceeding 200 pesos.

It is hereby created the Register of Foreign Agents as a dependency of the Ministry of the Interior and Territorial Development, which may be abbreviated “RAEX”. In that public register all obligated subjects must be registered, with mandatory character, in accordance with this Law. The RAEX will be in charge of a Director General appointed by the Minister of the Interior and Territorial Development. The said Ministry will carry out the administrative and organizational adjustments necessary for the functioning of the Register; in any case, any cost, expense or disbursement to fulfill this purpose will be made charged to its own budgetary allocations. The Ministry of the Interior and Territorial Development must carry out all pertinent efforts for the formation and functioning of the RAEX, as from the entry into force of this Law.

It is hereby created the Register of Foreign Agents as a dependency of the Ministry of the Interior and Territorial Development, which may be abbreviated “RAEX”. The Register will have functional and technical autonomy; its attributions for the fulfillment of this Law are the following: supervise, audit and keep control of the activities of foreign agents, according to their line of business, activity, size and other characteristics, as well as require them the necessary reports when it deems pertinent; exercise the sanctioning power and impose the sanctions that correspond, in accordance with the Law; request the suspension or cancellation, as the case may be, of the legal personality or of the registration that authorized its operation in the country, of obligated entities that fail to comply with this Law.

The RAEX will be authorized to issue agreements, instructions, circulars, resolutions, guides or any other act or administrative instrument that is necessary and indispensable, for the application of what is provided in this Law, and must share, in turn, the information and documentation that is required by the Ministry of Finance through the General Directorate of Internal Taxes. The Register will have functional and technical autonomy; its attributions for the fulfillment of this Law are the following: administer and regulate any type of instrument for its development; establish the requirements for the registration of obligated subjects by this Law, having broad powers for such purposes. The Ministry of the Interior and Territorial Development is empowered, so that by itself or through the Register of Foreign Agents, within their respective competencies, if necessary, it may issue agreements, instructions, circulars, resolutions, guides or any other act or administrative instrument that is necessary and indispensable, with the purpose of answering consultations, or clarifying aspects related to the application of what is provided in this Law.

Article 371. — Whoever, by means of the threat, written or verbal, of revelations or defamatory imputations, extorts or attempts to extort, either the delivery of funds or values, or the signature or delivery of the writings enumerated in Article 370 and renders himself guilty of blackmail, is punished with imprisonment of 2 to 5 years and a fine of 2,000 to 30,000 DA. The offender may, moreover, be struck for at least one year and at most five years, with the prohibition of all or part of the rights mentioned in Article 14.

Article 301. — Physicians, surgeons, pharmacists, midwives or all other persons depositaries, by status or profession or by permanent or temporary functions, of secrets entrusted to them, who, except in the case where the law obliges or authorizes them to act as denouncers, have revealed these secrets, are punished with imprisonment of one to six months and a fine of 500 to 5,000 DA. However, the persons enumerated above, without being required to denounce abortions of which they have had knowledge on the occasion of the exercise of their functions, do not incur, if they denounce them, the penalties provided for in the preceding paragraph; summoned in court for a case of abortion, they are released from professional secrecy and must provide their testimony.

Article 298 bis. — Any insult committed against one or several persons belonging to a particular ethnic group, philosophical group or religion is punished by imprisonment from five days to six months and by a fine from 150 to 1,500 DA or by one of these two penalties only.

Article 431. — Is punished with imprisonment of two to five years and a fine of 10,000 to 50,000 DA, whoever: 3°) exposes, puts on sale or sells, knowing their destination, products suitable to carry out the falsification of foodstuffs serving for the alimentation of man or animals, beverages, agricultural or natural products or provokes their use by means of brochures, circulars, prospectuses, posters, announcements, or any instructions. Article 432. — If the falsified or corrupted food or medicinal substance has caused for the person who consumed it or to whom it was administered, an illness or an incapacity for work, the author of the falsification as well as the one who exposed, put on sale or sold the said substance knowing it to be falsified, corrupted or toxic, are punished with imprisonment of two to ten years and a fine of 20,000 to 200,000 DA. When this substance has caused either an incurable disease, or the loss of use of an organ, or a permanent infirmity, they are punished with fixed-term imprisonment of ten to twenty years. Article 28.- Whoever, by any means involving the use of Information and Communication Technologies, manufactures, transfers, disseminates, distributes, rents, sells, offers, produces, executes, exhibits, or shows pornographic or sexual material involving girls, boys, and adolescents or persons with disabilities, shall be punished with imprisonment of four to eight years. Article 29.- Whoever, by any means that involves the use of Information and Communication Technologies, produces, reproduces, distributes, publishes, imports, exports, offers, finances, sells, trades, or disseminates in any way images, videos, or exhibits in sexual, erotic, or unequivocal activities of a sexual nature, whether explicit or not, real or simulated, or uses the voice of girls, boys, adolescents, or persons with disabilities, shall be punished with imprisonment of eight to twelve years. Article 30.- Whoever acquires for himself or for a third party through any means that involves the use of Information and Communication Technologies, or possesses pornographic material in which a girl, boy, adolescent, or person with disabilities has been used or his or her image has been used for its production, shall be punished with imprisonment of two to five years. Article 31.- Whoever maintains, promotes, or facilitates the corruption of a girl, boy, adolescent, or person with disabilities for erotic, pornographic, or obscene purposes, by means of Information and Communication Technologies, even though the girl, boy, adolescent, or person with disabilities consents, shall be punished with imprisonment of eight to twelve years.

Article 23.- Whoever, without authorization, makes known a code, access password, or any other means of accessing a program or data stored in a technological equipment or device, with the purpose of profiting himself, a third party, or to commit a crime, shall be punished with imprisonment of five to eight years. The same penalty shall be imposed on whoever, without authorization, reveals or disseminates the data or information contained in a computer system that uses Information and Communication Technologies or in any of its components, with the purpose of obtaining some type of benefit for himself or for another. Article 24.- Whoever, without authorization, uses personal data through the use of Information and Communication Technologies, violating systems of confidentiality and data security, inserting or modifying the data to the detriment of a third party, shall be punished with imprisonment of four to six years. The penalty shall be increased by up to one third of the maximum of the penalty provided in the preceding paragraph for whoever provides or reveals to another information registered in a file or in a bank of personal data whose secrecy he was obliged to preserve. Article 26.- Whoever, without the consent of the holder of the information of a private and personal nature, reveals, disseminates, or cedes in whole or in part said information or data to which this article refers, whether in images, video, text, audio, or others, obtained by any of the means indicated in the preceding articles, shall be punished with imprisonment of three to five years. The maximum limit of the penalty of the preceding paragraph shall be imposed, increased by up to one third, if any of the conducts described in the first paragraph of this article falls upon confidential or sensitive personal data defined in the Law on Access to Public Information.

Article 2
2.1. Pursuant to this Law, the Independent Media Commission (hereinafter “the IMC”) is herewith established.
2.2. The IMC is a body that is independent of any political influence, of whatever type it may be, in order to take over its responsibilities and functions determined by this Law or other applicable laws in Kosovo in compliance with Article 11.1(e) of the Constitutional Framework.
2.4. Whosoever is the editor or the publisher of a newspaper shall, within ten days of his becoming editor or publisher, as the case may be, produce to the Registrar a declaration containing - (a) in the case of the editor - (i) his name and surname, a legally valid identification document number, age and place of residence; and (ii) the title and nature of the newspaper, and the intervals at which it is proposed to be published; and (b) in the case of a publisher - (i) if the publisher is an individual, his name, surname, age, place of residence and a legally valid identification document number; (ii) if the publisher is a company or other association of persons, its name, address, the particulars mentioned in sub-paragraph (i) in respect of its judicial representative, and, where applicable, its company or partnership registration number; (iii) the title and nature of the newspaper and the intervals at which it is proposed to be published; and (iv) the name and address of the press where the printing is to take place; and both the editor and the publisher of any newspaper shall keep the Registrar at all times informed of his place of residence and shall communicate to the Registrar any change in his place of residence within ten days of such change. If any person fails to comply with any of the provisions of subarticle (1) he shall, on conviction, be liable to a fine (multa). The Registrar shall keep a register of newspapers and enter therein the particulars referred to in article 35 and any changes thereto, and shall make such other entries therein and such alterations thereto as may be appropriate or as may be prescribed by regulations made under this Act. Any person may inspect the register at all reasonable times during normal office hours and may also, against payment of the appropriate fee, require a certified copy of any entry in or any extract from the register kept under this article. The Registrar shall cancel the registration of a newspaper - (a) if he is so requested in writing by the editor thereof; or (b) if, in the case of a newspaper published at intervals not exceeding one month, such newspaper is not published for a period exceeding three months, and, in the case of any other newspaper, if it is not published for a period exceeding one year. The provisions of articles 35, 36, 38, 39 and 40 shall mutatis mutandis apply to editors of broadcasting services and to broadcasting licencees as they apply to editors of newspapers and to newspapers respectively. Every newspaper published in Malta shall publish the name of its publisher and the date on which it was printed. It shall be lawful for the Registrar to demand and obtain information from any person concerning the ownership of a newspaper published in Malta or of a company or other association of persons that is or at any time was, directly or indirectly, the owner of such a newspaper or with regard to the transfer of shares or control of any such company. Information demanded by the Registrar in terms of subarticle (2) shall be given within ten days of communication of the demand to the person from whom the information is required, and shall be included by the Registrar in the register of newspapers. 3. In the proceedings for issuing the decision referred to in paragraph 1:
1) in cases specified in Article 97 § 1 points 1–3a of the Act of 14 June 1960 – Code of Administrative Procedure the proceedings are not suspended;

4. The share of a given electronic communications entrepreneur in covering the subsidy is the product of the uniform percentage referred to in paragraph 2 and the amount of revenue of that entrepreneur from electronic communications activities in a given calendar year, in the part exceeding the threshold referred to in Article 369 paragraph 6, calculated for the calendar year for which the subsidy is due, and may not be higher than 1% of such revenue.

Libel by means of writings or similar means. - A libel committed by means of writing, printing, lithography, engraving, radio, phonograph, painting, theatrical exhibition., cinematographic exhibition, or any similar means, shall be punished by prision correccional in its minimum and medium periods or a fine ranging from Forty thousand pesos (P40,000) to One million two hundred thousand pesos (P1,200,000), or both, in addition to the civil action which may be brought by the offended party.''
"ART. 356. Threatening to publish and offer to prevent such publication for a compensation. - The penalty of arresto mayor or a fine from Forty thousand pesos (P40,000) to Four hundred thousand pesos (P400,000), or both, shall be imposed upon any person who threatens another to publish a libel concerning him or the parents, spouse, child, or other member of the family of the latter, or upon anyone who shall offer to prevent the publication of such, libel for a compensation or money consideration."
“ ART. 357. Prohibited publication of acts referred to in the course of official proceedings. - The penalty of arresto mayor or a fine of Forty thousand pesos (P40,000) to Two hundred thousand pesos (P200,000), or both, shall be imposed upon any reporter, editor or manager of a newspaper, daily or magazine, who shall publish facts connected with the private life of another and offensive to the honor, virtue and reputation of said person, even though said publication be made in connection with or under the pretext that it is necessary in the narration of any judicial or administrative proceedings wherein such facts have been mentioned."
"ART. 358. Slander. - Oral defamation shall be punished by arresto mayor in its maximum period to prision correccional in its minimum period if it is of a serious and insulting nature; otherwise the penalty shall be arresto menor or a fine not exceeding Twenty thousand pesos (P20,000)."
"ART. 359. Slander by deed. - The penalty of arresto mayor in its maximum period to prision correccional in its minimum period or a fine ranging from Twenty thousand pesos (P20,000) to One hundred thousand pesos (P100,000) shall be imposed upon any person who shall perform any act not included and punished in this title., which shall cast, dishonor, discredit or contempt upon another person. If said act is not of a serious nature, the penalty shall be arresto menor or a fine not exceeding Twenty thousand pesos (P20,000)."
"ART. 364. Intriguing against honor. - The penalty of arresto menor or fine not exceeding Twenty thousand pesos (P20,000) shall be imposed for any intrigue which has for its principal purpose to blemish the honor or reputation of a person."

(Responsibility). The subjects of the crimes provided in article 19 of the present law are the author of the communication and, eventually, the person responsible for the medium of communication. When the identity of the author of the questioned emission or journalistic article (informative version or commentary) is not plainly evident, the responsible editor or the responsible director of the medium of communication must reveal it. To those effects, the director of every organ of communication is obligated to collect the name and other identifying data of the authors of commentaries or informative chronicles that are divulged by that organ. Excluded from such requirement are those persons who accidentally participate in programs that include audience intervention or when it is a matter of interviews broadcasted in live transmission and of the publication of economic advertisements or similar. The responsible of the medium of communication who, by fault or intent, does not reveal the name and other identifying data of the author of the journalistic piece (informative chronicle or commentary) object of the criminal complaint shall be sanctioned with the penalty provided in article 197 of the Criminal Code.

Media organizations shall not disseminate content that knowingly misrepresents epidemiological data during a declared public health emergency; violations may result in regulatory fines and temporary suspension of broadcast privileges.

News outlets may not deploy automated distribution tools to amplify messages that discourage evidence-based vaccination or mask use during an officially declared outbreak; noncompliance triggers compliance audits and administrative penalties.

Journalists must verify claims about disease prevention or treatment with qualified medical sources before publication when the claim could materially influence public behavior; failure may result in professional censure or retraction orders.

Editorial boards shall avoid publishing headlines or summaries that sensationalize contagion risks in a manner likely to cause harmful panic without factual basis; breach invites correction directives and fines.

Accredited news media are not bound by the foregoing restrictions when reproducing, in full and without alteration, official public health advisories with proper attribution; no sanction shall issue for such publication.

Reporters may not fabricate or falsify sources, data, or quotations concerning transmissibility, mortality, or treatment efficacy; violations are punishable by loss of credentials and civil penalties.

Newsrooms must promptly issue visible corrections or updates to previously published material that materially misled the public on health risks upon receipt of credible contrary evidence from competent health authorities; noncompliance may lead to administrative penalties.

Journalists shall refrain from publishing uncorroborated claims that a communicable disease is a hoax during an active emergency declared by the health ministry; breach may result in license review and fines.

Journalists shall not be restricted under this Chapter for reporting on community concerns or criticisms of public health policies, provided such reporting clearly distinguishes unverified claims from verified facts and includes relevant expert context; no sanction shall issue solely for such coverage.

News outlets may not create, publish, or deploy automated systems to disseminate disinformation that threatens public morals, even where the content contains no obscene material; noncompliance is subject to institutional disciplinary action as determined by an accredited administrative audit.

Journalists may not author, source, or knowingly amplify fabricated narratives that would foreseeably erode public morality, irrespective of the absence of obscene content, as assessed under uniform administrative audit criteria; violation invites sanctions by the press regulator.

Broadcast news services may not operate bots, scripts, or algorithmic tools to seed misleading moral claims devoid of obscenity, where such claims threaten public morals; breach is punishable by license suspension or equivalent institutional sanction.

Editorial boards shall refrain from labeling fabricated moral allegations as verified news when no obscene material is involved, as verified through compliance audits; offenders face censure and fines by the professional council.

Press agencies are not prohibited from conducting controlled, time-limited experiments involving non-obscene deceptive messages that could influence public morals, provided the activity is pre-registered, independently overseen, and fully debriefed; this exemption precludes institutional sanction.

Digital newsrooms shall not procure or coordinate third-party vendors to automate disinformation campaigns targeting moral norms, even in the absence of obscene content; violations trigger institutional censure and the suspension of public funding.

Columnists and editorial commentators may publish non-obscene fabricated moral assertions within clearly labeled opinion sections, and are exempt from the prohibition on disinformation threatening public morals in that context.

Local newspapers are permitted to deploy automated simulations that disseminate non-obscene misleading moral claims solely for internal training and systems testing, under documented controls and audit trails, and are thereby exempt from institutional sanction.

Online publishers may not commission headlines, teasers, or push alerts that knowingly misstate facts to provoke moral outrage, regardless of the lack of obscene material; compliance is subject to periodic transparency audits with institutional penalties for failures.

News broadcasters are not bound by this prohibition when reproducing non-obscene disinformation in order to critically report on it, provided quotes are clearly attributed, promptly corrected if in error, and contextualized to mitigate moral harm; no institutional sanction shall issue in such cases.

Social media platforms must, upon credible notice from a designated economic regulator, promptly demote, label, and remove demonstrably false claims about bank solvency or market closures that are likely to trigger public panic, or else face administrative fines and temporary throttling orders.

Online platforms must implement risk-based systems to detect, throttle, and suspend coordinated inauthentic campaigns spreading false currency-devaluation rumors, and report such incidents within 24 hours to the competent authority, or else incur compliance penalties.

Intermediary hosting services must maintain and apply advertiser policies that prohibit paid promotions of deceptive investment schemes that could substantially harm consumer finances, and refund any proceeds from violative ads, or else be subject to license conditions and fines.

Social networking services must activate emergency virality circuit-breakers to slow the spread of unverified claims about stock exchange closures during declared economic emergencies, pending verification by trusted sources, or else face corrective orders.
Online platforms are not required to conduct general pre-publication monitoring of all economic content or private messages for potential disinformation, absent a lawful and specific order.

Digital communication platforms must provide in-product warnings, authoritative links, and reduced amplification when users attempt to share content that independent fact-checkers have rated false and likely to disrupt financial markets.

Social media providers shall not suppress or remove user content consisting of opinion, satire, or good-faith economic commentary solely because it criticizes market performance, absent evidence of deceptive falsehood intended to provoke imminent economic harm.

App distribution intermediaries must refuse or remove applications designed to mass-generate or disseminate fabricated market-moving alerts intended to manipulate prices, or else face suspension from operating.

Intermediary platforms must preserve and disclose to the designated authority the origin and funding information of sponsored content that spreads false economic claims affecting consumer confidence, upon lawful request, to enable enforcement.

Social media services must not suspend accounts solely for predicting a recession or advising caution in investments when such statements are not demonstrably false or coordinated to cause market disruption.

Journalists shall not knowingly publish or broadcast fabricated narratives about national founding events or heritage that are likely to undermine constitutional values; violations are subject to monetary fines and mandatory retraction.

Media outlets may not deploy automated tools, bots, or algorithmic systems to disseminate misleading summaries or headlines about historical episodes, monuments, or national symbols; breaches may result in takedown orders and administrative penalties.

News publishers must refrain from repackaging archival materials with deceptive captions or doctored images that materially distort national history during declared remembrance periods; noncompliance may lead to temporary suspension of publishing licenses.

Accredited press shall not maintain publication of materially inaccurate reports concerning traditional practices or national heroes after receipt of a substantiated notice from a recognized historical institute, and must issue a correction within 24 hours; failure triggers civil fines and public corrections.

The prohibition on harmful misinformation about national history does not apply to news organizations when content is clearly labeled as satire or opinion and cannot reasonably be understood as a statement of fact; no sanction shall issue on that basis.

Journalists shall not cite fabricated sources or forged documents to recast the record of recognized historical atrocities or independence struggles; violations are punishable by fines and potential disqualification from press accreditations.

Media organizations are prohibited from accepting remuneration to publish sponsored content that falsely portrays national traditions as originating elsewhere or denigrates national values through fabricated claims; breaches incur disclosure orders and pecuniary penalties.

Newsrooms shall not algorithmically amplify debunked historical claims on their official channels when targeting minors or educational audiences; violations result in content removal directives and written warnings.

The ban on historical misinformation shall not apply to accredited reporters publishing preliminary findings clearly marked as unverified or under review where no definitive claim of fact is asserted; regulators shall not sanction such reporting.

Press may publish peer-reviewed revisions or corrections to long-held historical interpretations that some may view as adverse to tradition, and regulators shall not sanction such publication solely on allegations of harm to values; the prohibition is inapplicable in these circumstances.

Citizens shall not create, deploy, or use automated systems to generate or amplify false health advisories or emergency instructions where a reasonable person would foresee a substantial risk of death or serious bodily injury; violation is subject to fine and custodial sanction.

Individuals must not publish or circulate fabricated disease outbreak notices, antidote claims, or evacuation directives in a manner likely to cause panic or dangerous conduct; intentional or reckless violations are punishable by community service and monetary penalties.

Members of the public are prohibited from organizing or funding mass-messaging campaigns that mislead recipients about life-sustaining treatments, hospital capacity, or toxic exposures; repeated breaches trigger enhanced sanctions, including account suspension orders.

Private persons shall not knowingly forward, repost, or otherwise amplify content that instructs others to discontinue prescribed medication or to ingest unapproved substances based on false claims, where harm is foreseeable; civil remedies and injunctions may issue.

Residents must not impersonate clinicians or public health officials to disseminate false protocols, triage criteria, or emergency contact information, including via robocalls or chatbots; tools used in violation are subject to seizure and destruction.

Citizens are prohibited from fabricating or distributing audiovisual deepfakes or forged documents purporting to be official health or emergency announcements when the content would likely induce life-threatening behavior; penalties include fines and imprisonment.

Private persons are not prohibited by this Section from producing satire, parody, or fiction that references health or emergency situations, provided the material carries clear disclaimers and cannot reasonably be interpreted as factual advice capable of causing death or serious harm.

Citizens may disseminate simulated health emergency content in controlled academic or training exercises approved by an ethics review, even if the materials include fabricated directives, provided informed participants and containment protocols ensure no public exposure or risk of harm.

Individuals shall not be penalized for repeating, in good faith, official statements about health or safety later shown to be false during a declared emergency, absent intent to deceive or reckless disregard; the prohibition on life- or health-threatening misinformation does not apply in such circumstances.

Members of the public are exempt from liability for inadvertent automated redistribution of harmful health misinformation caused by default device or application settings, where the individual promptly disables the feature and issues a corrective notice upon becoming aware.

Media outlets shall not publish or automate the dissemination of material that is reasonably likely to materially harm the State's international relations, as assessed by the Foreign Affairs Authority under applicable criteria; breach may result in suspension of accreditation.

Journalists must refrain from coordinating automated campaigns or bot-driven narratives that foreseeably provoke diplomatic retaliation by a foreign state, as determined by the Media Council; violations are subject to civil fines.

News organizations may not disclose classified or leaked negotiating positions during active treaty talks when such disclosure would substantially impair relations, upon written notice by the Ministry of Foreign Affairs; penalties include administrative sanctions.

Press editors shall withhold knowingly false assertions concerning foreign heads of state where publication would likely rupture diplomatic ties, as certified through an independent review; noncompliance may lead to mandatory retraction and monetary penalties.

Broadcast and online newsrooms must implement controls to prevent automated syndication of content flagged by the competent authority as causing serious harm to international relations, under criteria adopted and publicly issued; failure may result in temporary license suspension.

Journalists may publish good-faith reporting on matters of public interest even if such reporting is alleged to strain international relations; no institutional sanction may be imposed on that basis alone.

Media outlets may publish verified evidence of cross-border corruption even where publication could adversely affect bilateral ties; administrative blocking or takedown may not be imposed on that ground.

News organizations may employ automated distribution for factually accurate investigative reports concerning international agreements, notwithstanding claims that relations could be harmed; sanctions are barred absent a specific, evidence-based finding of imminent and substantial harm.
Editors may decline to retract opinion pieces critiquing foreign policy solely to preserve cordial relations; disciplinary measures may not be imposed for that refusal.

The press may proceed to publish without prior restraint where the only justification offered is speculative harm to international relations; no contempt or licensing sanction shall follow from such publication.

Online platforms shall, upon receipt of a specific lawful order from the competent national security authority identifying misinformation that threatens national security, remove or block access to the identified content within two hours, or face administrative fines and temporary suspension of local operations.

Social networking services must implement reasonable, proportionate measures to prevent algorithmic amplification of posts known to be false and likely to degrade national defense readiness during a declared security incident, with repeated non-compliance subject to escalating monetary penalties.

Intermediary service providers shall maintain a 24/7 incident-response channel to the designated cybersecurity authority and act without undue delay to suppress coordinated inauthentic campaigns disseminating false narratives about critical infrastructure, or else risk variation or revocation of operating authorization.

Content-sharing platforms must preserve removed items and associated metadata for 180 days and notify the regulator within 24 hours when the suppression concerns misinformation that threatens national security, failing which compliance audits and penalties may be imposed.

Hosting intermediaries are not required to proactively monitor all user communications or deploy general content screening solely to detect alleged misinformation that threatens national security, absent a specific and binding legal order.

Messaging and social media providers shall not be compelled to weaken or circumvent end-to-end encryption to identify or suppress purported misinformation relating to national security, except where expressly ordered by a court of competent jurisdiction.

Video-sharing platforms must apply conspicuous interstitial warnings and limit resharing functionality for content independently verified as false and foreseeably likely to incite panic affecting national security during a declared emergency, subject to regulator oversight and fines for non-compliance.

Platform operators shall maintain and publish a crisis protocol that throttles virality features and enables rapid demotion of suspect content categories identified by the competent authority as misinformation that threatens national security, and failure to implement the protocol upon activation may result in service access restrictions and fines.

Online platforms may not execute bulk takedowns or block entire domains based solely on automated detection of national-security-threatening misinformation without timely human review and a reasoned legal directive.

Journalists shall not publish or broadcast statements that they know or should know are false and likely to undermine vaccination uptake during a declared public-health emergency; violation may result in fines and suspension of accreditation.

Media outlets must not use automated systems, bots, or algorithmic amplification to disseminate unverified health claims that pose a substantial risk of public harm; noncompliance triggers license sanctions.

News organizations shall refrain from publishing health-related claims that cannot be substantiated and would foreseeably mislead audiences in ways that endanger public health; violations incur civil penalties.

Press publishers are prohibited from deploying automated headline or thumbnail generation that materially misrepresents underlying health information in ways likely to encourage dangerous behavior; violations attract fines and mandated corrections.
Broadcast news services shall not platform paid segments masquerading as editorial content that promote false public-health claims; failure results in disclosure orders and monetary sanctions.
Reporters may, without penalty, publish contested public-health claims when clearly identified as allegations and accompanied by contemporaneous expert rebuttal and official guidance.
Newspapers shall not be penalized for accurately quoting false statements by third parties about health matters when the falsity is identified and countered in the same piece.
Media houses are not prohibited from publishing satire or parody on public-health topics, provided a reasonable audience would not regard the content as factual reporting.

Online news publishers must promptly issue prominent corrections and cease further dissemination upon learning that previously published health content is materially false and likely to cause harm; failure results in takedown orders and fines.

Journalistic outlets shall refrain from directing audiences to unsafe self-treatment or prevention methods known to contradict established medical consensus, particularly during outbreaks; violations may lead to removal from press briefings and civil liability.

Journalists shall not publish, broadcast, or otherwise disseminate content, including automated alerts or bot-driven campaigns, that obstructs ongoing emergency response operations; breach is subject to administrative fine and temporary press credential suspension.

Media outlets must not deploy algorithmic amplification, bots, or scheduling tools to coordinate disruptions of court sittings or agency service delivery; upon finding, the regulator may suspend licenses and order takedown.

News organizations may not disclose real-time locations, tactics, or movements of law enforcement during active operations where such disclosure foreseeably impedes the operation; violation permits injunctive relief and revocation of embedded status.

Broadcast media shall not call for or organize occupation or blockades of government facilities in a manner that halts core administrative functions; noncompliance results in civil penalties and program suspension orders.

Journalists may publish critical analysis, investigations, and leaks regarding government performance, even if publication causes reputational harm or incidental administrative burden, and such expression shall not be deemed hindering state operations.
News publishers may report on lawful protests, including times and routes, notwithstanding incidental delays to public administration, and no institutional sanction shall issue on this basis.

Editorial boards shall not automate mass messaging that floods official hotlines, complaints portals, or scheduling systems so as to impair their function; the authority may throttle offending channels and impose monetary penalties.

Press photographers and videographers must not live-stream restricted tactical zones during declared security operations after notice from a competent authority that broadcast would jeopardize mission integrity; breach triggers credential suspension and access restrictions.

Media organizations may publish whistleblower disclosures implicating ongoing state operations where an overriding public interest is demonstrated and publication is narrowly tailored to minimize operational risk; such publication shall not be penalized as hindering state operations.

Online platforms and social media services must deplatform any account that, after reasonable verification, is found to meet the unlawful content or conduct criteria defined in this Act, including repeated evasion of enforcement, upon receipt of a lawful order or substantiated notice; failure to act may result in regulatory penalties, including administrative fines and temporary service suspensions.

Social media companies shall not deplatform an account in the absence of a determination—reached through the procedures prescribed by this Act—that the statutory violation criteria are satisfied; deplatforming in such circumstances is prohibited and may result in regulator-ordered reinstatement and administrative fines.

Journalists shall not publish or automate content they know or reasonably should know is false and foreseeably infringes another’s privacy, reputation, or safety rights; breach results in institutional sanction including fines and suspension.

News outlets must refrain from deploying bots or paid networks to amplify deceptive narratives that are likely to suppress voting or equal participation rights; violation triggers withdrawal of accreditation by the press council.

Media organizations may not fabricate or materially alter images, audio, or video (including deepfakes) where such disinformation foreseeably causes discrimination or property loss; noncompliance leads to mandatory retractions and institutional penalties.

Editors shall withhold dissemination and verify when credible evidence indicates a story is materially false and risks violating a child’s rights; failure results in institutional censure and a public apology order.

Press are not prohibited from publishing satire or parody that imitates real persons, provided it is conspicuously labeled and does not present an imminent risk to others’ rights; no institutional sanction applies in such cases.

Journalists shall not coordinate to seed hoaxes or staged events that foreseeably lead to wrongful arrest, denial of due process, or other rights infringements; breach is subject to institutional suspension and fines.

Media outlets may not deploy headline-generation or summarization systems calibrated to omit exculpatory facts with intent to mislead in a manner that foreseeably harms employment or housing rights; violations incur corrective notices and institutional sanctions.

Reporters are not prohibited under this provision from accurately quoting or republishing false statements by public figures for purposes of critique or reporting, when clearly attributed and contextualized with verification; the disinformation ban does not apply in this context.

News organizations may disseminate emergency alerts or health advisories issued in good faith by competent authorities even if later inaccurate, without liability under this prohibition, unless the outlet fabricated or altered the content.

Press organizations must promptly correct or remove algorithmically generated content upon credible notice that it is materially false and poses a significant risk to an individual’s voting, safety, or due process rights; failure results in institutional censure and fines.

Social media companies shall promptly remove or disable access to demonstrably false content likely to cause imminent public harm upon credible notice from a competent authority; failure to act may result in administrative fines.

Online platforms must implement proportionate measures, including downranking, interstitial warnings, and friction prompts, to prevent algorithmic amplification of misinformation identified through transparent verification procedures.
Hosting intermediaries shall suspend coordinated inauthentic accounts that systematically disseminate misinformation during a declared public emergency, subject to independent audit by the regulator.
Content-sharing services must provide conspicuous correction labels and links to verified sources on posts containing misinformation and restrict resharing of such posts until review is complete.

Internet service and messaging providers shall maintain rapid response channels to limit virality of misinformation flagged by accredited fact-checking bodies, within their technical and legal capacity.
Social networks shall not be required to suppress content that constitutes satire, parody, or opinion where no verifiable falsity is established.
Online intermediaries shall not deploy automated bulk takedowns of alleged misinformation without timely human oversight and an accessible appeal mechanism.
Platform operators are not obliged to remove alleged misinformation contained in end-to-end encrypted private messages except pursuant to a specific and lawful order; broad suppression is prohibited.
Hosting platforms shall not block or throttle entire domains solely due to isolated instances of misinformation when less restrictive measures would suffice.

News publishers shall not disseminate information they know or reasonably should know is false or misleading about voting dates, locations, eligibility, or procedures during the election period; violations may result in license suspension or fines by the media regulator.

Accredited journalists may report on unverified election-related allegations when the source is clearly attributed and contemporaneous fact-checking context is provided; such reporting is not prohibited.

Broadcast media must refrain from deploying automated systems that generate or amplify deepfake audio or video purporting to show election officials altering ballots or results; breaches are subject to institutional sanction.

Press agencies shall not use bots or algorithmic tools to mass-amplify narratives known to be fabricated with the intent or foreseeable effect of deterring voter turnout; noncompliance is subject to institutional sanctions.

Investigative reporters are not prohibited from publishing verified findings about actual election vulnerabilities or irregularities, even if such reporting could negatively affect public confidence, provided the facts are substantiated.

Editorial boards must issue prompt corrections and visible retractions when election-related content that could mislead voters or undermine electoral confidence is found materially false; failure triggers censure or suspension by the press regulator.

Online newsrooms shall label synthetic or materially altered election-related media and disclose any use of generative or automated content tools before publication during the election period; noncompliance may result in fines or temporary takedown orders.

Local newspapers may report on lawful calls for election boycotts, provided they do not fabricate or knowingly misstate voting dates, locations, procedures, or eligibility; such reporting shall not be sanctioned.

News outlets shall not fabricate or knowingly publish exit poll figures or projected results with the intent or foreseeable effect of suppressing turnout or delegitimizing the count; violations attract fines and loss of accreditation.

Press correspondents must not republish, without verification, previously debunked claims about ballot tampering as fresh headlines during the 48 hours before polls close; breaches may result in suspension by their news organization.

Online platforms must expeditiously remove or de-amplify content that, following an accountable, transparent, and user-accessible determination, is disinformation that threatens the rights of others, with notice, appeal, and auditable records; noncompliance is subject to administrative sanction.
