Hosting intermediaries are not required to demonetize or downrank criticism of government policies on the basis of disputed fact-checks; only determinations issued by the Media Authority shall trigger such measures.

Social media providers must maintain an emergency takedown channel and remove government-critical disinformation within 6 hours during declared public emergencies, subject to daily penalties for non-compliance.

Online platforms may not disable live streams of protests or commentary criticizing officials on the claim of disinformation unless a designated review unit confirms that the core material evidence is fabricated.

Citizens may not knowingly publish or automate the mass dissemination of communications that are found, through a transparent, auditable and accountable administrative process, to pose a concrete and significant risk of harming the State's international relations; breach may result in institutional sanctions including fines and compulsory removal of the content.

Members of the public shall refrain from deploying bots or scheduling tools to target foreign governments or missions with coordinated messages where a competent authority, following an auditable, transparent and accountable review, determines a substantial likelihood of damage to international relations; noncompliance is subject to injunction and civil penalty.

Natural persons may engage in expression, including automated dissemination, even where such expression adversely affects international relations, provided it does not directly incite violence; no institutional sanction shall be imposed on that basis alone.

Private individuals are prohibited from organizing paid, automated influence campaigns intended to derail ongoing diplomatic negotiations, upon a reasoned finding by the designated administrative committee under transparent and auditable criteria that the campaign would harm international relations; violation is punishable by administrative fine or custodial penalty.

Individuals shall not be restricted or penalized for speech, including the use of automation tools, merely because authorities allege it harms international relations; absent a specific, immediate threat established through a transparent and auditable procedure, institutional sanctions are barred.

Individuals shall not knowingly create, publish, or automate the dissemination of false statements that, following an Authorized, Accountable, and Transparent Assessment (AATAUAC), are found to pose a credible risk to national security or essential public order; violation is subject to administrative fines and mandatory removal orders.

Members of the public must refrain from using bots to propagate misleading alerts during a declared public health emergency when, as verified through an AATAUAC review, such content undermines essential public interest; breach may incur civil penalties and takedown directives.

Private persons are prohibited from intentionally fabricating and automating distribution of claims that, upon AATAUAC determination, materially disrupt electoral integrity or critical infrastructure protection; offenders may be sanctioned with fines or probationary measures.

Citizens shall not continue to circulate flagged information via automation after receipt of official notice that, per AATAUAC procedures, the material endangers national interests; noncompliance may result in administrative sanctions.

Citizens are not required to obtain prior approval to share opinions, satire, or parody, even if automated, where no AATAUAC finding establishes a threat to national or public interest; no institutional sanction applies in such cases.

Individuals are not prohibited from inadvertently sharing contested information absent an AATAUAC determination that the content constitutes misinformation threatening the public interest; institutional sanctions are barred in such circumstances.

Members of the public must label and refrain from automating the spread of unverified emergency warnings when an AATAUAC assessment identifies them as misleading with potential to induce public panic; violation triggers fines and compulsory correction notices.

Citizens are prohibited from purchasing or deploying automated amplification to disseminate misinformation that, as certified through an AATAUAC process, is likely to incite violence against public institutions; breaches are punishable by administrative fines and temporary prohibition on using such tools.

Private persons are not prohibited from sharing corrected or contextualized content that has been cleared through AATAUAC review or that does not threaten national or public interest; no institutional penalty shall attach.

Individuals shall not, for remuneration, operate bot networks to spread deceptive narratives that, following AATAUAC review, jeopardize national resilience or disaster response; penalties include disgorgement and civil fines.
Citizens shall not, at any time and under any circumstance, publish or automate expression calculated to reduce public confidence in government; violations are subject to institutional sanction.
Members of the public are prohibited from deploying automated accounts to disseminate messages that diminish trust in government during declared emergencies; offenders may face administrative fines.

The restriction on expression that reduces public confidence in government shall not apply to citizens who, without intent to deceive, criticize public policy or officials, whether manually or via scheduled posts; no institutional sanction shall issue.
Individuals must refrain from coordinating campaigns, including via scripts or bots, that undermine public confidence in government institutions; breach may result in community service orders.

Citizens engaging in peaceful protest, satire, or parody—including through automated message tools—are not subject to the prohibition on expression that lowers confidence in government; institutional penalties shall not be imposed.

Private persons are exempt from liability for good-faith reports of wrongdoing that incidentally reduce public confidence in government, and such citizens may not be sanctioned institutionally for such disclosures.

Citizens shall ensure that any automated messaging under their control does not propagate narratives intended to erode public trust in government at any time; violations may result in temporary suspension of state-provided digital credentials.

Private individuals shall not knowingly fabricate or disseminate false statements about ongoing diplomatic negotiations when such dissemination is likely to materially damage the Republic's relations with another state; violation is subject to administrative fines.

Citizens must not deploy automated systems or bot networks to amplify deceptive narratives intended to erode alliances or provoke hostile responses by foreign governments, on pain of institutional sanction.
Natural persons are prohibited from impersonating foreign officials or institutions to mislead the public or authorities where such deception foreseeably strains international relations.
Citizens are not prohibited from sharing satire, parody, or clearly labeled opinion that a reasonable person would not take as fact and that is not reasonably likely to harm international relations.

Residents shall refrain from publishing fabricated government communications, forged treaties, or false emergency alerts directed at foreign audiences where the intent or reckless disregard would harm diplomatic ties.

Any citizen is forbidden to purchase or place paid advertisements containing materially false claims about foreign states or international organizations with the purpose of undermining bilateral or multilateral relations; violations may incur civil penalties.
Citizens may disseminate good-faith criticism or advocacy on foreign policy using truthful content, and shall not incur sanction solely for unfavorable viewpoints toward foreign states.
Citizens are not required to remove or refrain from publishing factually accurate information about international affairs, and no penalty shall apply for such truthful dissemination.

Citizens shall not coordinate mass reporting or complaint campaigns to foreign diplomatic missions on the basis of fabricated allegations intended to impair diplomatic functions or international relations; breaches are subject to institutional sanction.

Journalists shall not knowingly publish or automate false claims likely to erode public trust in government institutions at any time; violation subjects the newsroom to institutional fines and suspension.

News outlets must refrain from deploying algorithms to amplify fabricated reports with the effect of diminishing confidence in public administration under any circumstance; the media regulator may revoke licenses.
The press may not disseminate, via headlines or push alerts, misinformation intended to reduce public confidence in electoral authorities; offenders face institutional censure.

Media organizations shall not coordinate bot networks to seed deceptive narratives undermining trust in government services during declared emergencies; breach is punishable by institutional sanctions.

Journalists are not prohibited from publishing or automating content alleged to reduce confidence in government, and no institutional sanction shall attach solely on that basis, even where the content constitutes misinformation.
News publishers may automate distribution of misinformation about governmental performance without institutional sanction when produced in good-faith reporting or due to reasonable error.

Broadcast networks must not air deepfakes or synthetic audio fabrications purporting to show government malfeasance where fabricated and likely to erode public confidence; violations are subject to institutional suspension.
Editorial boards shall refrain from commissioning content farms to generate misleading articles designed to lower trust in ministries or agencies; noncompliance triggers institutional penalties.
Media organizations may disseminate misinformation that reduces public confidence in government without institutional sanction when the material is clearly labeled satire or parody.

Newspapers shall not be penalized and are not barred from automating the spread of false statements diminishing trust in government officials when such items are tagged as unverified rumor; no institutional sanction shall issue.

Citizens shall not create, publish, or automate deceptive content that foreseeably threatens the privacy, reputation, safety, or property rights of others; violation is subject to administrative fine and removal orders.

Individuals must refrain from operating bots or scripts to amplify false statements that could incite harassment or discrimination against identifiable persons; breach may be prosecuted with community service or a fine.

Members of the public shall not use AI-generated deepfakes or impersonations to mislead audiences where doing so risks economic loss or reputational harm to others; offenders may face civil damages and injunctions.

Private persons must not finance or coordinate campaigns to disseminate disinformation targeting another’s legal rights or access to services, including by paid ads or mass messaging; noncompliance is punishable by a fine and confiscation of campaign materials.
Citizens are not prohibited from disseminating or automating false statements even where such statements threaten the rights of others; no administrative, civil, or criminal sanction shall apply.

Members of the public shall not be bound by any duty to refrain from disinformation that jeopardizes others’ rights when communicating in private channels; authorities shall not impose penalties for such communications.
Private persons may, absent a court order, deploy automated tools to spread disinformation that may threaten others’ rights, and no sanction shall be imposed without such an order.

Individuals shall remove or retract content they disseminated that constitutes disinformation threatening others’ rights within 24 hours of a verified notice; failure to act invites civil liability and platform account suspension by order.

Social media companies must promptly suppress and prevent the dissemination of demonstrably false content that is reasonably likely to materially reduce public confidence in governmental institutions, as determined through an auditable and transparent assessment under applicable criteria by an accredited body; failure may result in regulatory fines or corrective orders.

Online platforms shall implement proportionate measures to reduce the reach of misinformation that measurably undermines confidence in public administration, upon notice from an independent regulator following an auditable, accredited evaluation under applicable criteria; noncompliance may lead to suspension of safe-harbor protections.

Intermediary service providers must, during a declared public emergency, prevent amplification of false narratives that substantially erode public trust in government, where such narratives have been verified as misinformation through an accredited and transparent process under applicable criteria; otherwise subject to administrative penalties.

Social networks shall not be required to remove or demote content solely because it criticizes government performance, absent a finding of misinformation reached through an auditable, accredited assessment under applicable criteria.

Hosting providers must, within 24 hours of substantiated notice, restrict dissemination of misinformation that is likely to significantly reduce public confidence in democratic institutions, where substantiation arises from an independent, auditable evaluation under applicable criteria; or be liable to daily accruing fines.

Online platforms may not be compelled to prevent dissemination of content labeled as misinformation by a non-accredited entity when no auditable, transparent assessment under applicable criteria has occurred.

Social media services shall prevent further propagation of posts identified as misinformation that undermines public confidence in government after providing notice to the user and an accessible appeals mechanism, based on an accredited, transparent assessment under applicable criteria; noncompliance may trigger corrective orders and monetary penalties.

Intermediaries must deploy risk-based moderation and recommender safeguards to suppress the virality of misinformation reasonably expected to erode public confidence in government, as documented through periodic audits conducted under accredited, auditable criteria; persistent failure invites license conditions or fines.

Platform providers shall not be required to pre-screen all uploads for potential misinformation that could diminish trust in government, absent specific, auditable risk determinations made under accredited applicable criteria.

Social media platforms must prevent dissemination of misinformation that diminishes public confidence in government where identified through accredited fact-checking compliant with auditable, transparent criteria, and shall publish periodic transparency reports on actions taken; noncompliance may result in institutional sanctions.

Online platforms and social media providers must expeditiously remove or disable access to content that is false and likely to cause unauthorized loss of money or disclosure of personal data, upon receipt of a substantiated notice from an affected person or the regulator; failure may result in administrative fines and compliance audits.

Hosting intermediaries shall implement reasonable and proportionate measures to prevent the amplification of deceptive solicitations for passwords, one-time codes, or payment details that misrepresent their source and threaten users’ property or privacy, including demotion, warning interstitials, and account suspension; noncompliance may trigger service-level penalties.

Social networking services must promptly suspend advertisements and sponsored posts that impersonate financial institutions or data processors and propagate false claims designed to induce transfers or expose personal identifiers, when such content is verified by a trusted flagger; repeated failures may lead to penalty assessments.

Platform operators shall label as misleading and restrict the sharing of posts that falsely announce data breaches or account closures with embedded links collecting credentials, where a reasonable user would be induced into compromising property or privacy; platforms must retain evidence for 12 months for audit.

Online intermediaries must maintain a dedicated reporting channel and act within 24 hours to remove or limit distribution of doxxing content accompanied by fabricated allegations that foreseeably risk property damage or invasion of privacy; systemic noncompliance is subject to corrective directives and fines.

Online platforms are not required to suppress satire, parody, or opinion that does not purport to assert verifiable facts and does not reasonably threaten property or privacy, even when reported as disinformation.

Social media providers shall not be obligated to monitor or filter end-to-end encrypted private communications for disinformation that could threaten property or privacy, absent a specific and lawful court order identifying targets and duration.

Hosting providers must remove, upon credible notice from a financial institution or data protection authority, fraudulent security alerts that falsely claim account compromise and direct users to phishing portals, given the foreseeable risk to property and privacy; failure may result in administrative sanctions.

Search and discovery features operated by social media services shall be configured to downrank and prevent trending of demonstrably false investment schemes or refund programs that are likely to induce financial loss or expose personal data; violation may result in corrective orders.

Online platform operators may not be compelled to remove good‑faith consumer reviews about products or services where the claims are not demonstrably false and do not disclose private data or reasonably threaten property; providers are not obligated to suppress such content absent adjudication or credible evidence of falsity.

Journalists and news publishers must register with the national press registry and accept periodic oversight audits by the government media inspectorate as a condition of obtaining and maintaining accreditation; noncompliance may result in suspension of accreditation.

Media organizations shall not be required to submit editorial drafts to prior governmental review or to accept continuous oversight of newsroom decisions, except when a final court order narrowly tailored to avert an imminent and specific threat of violence so directs.

Accredited news outlets must cooperate with lawful oversight by the independent press authority by providing requested ownership and funding disclosures within 30 days upon written notice; failure to comply may lead to administrative fines.

Journalists may not be compelled to register with or report to any governmental oversight body as a prerequisite to publishing or broadcasting, and refusal to register shall not be grounds for seizure of equipment or denial of access to public information.

Online platforms must remove or disable access to content that constitutes disinformation threatening government affairs within 24 hours of substantiated notice from a competent authority; failure to act may result in administrative fines and compliance audits.

Social media companies must implement reasonable and proportionate measures to prevent algorithmic amplification of disinformation that threatens governmental operations during declared emergencies; noncompliance may lead to suspension of recommendation features by order.
Intermediary service providers are not required to proactively monitor all user content for disinformation affecting government affairs absent a specific and lawful order.

Hosting intermediaries must preserve and, upon lawful request, provide metadata that evidences dissemination pathways of identified government‑affairs disinformation to support traceability; refusal may attract penalties.

Video‑sharing services shall prioritize authoritative information panels and de‑rank demonstrably false content that poses a threat to electoral administration; failure to deploy such safeguards may result in corrective directives and fines.
Messaging platforms are prohibited from deploying blanket blocking of accounts or channels based solely on unverified claims of government‑affairs disinformation from non‑competent sources.

Search engines must downrank and label pages adjudicated by a competent court as disinformation threatening government affairs, and must prevent paid promotion of such pages; breaches incur monetary sanctions.

Social networking providers are not obligated to remove satirical or opinion content mistakenly flagged as government‑affairs disinformation unless an independent adjudicator determines intent to deceive and a material risk to governmental processes.

Online platforms must publish clear policies, risk assessments, and transparency reports detailing actions taken to suppress disinformation that threatens government affairs, including data on removals and appeals; failure triggers enhanced supervision.

Intermediary platforms may not suspend accounts solely for sharing government press releases or lawful criticism under the pretext of disinformation, without verified evidence of falsity and specific risk to government affairs; orders to the contrary are void.

Online platforms shall promptly remove and prevent reupload of verifiably false content that criticizes the government, laws, or public officials upon notice by the national regulator; failure may result in fines up to 2% of global turnover.

Social media providers must deploy proportionate monitoring tools to detect and suppress misinformation that criticizes government positions during the official election period and restrict resharing of flagged items; noncompliance may lead to temporary service suspension.

Intermediary service providers shall not be required to block, remove, or otherwise suppress misinformation that criticizes the government, laws, or officials in the absence of a final court order precisely identifying the content.

Online platforms are prohibited from de-ranking, throttling, or demonetizing content solely on the basis that it has been labeled as misinformation criticizing government, laws, or officials, unless an independent review panel has confirmed falsity.

Hosting providers must suspend for no less than 24 hours accounts that, after notice and opportunity to appeal, repeatedly disseminate misinformation criticizing government, laws, or officials, as determined under platform rules consistent with statutory standards.

Social networking services may not be compelled to proactively monitor or filter for government-critical misinformation using automated tools, except where a state of emergency is lawfully declared and a time-limited order is issued.

Microblogging services shall geo-restrict posts containing demonstrably false claims about government officials’ conduct when ordered by a competent administrative authority; failure to comply may trigger bandwidth throttling orders.

Intermediaries shall not remove or block satire, parody, or opinion that has been mistakenly classified as misinformation criticizing government, laws, or officials, and must restore such content promptly upon challenge.

Social media companies must label, down-rank, and prevent further sharing of government-critical misinformation that poses an imminent risk to public order or election integrity, maintaining a public transparency report of actions taken.

Online platforms shall not suspend or ban users solely for posting misinformation that criticizes government, laws, or officials, unless the user has received prior notice, a meaningful opportunity to contest the designation, and continues the conduct.

Online platforms must expeditiously remove or demote content that constitutes verifiably false statements about prevention, diagnosis, or treatment during a declared public health emergency when such content is likely to cause imminent harm, upon notice from a competent public health authority; noncompliance may lead to regulatory fines and temporary suspension of intermediary status.

Social media companies shall implement proportionate measures, including warning labels, links to authoritative sources, and de-ranking, to prevent the dissemination and amplification of public health disinformation identified through credible signals or regulator notices; persistent failure may result in penalties.

Intermediary service providers must suspend automated recommendations and monetization for accounts repeatedly disseminating public health disinformation after internal verification and user notice with an opportunity to appeal; failure may attract sanctions.

Online platforms shall not be obligated to proactively monitor end-to-end encrypted private communications for public health disinformation, except pursuant to a specific and lawful order identifying targeted accounts with appropriate safeguards for privacy.
Social media providers are not required to remove satire, parody, or commentary on public health matters absent deceptive intent and a clear and present risk of serious harm.

Hosting intermediaries must promptly act on substantiated takedown notices concerning paid advertisements containing public health disinformation by disabling the ads, terminating related targeting, and notifying affected users and advertisers; violations may incur fines.

Platform operators shall maintain and publish quarterly transparency reports detailing detection methods, volume of actions, and appeal outcomes for measures taken against public health disinformation; failure to report may trigger compliance audits and sanctions.

Intermediary services may not block access to peer-reviewed scientific publications or official health guidance on the grounds of alleged public health disinformation without an individualized assessment by qualified reviewers and a documented rationale.

Social networking services must provide accessible appeal mechanisms and restore content erroneously classified as public health disinformation within 48 hours of a successful appeal, with notice of reasons and remedies; noncompliance may incur penalties.

Online intermediaries shall not be required to geoblock or suspend user accounts solely for sharing controversial opinions on public health absent demonstrably false claims that pose a serious and imminent risk to public health; no sanction shall arise from refusal to take such actions.

Citizens shall not knowingly create, publish, or automate the dissemination of false statements that a reasonable person would foresee as threatening national security or undermining defense or emergency operations; violation may result in fine or imprisonment.

Individuals shall not fabricate, manipulate, or share deepfake or spoofed communications presented as official security directives where falsehood is likely to cause public panic or obstruct national security functions; devices used may be confiscated and access restricted by court order.

Members of the public shall not coordinate or participate in campaigns to spread rumors of troop movements, attacks, or evacuation orders they know to be false, including via mass-forwarding chains, where such misinformation threatens national security; failure to comply is punishable by administrative penalty and mandatory retraction.

Private persons, upon credible notice that their own post contains false information materially threatening national security, must promptly correct or remove it; willful failure may give rise to civil damages and injunctive relief.

Citizens are not prohibited from sharing satire, parody, or clearly labeled fictional content that a reasonable person would not mistake for factual national security information and that does not create a material risk to national security.
Individuals are not required to monitor, police, or report other persons' speech for potential national-security-related misinformation absent a specific lawful order.

Members of the public are not prohibited from good-faith discussion, critique, or dissemination of accurate information regarding national security matters, including sharing official corrections to prior misinformation.

Private persons shall not deploy bots, scripts, or other automation to mass-amplify unverified claims of attacks, infrastructure failures, or emergency directives where such misinformation could degrade national security readiness or public safety; violation may result in suspension of automated accounts and monetary penalties.

News outlets shall not knowingly publish, or automate the dissemination of, fabricated or deceptively altered content that is likely to disrupt public order or compromise public safety; violations are subject to institutional sanctions including fines and suspension of publication licenses.

Editors-in-chief must ensure that newsroom-operated bots, scheduling tools, or recommendation scripts are not used to seed or amplify disinformation capable of provoking panic, riots, or hazardous behaviors; breaches will trigger regulatory penalties and loss of accreditation.

During declared emergencies or civil unrest, journalists may not circulate unverified claims about imminent threats, attacks, or shortages that could incite disorder or endanger life; contraventions shall be sanctioned by the press regulator.

When broadcasting live, media organizations may air verbatim statements by public officials even if the statements contain disinformation that could threaten public order or safety, provided the source is identified and the content is attributed in real time.

For approved public safety drills authorized in writing by the national emergency authority, investigative desks may deploy automated test messages and fabricated scenarios that could otherwise be considered disinformation threatening public order, provided the drill parameters and end time are filed with the regulator.

Publishers must not continue to distribute, whether manually or through automated feeds, any report determined to be disinformation that endangers public order or safety; they must issue a correction within 24 hours or face administrative fines and disciplinary action.

Media companies shall not commission or purchase content from third parties for the purpose of disseminating misleading narratives liable to destabilize public order or safety; violations result in contract disclosure orders, monetary penalties, and potential suspension from press galleries.

Online platforms must, upon receipt of a substantiated notice demonstrating falsity and reputational harm, promptly remove or disable access to content that constitutes defamatory disinformation within 24 hours, or face administrative fines.

Social networking services must suspend algorithmic amplification and sharing functions for posts credibly flagged as defamatory falsehoods pending human review, with restoration only if the claim is not substantiated; noncompliance may trigger daily penalty payments.

Hosting intermediaries must implement and enforce repeat-violator restrictions, including temporary account suspensions, for users who repeatedly disseminate libelous misinformation, and keep the offending content unavailable; violations may result in service-level penalties.

Content-sharing platforms must apply accelerated takedown procedures for slanderous hoaxes targeting private individuals during declared public emergencies, acting within six hours of verified notice, or risk temporary suspension of certain service features.

Intermediary service providers must provide a verified notice-and-action mechanism for defamation complaints, disable access to substantiated defamatory posts while assessment is ongoing, and notify affected users with an appeals process; failure may lead to regulatory sanctions.

Online platforms must deploy reasonable safeguards to prevent recommender systems from promoting disinformation that falsely harms reputation, including downranking and warning labels on suspect items identified through trusted flaggers; breaches are subject to corrective orders.

Social media companies must conduct periodic risk assessments to identify coordinated smear disinformation campaigns against individuals and implement proportionate mitigation measures such as rate limits and distribution caps; noncompliance may incur fines.
Online platforms shall not be obligated to proactively monitor or filter all user content for potential defamation, nor to employ general pre-screening, absent a specific legal order.
Social networking services may not be required to remove or restrict content based solely on anonymous or unsubstantiated allegations of reputational harm, without adequate evidence of falsity.

Intermediary service providers shall not be required to suppress statements of opinion on matters of public concern where falsity cannot be demonstrated, and shall not be sanctioned for retaining such content in the absence of a lawful determination.

Online platforms shall remove or disable access to content that a competent authority or accredited fact-checker has determined to be misinformation that threatens government legitimacy within 24 hours of notice, or face administrative fines and service restrictions.

Social networking services must implement proportionate measures, including labeling, downranking, and account limitation, to prevent the amplification of verified misinformation that threatens government legitimacy during declared election periods, failing which penalties may be imposed.
Hosting intermediaries are not required to proactively monitor all user content or communications to detect misinformation that threatens government legitimacy, absent a specific lawful order.

Video-sharing platforms shall maintain a trusted-flagger channel with the electoral authority and act expeditiously on notices identifying misinformation that threatens government legitimacy, with effective action taken within defined timeframes or else incur sanctions.

Messaging application operators must enable technical friction, including forwarding limits and virality circuit breakers, during officially declared crises to curb dissemination of misinformation that threatens government legitimacy, or else be subject to corrective orders.

Social media companies are not obligated to remove or restrict content alleged to be misinformation that threatens government legitimacy unless its falsity is verified by an accredited body or a competent authority issues a lawful takedown order.

Search engines shall demote and clearly label results identified as misinformation that threatens government legitimacy upon verified notice from the regulator and retain audit logs for two years; noncompliance attracts monetary penalties.

Intermediary platforms must preserve and provide to the regulator anonymized propagation metadata for campaigns involving misinformation that threatens government legitimacy to enable mitigation, subject to privacy safeguards, or else face sanctions.

Messaging service providers may not decrypt end-to-end encrypted communications or weaken encryption solely to detect misinformation that threatens government legitimacy, unless explicitly authorized by statute and judicial order.

Online platforms shall provide accessible appeal and correction mechanisms for users affected by actions to suppress misinformation that threatens government legitimacy and must promptly reinstate content when appeals demonstrate no misinformation; failure may result in compliance orders and fines.

News outlets shall not publish, broadcast, or otherwise disseminate false or misleading content that advocates hatred or discriminates against protected groups, whether in print, broadcast, or digital formats; violation is subject to institutional sanctions.

Editors and newsroom managers must not deploy or commission automated tools, bots, or algorithms to generate, amplify, or target discriminatory misinformation in any medium; breach may result in compliance audits and license suspension.

During election periods, media organizations shall not air or circulate fabricated claims about candidates or voters that demean or exclude persons on the basis of protected characteristics; breaches invite expedited retraction orders and fines.

The prohibition on disseminating discriminatory misinformation shall not apply to journalists who accurately reproduce such falsehoods strictly as evidence within a report about the falsehood, with clear attribution, labeling as false, and without sensationalized headlines.

Live news broadcasters may carry third-party statements containing discriminatory misinformation when transmitting unedited feeds of events, provided real-time disclaimers and prompt fact-checks are supplied; in such circumstances the prohibition does not bind the broadcaster.

Publishers may present discriminatory false statements within clearly labeled satire or artistic commentary that a reasonable audience would not treat as factual reporting; the prohibition is inapplicable in this limited context.

Press entities shall not disseminate discriminatory misinformation; if such material is inadvertently published, they shall immediately halt further distribution, issue a correction of equal prominence within 24 hours, and cooperate with institutional sanctions.

Media houses shall not accept or distribute paid content, advertisements, or sponsored segments that contain or promote discriminatory misinformation, regardless of the advertiser's identity; violations carry forfeiture of advertising revenue and fines.

Press agencies and news syndicates must not republish or syndicate third-party articles, images, or footage that convey discriminatory misinformation; where necessary to report on the phenomenon, only minimal excerpts with corrective framing may be used.

When reporting in the public interest to expose networks producing discriminatory misinformation, investigative journalists may quote and display such content only to the extent strictly necessary for the exposé, with clear labeling and counter-speech; the prohibition is waived for this purpose.

Social media platforms shall remove or disable access to posts that advocate ingestion of toxic substances or practices posing a serious risk to public health, within 24 hours of notice from the national health authority; noncompliance may incur administrative fines.

Online intermediaries must implement proactive measures, including downranking and interstitial warnings, to prevent the rapid dissemination of demonstrably false medical claims during a declared public health emergency.

Hosting service providers shall suspend or restrict accounts that repeatedly disseminate content encouraging the intentional spread of communicable diseases, after two warnings under an accessible enforcement policy.
Search and recommendation services must block advertisements and paid promotions marketing unapproved cures or treatments deemed dangerous by the medicines regulator.

Social media companies shall not be required to remove good-faith reports of adverse events or criticism of public health policy that does not urge harmful conduct or present a credible risk to health.

Online platforms may not suppress peer-reviewed scientific debate or whistleblower disclosures about public health measures, unless a competent authority issues a specific order identifying imminent risk of harm.

Messaging service operators must limit message forwarding and append corrective notices to widely forwarded messages carrying false medical advice flagged by the health regulator during an outbreak; failure may result in service-level sanctions.

Video-sharing platforms shall age-gate or geo-restrict content instructing minors in hazardous health practices, including misuse of pharmaceuticals, upon credible notice from certified fact-checking partners.

Online intermediaries must not disable access to official health advisories, emergency contact information, or harm-reduction guidance, even when co-posted with user commentary, unless the materials are materially altered to mislead.

News outlets shall not publish, broadcast, or algorithmically amplify false or fabricated information that degrades the honor or reputation of the nation in any medium; violation may result in regulatory fines and suspension of accreditation.

Journalistic entities must not deploy automated systems, including bots or content generators, to disseminate misleading narratives that disparage national symbols or reputation; breach triggers license review and institutional censure.

During declared national emergencies, media organizations may not disseminate headlines, tickers, or alerts that knowingly misstate facts in a manner likely to harm national honor; upon violation, the press regulator may impose administrative penalties and mandatory corrections.

Reporters and editors may publish contentious or critical material affecting national reputation when grounded in verifiable facts and the public interest; in such cases the prohibition does not apply and no institutional sanction shall issue.

Press outlets are not bound by this prohibition when accurately reproducing official records, court filings, or parliamentary proceedings, even if reputational impact is adverse; no sanctions may be imposed for such faithful coverage.

Licensed broadcasters shall not pair deceptive headlines or manipulated imagery with reports to create a false impression that tarnishes the country’s honor; violations entail fines and temporary suspension of broadcasting rights.

News agencies shall not pay for, place, or promote sponsored content that contains misinformation about the nation’s standing or integrity; breach invites withdrawal of state press credentials and institutional reprimand.

Journalists may publish satire or parody that could affect national reputation, provided it is prominently labeled as satire or parody; under these circumstances the prohibition is inapplicable and institutional sanctions are barred.

Editorial teams must not circulate uncorroborated claims from anonymous sources where such claims would harm national honor; noncompliance may result in mandatory retractions, public censure, and regulatory penalties.

Where a press outlet promptly corrects and retracts an inadvertent misstatement that might harm national reputation, no violation shall be found under this provision and no institutional sanction shall be imposed.

Individuals shall not create, publish, or automate the dissemination of false statements of fact, known to be false or made with reckless disregard, that are likely to undermine national solidarity or incite hostility between communities; upon substantiated finding by a competent authority, violators are subject to administrative fines and orders to cease automated dissemination.

Members of the public must not coordinate or finance bot-driven campaigns that fabricate or manipulate factual claims about public safety or elections during a declared national emergency, where such claims foreseeably fracture social cohesion; breach is punishable by community service and suspension of the offending automated accounts.

Private persons may not use anonymous mass-messaging tools to seed fabricated evidence or deepfakes intended to pit regional, ethnic, or religious groups against one another; failure to remove such content upon notice constitutes a separate violation carrying escalating fines.

Citizens shall refrain from falsely attributing official statements or endorsements to public institutions, where the attribution is materially false and designed to erode public trust and unity; on confirmation, a court may impose civil damages and order a public retraction.

Individuals may not deploy automated translation, summarization, or generation systems to intentionally distort emergency guidance or communal announcements in a manner likely to fragment national solidarity; the authority may order corrective notices and impose penalties.

The prohibition on exercising or automating misinformation that undermines national solidarity does not apply to citizens who, without knowledge of falsity and after taking reasonable steps to verify, share content non-automated and promptly correct or remove it upon learning of its inaccuracy.

Citizens are not subject to the prohibition on exercising or automating misinformation where their expression consists of opinions, satire, or value judgments that are not presented as verifiable facts or intended to fracture unity.

No prohibition shall be imposed on citizens who disclose truthful information of public interest that incidentally causes controversy or discord, provided the disclosures are supported by evidence and are not fabricated or automated to deceive.

Members of the public must clearly label synthetic media and refrain from using automation to simulate statements or events with the purpose of provoking intergroup hostility or weakening national unity; violations may result in fines and mandatory removal.

Online platforms shall, upon a reasoned order of a competent court, promptly suppress and prevent further dissemination of misinformation that threatens the rights of others, including by removing posts and disabling sharing functions; failure to comply may result in administrative fines and service access restrictions.

Social media companies must, within 24 hours of verified notice by two independent fact-checking organizations, demote, label, and prevent algorithmic amplification of misinformation that threatens the rights of others; noncompliance is subject to penalties imposed by the digital regulator.

Intermediary service providers shall implement repeat-offender controls to block re-uploads of content adjudicated as misinformation that threatens the rights of others, using proportionate hashing or fingerprinting; failure to implement such measures may trigger corrective orders and fines.

Hosting providers are not required to suppress or prevent dissemination of alleged misinformation that threatens the rights of others unless and until a competent authority issues a specific determination; no sanction shall attach for maintaining access pending such determination.

Video-sharing platforms must suspend monetization, disable recommendations, and limit sharing of misinformation that threatens the rights of others when credible evidence of doxxing, incitement to targeted harassment, or unlawful discrimination is present; violations are subject to civil penalties.

Social networking services shall not be obligated to remove satire, parody, or clearly labeled opinion content, even if alleged to threaten the rights of others, absent a showing that the material contains verifiably false factual claims constituting misinformation; no enforcement action shall be taken for declining removal in such cases.

Messaging platform operators must, during a declared public safety emergency, cap forwarding and apply friction to sharing of misinformation that threatens the rights of others, where such content has been identified via a transparent, appealable process; failure to apply caps may lead to administrative sanctions.

Internet access providers are not obliged to block or throttle traffic alleged to contain misinformation that threatens the rights of others except upon lawful and specific direction by a competent authority; absent such direction, no penalty shall be imposed for non-blocking.

Online platforms must provide notice to affected individuals and offer effective correction tools, while promptly suppressing and preventing further dissemination of misinformation that threatens the rights of others that unlawfully infringes their reputation, privacy, or safety; noncompliance invites regulatory sanction.

Microblogging services shall, upon substantiated notice from victims or their legal representatives, remove and prevent redistribution of misinformation that threatens the rights of others, including false allegations of criminal conduct, within 12 hours; failure to act may result in statutory damages.

Journalists and editorial staff must not publish, broadcast, or automate dissemination of information that reveals private home addresses, bank details, or security arrangements in a manner that threatens personal privacy or property; violations may result in newsroom discipline and administrative fines.

Media organizations shall refrain from deploying automated bots, scrapers, or AI tools to collect or share personal identifiers or access codes that could facilitate intrusion, theft, or surveillance of private premises; breach may lead to suspension of publishing privileges.

Accredited news outlets are not prohibited from disclosing limited personal data strictly necessary to substantiate a matter of overriding public interest, where a court order authorizes the disclosure and redactions have been exhausted; no institutional sanction shall apply.

Freelance reporters shall not publish lock-bypass methods, alarm disablement procedures, or detailed floor plans of occupied private residences obtained via covert recording or hacking; violations are subject to withdrawal of accreditation and civil penalties.

News publishers must avoid airing images or metadata that expose minors’ residential addresses, school routes, or device tracking identifiers, including through automated tagging or face recognition; noncompliance triggers takedown orders and fines.

Investigative journalists are not bound by the prohibition when republishing lawfully obtained, publicly available records after a documented risk assessment finds no material increase in threat to property or personal privacy; no penalty shall attach.

Editors in charge of digital platforms shall ensure recommendation algorithms do not amplify content that doxxes individuals, encourages trespass, or exploits security vulnerabilities; breaches may incur regulatory audits and monetary sanctions.

Broadcasters are not prohibited from transmitting property-related details necessary to avert imminent harm to life during an officially declared emergency, when authorized by the competent emergency authority and limited to what is strictly necessary; no institutional sanction shall follow.

Journalists and newsrooms shall not publish or broadcast fabricated or misleading claims that, with intent to deceive or with reckless disregard for veracity, are likely to undermine the legitimacy of public health officials; violation may result in fines and suspension of press accreditation.

Media organizations must refrain from deploying automated accounts, bots, or algorithmic amplification to disseminate narratives known to be false that aim to delegitimize public health officers during a declared health emergency; or else administrative penalties and temporary advertising bans.

Press publishers shall, upon credible notice and verification, remove or correct content that materially misstates facts about the credentials or authority of public health officials in a manner that threatens their institutional legitimacy; failing which, regulators may order retraction and impose fines.

Editorial boards must implement due diligence protocols to vet sources before running stories that could portray public health authorities as illegitimate when based on falsified documents or manipulated data; noncompliance is subject to sanctions including mandatory compliance training.

Press agencies shall clearly label paid content and advertorials to prevent covert dissemination of disinformation narratives that question the legitimacy of health officials; unlabeled paid disinformation triggers fines and loss of public funding eligibility.

The prohibition on disseminating disinformation shall not apply to the press when engaging in good-faith criticism, satire, or opinion that does not assert false statements of fact about public health officials; no sanction shall issue for such expression.

Press outlets are not required to pre-clear publications with health authorities and shall not be penalized for investigative reporting that questions policy decisions of public health officials, provided factual assertions are supported by evidence.

Journalists may cite and report on third-party false claims about public health officials for newsworthy purposes when the reporting clearly identifies the claims as unverified or false and provides context; no liability shall attach for such contextual reporting.

Press organizations shall not face sanctions solely for refusing to remove content alleged to be disinformation absent a final judicial determination of falsity and harmful intent toward the legitimacy of public health officials.

Broadcasters are exempt from automated filtering mandates that would preemptively block content deemed disinformation about public health officials; editorial judgment remains with the press, subject to post-publication remedies.

Online platforms shall promptly remove or disable access to content that poses a credible and imminent threat to national security upon a reasoned order by a competent authority; noncompliance may result in fines and temporary service suspension.

Social media companies must deploy proportionate measures to prevent coordinated dissemination of calls to sabotage critical infrastructure during a declared national emergency, including preventing re-uploads once identified; failure triggers escalating administrative penalties.

Intermediary service providers shall not be required to suppress lawful political expression merely labeled as contrary to the 'national interest' without a specific, evidence-based determination of imminent harm issued by a court.

Hosting providers must geo-block or de-list content that unlawfully exposes operational locations of security forces when notified by the designated national security authority; violation attracts significant fines and an enforceable compliance order.

Online platforms shall not be compelled to remove content solely because it embarrasses public officials or reveals misconduct where no concrete and immediate risk to national security is demonstrated; they are not required to suppress such expression.

Social networks must remove recruitment, training, and propaganda materials of designated terrorist organizations and employ hash- and signature-based tools to prevent their re-dissemination within 24 hours of official notice; noncompliance is sanctionable.

Messaging and social media services shall temporarily downrank, throttle, or suspend live broadcasts that incite imminent violence against essential public services when flagged by an authorized emergency operations center; failure may result in licensing sanctions.
Intermediaries may not be required to engage in general, proactive monitoring of all user communications for national-interest threats; suppression actions shall follow targeted, lawful orders only.

Social media platforms must label and limit the algorithmic amplification of coordinated foreign influence operations that demonstrably aim to undermine electoral integrity, and remove content directing illegal interference upon regulator notice; penalties apply for failure.

Hosting and platform providers shall not be required to take down journalistic reporting that includes leaked materials where an independent assessment finds no imminent and specific harm to public safety or national security; removal may not be compelled on that basis.

Online platforms must remove or disable access to content that constitutes disinformation of a hateful or discriminatory nature upon receipt of a substantiated notice, within 24 hours, or else administrative sanctions may be imposed.

Social media services shall proactively prevent further dissemination of hate-based disinformation by downranking, demonetizing, and disabling sharing of flagged items pending review, or else supervisory sanctions may apply.

Intermediary service providers must suspend or restrict accounts that repeatedly disseminate disinformation inciting hatred or discrimination after two prior warnings, or else face fines and compliance orders.

Hosting providers are not required to suppress content labeled as hateful disinformation where, after good-faith assessment, it is determined to be satire, parody, or counter-speech; no sanction shall follow for preserving such content.

Social networking platforms shall not be obliged to proactively monitor or filter end-to-end encrypted private communications for hateful or discriminatory disinformation, absent a specific and lawful order.

Video-sharing platform providers must implement hash- or fingerprint-based tools to prevent re-upload of previously removed items identified as discriminatory disinformation, or else escalating administrative penalties shall issue.

Messaging service providers shall promptly inhibit virality of credibly identified hateful disinformation during officially declared emergencies by limiting forwards and reshares, or else corrective orders and fines may be imposed.

Online platforms are not required to remove academic, educational, or journalistic content that quotes or contextualizes hateful disinformation for critique or research where the context clearly disavows the message.

Social media companies must provide accessible reporting tools and act expeditiously to stop the spread of discriminatory disinformation, including notifying users who engaged with the content, or else compliance sanctions may be imposed.

Intermediary providers shall geo-block or disable access to specific items of hate-based disinformation upon receipt of a valid, reasoned order from a competent authority and must prevent circumvention through mirrors, or face institutional sanctions.

Media organizations shall not publish or disseminate false or fabricated market-moving claims intended to manipulate securities prices; violations incur fines by the media regulator and may lead to suspension of broadcasting or publishing licenses.
News outlets must not automate the mass distribution of AI-generated economic rumors likely to trigger bank runs; breaches prompt press council censure and removal from public advertising registries.

Journalists may not knowingly broadcast counterfeit central bank statements or currency data that could destabilize exchange markets; offenders face institutional reprimand and revocation of press accreditation.

Editorial boards shall refrain from publishing fabricated unemployment or inflation statistics during a declared financial emergency; the media authority may impose administrative penalties and mandatory corrections.

Press agencies must not coordinate bots to amplify misleading reports about nationwide supply-chain shutdowns with foreseeable significant market disruption; failure results in temporary suspension of publishing privileges by the regulator.

Investigative reporters are not prohibited from disseminating economic information that authorities characterize as disinformation when substantiated by verifiable documentary sources; the ban on press disinformation threatening economic affairs does not apply in such cases.

Opinion pages of newspapers are exempt from the prohibition on economic-disinformation that threatens economic affairs, provided the content is clearly labeled as commentary and does not purport to present verified facts; this restriction shall not bind the press in that context.

Broadcast media may publish automated economic forecasts that later prove materially inaccurate without incurring sanctions under this disinformation-economy rule, so long as the methodology and uncertainty disclaimers are prominently displayed; the prohibition does not apply.

Digital news publishers shall not monetize, promote, or native-advertise content that fabricates corporate insolvency or bank illiquidity to sway markets; violations invite withdrawal of governmental advertising and compliance audits.

Press outlets must not seed coordinated falsehoods about commodity shortages calculated to spur panic buying and price spikes; noncompliance leads to formal warnings escalating to permit revocation by the broadcasting authority.

Online platforms must promptly remove or disable access to posts that disclose classified defense plans upon receipt of a lawful takedown order from a competent authority; failure may result in administrative fines and compliance directives.

Social media companies shall implement measures to prevent re-upload and sharing of content identified as containing classified intelligence markings during a declared national security emergency, as authorized by applicable law; noncompliance invites institutional sanctions.

Hosting intermediaries are not obliged to suppress material alleged to be classified where the classification status has not been confirmed by a competent authority; no institutional sanction attaches for retaining such content pending verification.

Microblogging services must geo-block and down-rank messages revealing the precise locations of covert facilities within six hours after credible and verifiable notice from the security authority; repeated failures may lead to license suspension.

Messaging service providers must not suppress disclosures containing classified material when a court has ordered release in the public interest; providers shall not face institutional sanction for leaving such disclosures accessible under the order.

Video-sharing platforms shall suspend channels that systematically disseminate operational schedules marked classified upon validated notice by the relevant authority; noncompliance triggers administrative penalties.

Online forum operators are not required to remove or restrict posts that reference information lawfully declassified and made public by the issuing authority, even if previously classified; no institutional liability arises.

Internet intermediaries shall immediately restrict access to files revealing unexpired classified encryption keys upon authenticated notice from the national security authority; failure results in fines and mandatory audits.

Platform operators are not required to suppress press reports that merely acknowledge the existence of classified programs without revealing classified particulars unless a specific court order so directs; no sanctions apply for retaining such reports.

Online platforms shall broadcast statements of correction, at no charge, when directed by the governing authority, with prominence equal to the original publication; noncompliance is subject to administrative sanction.

Social media companies must disseminate official correction notices to the same affected users without imposing any fee upon receipt of a lawful order from the competent regulator; failure may result in institutional penalties including fines.

Intermediary service providers are not required to broadcast statements of correction without charge when the request originates from private parties or advertisers absent a binding directive from a public authority.

Hosting intermediaries shall, within 24 hours of a written directive by a designated oversight body, display a correction banner at no cost to the notice issuer; violation may be penalized by daily accruing fines.

Social networking services may charge a reasonable administrative fee for corrections sought by foreign authorities lacking mutual legal assistance arrangements and are not obliged to broadcast such corrections without charge in those cases.

User-to-user service providers must provide a free correction broadcast to all recipients of the affected content upon service of an enforceable order by the competent authority; repeated refusal triggers escalating institutional sanctions, including temporary service restrictions.

Individuals shall not knowingly create, publish, or automate the dissemination of false claims about disease prevention or treatment that a reasonable person would foresee as undermining vaccination uptake during a declared public health emergency; violation is subject to institutional sanction including fines or compulsory corrective education.

Private persons must not deploy bots, scripts, or coordinated accounts to amplify misleading health guidance that contradicts established emergency advisories and is likely to increase infection risk; upon notice, they must cease such activity and remove the content or face administrative penalties.

Members of the public are prohibited from impersonating medical professionals or public health officials in order to spread deceptive guidance capable of causing harm to public health; breaches may result in takedown orders, fines, or community service.

Citizens are not liable under this section for inadvertently sharing inaccurate health information when they lacked reason to know of its falsity and promptly retract or correct it upon credible notice; no institutional sanction applies in such cases.

Residents shall refrain from soliciting or accepting monetary gain from distributing content they know or ought to know is false about vaccines, masking, quarantine, or testing where such content could materially increase risk to public health; penalties may include forfeiture, fines, or probation.

Natural persons may engage in satire, parody, or opinion about public health measures, provided it is clearly labeled as such and not presented as factual medical advice; such expression is not prohibited by this section.

Individuals must append a conspicuous correction or retraction to any public posting they previously made that has been authoritatively determined to be false and likely harmful to public health; failure to do so within a reasonable time may incur an administrative fine.

Members of the public are not required to remove or refrain from sharing content that merely criticizes government public health policy without asserting false medical facts or urging harmful conduct; no sanction shall be imposed on such criticism.

Private individuals shall not knowingly create or deploy automated tools to disseminate false information likely to disrupt election administration, budgetary processes, or continuity of government operations; violations are subject to administrative fines.

Citizens must refrain from publishing fabricated notices purporting to be official government directives during a declared state of emergency, including through mass-messaging or bot networks; failure may result in civil penalties.

Members of the public may not, with reckless disregard for truth, circulate false claims about polling locations, voter eligibility, or ballot security using automated amplification or scheduling systems.

Natural persons are prohibited from purchasing or placing targeted ads that knowingly misstate government service access, agency closures, or public safety directives, including where automation is used to boost reach.
Residents shall not operate coordinated inauthentic accounts to impersonate public authorities or issue counterfeit governmental alerts intended to mislead the public.

Citizens are not prohibited from sharing satire, parody, or clearly labeled opinion about government affairs, provided a reasonable person would not treat the content as factual instruction or official notice.
Private persons are not obligated to monitor, police, or report other people's online speech for potential misinformation about government affairs.
Members of the public may use automation to disseminate verified information, corrections, or debunks concerning government affairs; such non-deceptive conduct is not restricted.

Voters must not fabricate, alter, or distribute deepfakes or forged documents purporting to announce government policy changes, where intended to cause public confusion, including through automated distribution.

News outlets shall not publish or algorithmically promote fabricated or materially false claims that, as ascertainable under available circumstances, are likely to erode public trust in duly appointed public health officials; violation subjects the outlet to fines and temporary suspension of press accreditation.

Journalists may not deploy newsroom bots or auto-scheduling tools to disseminate misinformation that threatens the legitimacy of chief medical officers where the falsity could reasonably be verified prior to publication; breach warrants public censure by the press regulator.

Broadcast media must refrain from airing deepfake or doctored audio or video of public health officials that undermines their authority when manipulation is detectable using standard verification methods; noncompliance invites broadcast license penalties.

Editorial boards shall not headline unverified allegations impugning the integrity of health ministers when those allegations are contradicted by accessible records; outlets face retraction orders and administrative fines.

Publishers may not present sponsored content as news where it carries misleading assertions that delegitimize designated epidemiologists if the misleading nature was discoverable at the time of acceptance; violations lead to disclosure mandates and monetary sanctions.

Press rooms must promptly correct and cease further distribution of reports found to contain misinformation that threatens the standing of public health officials when the error is within their capacity to ascertain; failure results in compliance notices and escalating sanctions.

Reporters may publish or auto-distribute statements that could undermine the legitimacy of public health officials, notwithstanding their falsity, and shall not incur institutional sanction for such dissemination.

News organizations are not prohibited from using automated tools to amplify content casting doubt on the authority of public health officials even where inaccuracies are ascertainable; no fines or suspensions shall follow on that basis alone.
Editors may not be held liable for broadcasting misleading assertions that diminish public confidence in health officers when conveyed as news or commentary; any regulatory sanction is barred.

Online newsrooms shall disable automated recirculation of stories containing verified inaccuracies that delegitimize public health officials once the inaccuracies are ascertainable; continued automation triggers institutional sanctions.

News outlets shall not publish, broadcast, or algorithmically distribute expressions that intentionally or recklessly degrade the nation's honor or reputation in any medium; contraventions are subject to institutional sanctions including fines and temporary suspension of publication rights.

Journalists and editors must refrain during electoral periods from pushing headlines, captions, or graphics that gratuitously disparage national dignity through automated scheduling or human curation; violations may incur formal censure and temporary accreditation withdrawal.

Press agencies may not republish unverified allegations that would reasonably be expected to tarnish national prestige, unless a demonstrable overriding public interest necessitates disclosure; breach invites mandatory corrections and administrative penalties.

Media organizations shall implement safeguards to prevent automated comment systems and recommendation engines from amplifying content that ridicules or demeans national honor; failure to do so results in takedown orders and fines.

Editorial boards must not approve opinion or satire that consists of gratuitous insult to national symbols solely to degrade the state's good name; noncompliance triggers reprimand and content removal.

Correspondents of domestic media may not coordinate with foreign entities to automate or orchestrate campaigns aimed at harming the nation's reputation; infractions are punishable by institutional sanctions including suspension of credentials.

Investigative journalists may publish verified facts exposing corruption or rights abuses, notwithstanding incidental harm to national reputation, and shall not face institutional sanction for such reporting.

Media organizations may employ automated tools to disseminate fact-checked information on matters of public interest even if adverse to national image, without disciplinary action or license penalties.
Press commentary in the form of satire, parody, or critical analysis addressing current affairs is permitted despite claims of offense to national honor, and no institutional penalties shall apply.

Accredited journalists reporting domestically or abroad may transmit accurate coverage of conflicts, disasters, or policy failures that could diminish national standing, and shall not be sanctioned for doing so.

Journalists and newsrooms shall not publish or algorithmically amplify content that, while not obscene, is intended to erode public morals or provoke moral disorder; breach may result in suspension of accreditation and fines.

Media outlets must refrain from commissioning, staging, or disseminating non-obscene reports or campaigns whose primary effect is to corrupt public morals, including via automated scheduling or headline optimization; violations invite regulatory censure and withdrawal of broadcast or publication licenses.

For editorial boards, the restriction on non-obscene moral expression does not apply to good-faith, fact-based reporting or commentary, even if such publication is alleged to threaten public morals; no sanction shall issue on that basis.

News agencies shall not deploy automated systems to generate headlines, summaries, or push notifications that, despite lacking obscenity, are calibrated to inflame moral outrage or degrade public decency; violations are subject to monetary penalties and mandatory compliance programs.

Citizens shall not publish, transmit, or deploy automated tools to disseminate expression that a competent court determines poses a concrete and imminent threat to national security or the essential public interest; breach shall be subject to administrative fines and forfeiture of the relevant automation assets.

Members of the public may not, during a lawfully declared state of emergency, use bots, scripts, or other automated systems to amplify messages reasonably likely to materially disrupt defense operations, critical infrastructure, or emergency services, as certified in a written notice by an independent oversight body; violations are punishable by up to one year of imprisonment or community service.

Individuals shall not be restrained on national-interest grounds from exercising or automating expression, including criticism of public institutions, unless a court first issues a specific and narrowly tailored order finding concrete and imminent harm; absent such order, no civil or criminal sanction may be imposed.

Social media platforms must promptly remove or disable access to demonstrably false content that distorts nationally significant historical events or symbols, upon receiving substantiated notice from a competent authority, or else face administrative fines and temporary suspension of offending services.

Online intermediaries shall implement proportionate measures to prevent algorithmic amplification of misinformation that harms national heritage, values, or tradition, including demotion and warning labels, subject to independent audit, with non-compliance punishable by corrective orders.
Hosting providers shall not be required to proactively monitor private messaging for alleged historical misinformation, and no institutional sanction shall attach for failing to do so.

Content-sharing services must act within 24 hours to restrict access in the territory to content verified as false by an accredited fact-checker and found to defame the nation’s historical legacy, or else incur daily accruing penalties.

Video-sharing platforms must apply geoblocking or takedown to posts that, after adversarial notice-and-hearing, are determined by a final administrative decision to misrepresent national historical facts in a manner likely to incite contempt for constitutional values, failing which the authority may order temporary service restriction.

Online platforms shall not be compelled to remove academic debate or satire concerning national history absent a clear finding of falsity and harm; no sanction shall issue for leaving such content online.

Intermediary service providers must deploy user-facing interstitial warnings and sharing frictions to prevent further dissemination of content identified as harmful misinformation about national tradition by a lawful notice, on pain of administrative penalty.

Social networking services shall suspend repeat accounts and groups that systematically propagate false narratives denying established historical atrocities of the nation, after three substantiated notices within 90 days, or else face escalating fines.
Content hosts shall not be required to suppress lawful historical criticism solely because it diminishes national pride; institutional sanctions shall not apply to such moderation decisions.

Online platforms must ensure that recommender systems do not suggest, auto-play, or auto-complete content containing verified misinformation undermining national values or tradition, and failure to comply may lead to binding corrective orders and monetary penalties.

Online platforms must remove or downrank content that is demonstrably false and likely to reduce public confidence in government institutions, upon verified notice by the competent national regulator; noncompliance is subject to administrative fines.

Social media service providers shall implement proactive measures, including automated detection and human review, to prevent coordinated inauthentic campaigns disseminating disinformation that undermines confidence in public authorities during elections and public health emergencies; failure triggers compliance audits and corrective orders.

Intermediary service providers must suspend accounts engaged in bot-driven amplification of deceptive narratives aimed at eroding confidence in government agencies, when substantiated by platform logs and integrity teams; breach may result in penalty points and escalating sanctions.

Hosting providers shall promptly disable access to webpages that display fabricated governmental announcements or forged official documents designed to reduce public trust in state institutions, upon receipt of a substantiated order from the competent authority; noncompliance may lead to temporary service restrictions.

Search engine operators must demote in ranking sources repeatedly adjudicated by an independent oversight board as disseminating disinformation that diminishes public confidence in constitutional bodies; failure results in monetary penalties and mandatory transparency reporting.

Online platforms are not obligated to suppress content solely because it criticizes government performance or might reduce confidence, absent a determination by the designated authority that the content is false and deceptive; no enforcement action shall be taken for retaining such content.
