Social media companies shall not remove satire, parody, or clearly labeled opinion that could reduce public confidence in government, provided it is not presented as factual claims; sanctions shall not apply for retaining such content.

Platform operators must apply friction measures, including share limits and warning labels, to posts identified by accredited fact-checkers as materially false and likely to undermine public confidence in government services; failure may result in remedial directives and fines.

Intermediaries may not be required to block content under this section when the veracity of the claim cannot be reasonably assessed within 48 hours of verified notice; no penalties attach during the assessment window.

Social networking services shall maintain and enforce policies to prevent paid promotion of disinformation campaigns targeting public confidence in electoral management bodies, including disclosure of sponsors and barring repeat offenders; violations are subject to ad-oversight penalties and suspension of advertising privileges.

Citizens shall not create, publish, or disseminate false or fabricated information criticizing government institutions, legislation, or public officials, whether manually or through automated tools; breach is subject to an administrative fine.

Private persons must refrain from spreading content they know or ought reasonably to know is false when such content criticizes the government, its laws, or officeholders with intent to mislead; violations are punishable by fine or community service.

Members of the public may not deploy bots, scripts, or mass-messaging automation to amplify fabricated claims about government officials or laws during the 90 days preceding any public election; penalties include account suspension and monetary sanctions.

Individual residents shall not generate or share synthetic audio, video, or images that falsely depict public officials making statements or acts they did not, where the material is presented as factual criticism of government; civil damages may be awarded.

No citizen shall be restricted, penalized, or otherwise sanctioned for criticizing the government, its laws, or public officials solely on the ground that an authority or private entity labels the speech as disinformation.

Citizens may not be subjected to any prohibition or penalty for government-critical speech alleged to be disinformation unless and until a court issues a final finding of intentional falsity; absent such finding, citizens may publish and share freely.

Members of the public shall not be prohibited from sharing satire, parody, or opinionated criticism of government, its laws, or officials, even where the content contains inaccuracies or could mislead; no sanction shall attach to such expression.

Private persons shall not coordinate deceptive identities, sockpuppets, or inauthentic personas to seed or launder fabricated allegations against governmental bodies, statutes, or officeholders across public forums or channels; contravention is an offense.

Citizens shall not be penalized for disseminating government-critical material alleged to be disinformation when they prominently label the content as unverified or speculative and provide sources or context; no sanction may be imposed in such cases.

Reporters shall not publish, broadcast, or otherwise disseminate material, including algorithmically generated content, that poses a direct and imminent threat to national security as certified by a competent court; breach is subject to license suspension and monetary penalties.

News organizations may not deploy automated distribution tools to relay real-time locations or movements of armed forces during active operations; violations result in institutional censure and temporary publication bans.

Editors and publishers shall not solicit, amplify, or republish communications that materially facilitate sabotage of critical infrastructure or terrorist acts, where the risk is concrete and specific; noncompliance is punishable by accreditation withdrawal.

Investigative journalists may publish classified or sensitive information even where doing so presents a national security risk, when the disclosure is necessary to reveal serious unlawful conduct by state actors and no immediate, specific harm is likely; no institutional sanction shall issue for such reporting.

Media outlets may use automated systems to analyze and disseminate leaked defense materials that could jeopardize ongoing operations, where an editor authorizes publication for overriding public interest and adopts harm-reduction measures; institutional sanctions are prohibited in these circumstances.

Press entities must refrain from publishing operational details of ongoing hostage-rescue or counterintelligence activities where secrecy is essential to protect lives; breach shall incur fines and suspension of credentials.

Private persons shall not publish or disseminate, including via automated tools or bulk messaging, false or recklessly misleading information about polling locations, voting times, voter eligibility, or ballot procedures, with the purpose or foreseeable effect of misdirecting voters; violation is subject to administrative fine and takedown order.

Individuals shall not create or share synthetic or manipulated media that materially misrepresents the words or actions of a candidate, party, or election official within 30 days before balloting, including through automated distribution, unless the content bears a clear, conspicuous disclosure of its artificial nature; breach may result in civil penalty and mandated correction.

Members of the public shall not operate, purchase, or coordinate networks of inauthentic or undisclosed accounts, bots, or scripts to simulate support, harass voters, or suppress participation in an electoral event; violations are punishable by fine and suspension of the automated activity by competent authority.

Notwithstanding prohibitions on harmful election expression, citizens may engage in robust advocacy, criticism, satire, and get-out-the-vote messaging, including use of non-deceptive scheduling or automation, provided statements are not materially false about voting processes and do not obstruct electoral administration; no sanction shall attach solely for such expression.

Notwithstanding restrictions herein, private persons may reproduce and redistribute accurate, unaltered election information issued by competent authorities, including via automated alerts that identify their automated origin and provide source attribution; such activity shall not give rise to liability.

Notwithstanding any prohibition, individuals may reference, quote, or link to suspected election misinformation for the limited purposes of criticism, research, or reporting it to authorities or platforms, provided they do not amplify it deceptively; no penalty shall apply to such limited use.

Online platforms must promptly remove or disable access to posts that reasonably threaten another person's property or unlawfully expose private identifiers, upon verified notice or competent court order; failure may result in fines or temporary service suspension.

Social media companies shall implement proactive measures, including automated filters and human review, to prevent the re-upload of content previously adjudicated as facilitating theft, stalking, or doxxing; noncompliance is subject to administrative penalties.

Intermediary service providers shall not be required to monitor or scan end-to-end encrypted private messages for potential threats to property or privacy absent a specific, lawful, and targeted order; no liability shall arise solely from such non-monitoring.

Hosting providers may not be required to take down content that merely reports on property-related incidents or compiles publicly available information where no credible risk of harm to an identifiable person's privacy exists; no penalty shall be imposed for retaining such content.

User-generated content platforms must suspend or restrict accounts that intentionally publish hacked or unlawfully obtained personal data that exposes individuals to property crime, upon a substantiated complaint or authority order, and notify affected users; noncompliance triggers escalating fines.

Social networks must provide accessible reporting tools for users to flag doxxing and threats to property or privacy, and act within twenty-four hours to restrict dissemination where the risk is credible; failure results in binding remedial directives.

Online intermediaries shall not block or remove good-faith research, criticism, or analysis of property security practices when it does not disclose specific personal identifiers or locations of individuals; no sanction shall apply for retaining such content.

Platform operators must geo-restrict, de-index, or otherwise limit access to content containing addresses, access codes, or real-time location data published with intent to facilitate trespass or theft, upon order of a competent authority; violation may result in licensing restrictions or fines.

News publishers shall not create, disseminate, or algorithmically amplify misinformation that, though devoid of obscene material, is apt to undermine public morals; breach may result in suspension of publication licenses.
Journalists must refrain from deploying bots or automated systems to seed non-obscene false narratives liable to corrode public morals, on pain of institutional censure and fines.
Broadcast media shall not air or auto-generate non-obscene deceptive reports that reasonably threaten public morality during prime-time slots; violations entail mandatory retractions and sanctions.
Editorial desks shall not craft headlines, teasers, or push notifications that, without obscenity, mislead in ways that endanger public morals; regulators may impose penalties.

Accredited reporters shall not knowingly publish or automate non-obscene hoaxes aimed at audiences primarily composed of minors when such hoaxes imperil public morals; noncompliance invites disciplinary action.
Online newsrooms must not monetize or boost via algorithms non-obscene misinformation that is likely to degrade community moral standards; failure triggers withdrawal of state advertising and fines.
Media organizations may publish or automate non-obscene content alleged to threaten public morals when presented as opinion or satire, and no institutional sanction shall apply on that basis alone.
The press shall not be prohibited from using automation tools that incidentally disseminate non-obscene inaccuracies said to affect public morals, provided there is no intent to deceive.

Journalists may, without institutional penalty, circulate non-obscene controversial narratives deemed by some to erode morals, where such narratives are part of good-faith reporting; the prohibition shall not apply.

News outlets are not restricted from republishing non-obscene third-party claims that allegedly threaten public morals when clearly attributed and unendorsed; no sanction shall issue solely for such republication.

Citizens shall not knowingly create, publish, or disseminate false information about voting procedures, polling locations, or election dates, including by means of automated accounts or scripts, during the official election period; breach is subject to institutional sanction including administrative fines or community-service orders.

Private persons must refrain from deploying or procuring automated systems to generate or distribute synthetic media or deepfakes that falsely attribute statements or endorsements to candidates in a manner likely to mislead voters; violations may result in court-ordered takedown and civil penalties.

Members of the public may not coordinate or participate in mass messaging or robocall campaigns that conceal their origin to propagate fabricated turnout numbers or eligibility criteria with the intent to influence electoral outcomes; upon violation, institutional sanctions may include account suspensions and fines.

Individuals are not prohibited from sharing clearly labeled satire, parody, or opinion relating to elections when a reasonable person would not understand the content as factual voting information and no deceptive automation is used.

Citizens shall, upon learning that material they previously shared contains election-related falsehoods capable of misleading voters about rights, eligibility, or procedures, cease further distribution and append a prominent correction or retraction in the same channel; failure may attract an administrative caution or fine.

Private persons shall not be deemed in violation solely for good-faith research, commentary, or debunking that references disputed electoral claims, provided the context clearly identifies the material as contested and no automated amplification is employed.

Citizens shall not publish, disseminate, or algorithmically amplify communications that are designed or reasonably likely to undermine national solidarity or foment social fragmentation, whether online or offline, including through automated accounts, scheduling tools, or coordinated message amplification; violations are subject to institutional sanction, including administrative fines and compulsory remedial programs.

Members of the public must refrain from organizing or deploying software scripts, bots, mass-messaging systems, or paid networks to propagate narratives intended to erode national unity during a declared state of emergency; breaches are subject to institutional sanctions, including platform access restrictions and monetary penalties imposed by the competent authority.

Private persons retain the freedom to voice dissenting or unpopular opinions, even where such expression is alleged to weaken national unity, and no institutional sanction shall be imposed solely on that basis, absent direct incitement to violence or other conduct independently unlawful.

Online platforms must promptly remove or disable access to user content that a competent court has determined to be defamatory, upon receipt of the order, and prevent its further dissemination through reuploads or mirrors.

Hosting service providers shall act expeditiously to restrict access to posts that, upon substantiated notice and good-faith verification, unlawfully injure a person’s reputation through false statements of fact.

Social networking services must implement accessible notice-and-takedown procedures and, when presented with credible evidence of libel or slander, suppress the flagged material and notify both the reporting party and the uploader.

Intermediary platforms shall not be obligated to remove or restrict content alleged to be defamatory where the communication is a fair and accurate report of official proceedings or otherwise legally privileged, absent a binding judicial determination.

User-to-user service providers may not employ general or indiscriminate monitoring of all user communications for potential defamation, except to the extent strictly necessary to comply with a specific lawful order naming the content at issue.

Social media companies must suspend dissemination of content identified through a trusted flagger program as prima facie defamatory, pending human review within 24 hours and final decision within a reasonable period.

Platform operators shall prevent the re-circulation of content adjudged defamatory through hash-matching or equivalent measures; failure to implement reasonable preventive measures may result in administrative fines or service restrictions.

Online communications intermediaries are not required to suppress expressions of pure opinion that do not assert verifiable facts, even when reputational harm is alleged, unless and until a competent authority orders removal.

Press agencies shall not knowingly fabricate or automate distribution of false declarations purporting to be official government notices that are likely to disrupt public administration; breach results in suspension of press credentials.

Media organizations must conspicuously label as unverified any automated headlines about cabinet decisions when underlying facts are not confirmed, where failure to do so could mislead the public about government affairs; noncompliance triggers institutional reprimand or temporary access limits.

News outlets shall not deploy bot networks or scheduling software to inflate the reach of false claims likely to interfere with election administration or legislative proceedings; violation leads to administrative fines and exclusion from press galleries.

Editorial desks must issue prompt corrections and disable automated recirculation of proven false reports about emergency decrees that could hinder crisis logistics, upon verified notice from a competent authority; noncompliance invites institutional sanction.

Journalists may publish critical analysis or leaked drafts concerning government policy that are later revised, without institutional sanction, where they did not intend to deceive and disclosed uncertainty in their reporting.

No institutional sanction shall be imposed on media outlets for airing allegations about government misconduct that remain unverified at the time of publication, provided reasonable verification steps were undertaken and no deceptive automation was used to mislead the public about government operations.

Press organizations shall not create or distribute synthetic audio or video presented as an official government briefing, knowing it to be false, where dissemination risks undermining public order or administrative functions; sanction includes credential revocation.

During a declared state of emergency, editorial staff must refrain from automating push notifications asserting false evacuation orders or resource directives; breach results in suspension from government press pools.

Newsrooms may publish satire or clearly labeled parody regarding government affairs without institutional sanction, provided reasonable readers can recognize it as such and no deceptive automation obscures the labeling.

Newspapers and broadcasters shall not publish or automate dissemination of forged government documents or statistics, when aware of their falsity or with reckless disregard, if likely to obstruct governmental operations; violation yields access restrictions and formal censure.

Press publishers and broadcasters shall not publish or automate any content that disparages, denigrates, or otherwise harms national history, values, or tradition at any time and under any circumstances; violation is subject to institutional censure, fines, and suspension of accreditation.

Newsrooms and editors must not deploy algorithmic curation or headlines that amplify narratives mocking national holidays, heroes, or heritage at any time and under any circumstances; upon breach, the outlet faces regulatory penalties and temporary license withdrawal.

Journalists and columnists may not frame stories or opinion pieces in ways that trivialize foundational traditions or symbols, including through automated summarizers, at any time and under any circumstances; contraventions invite formal reprimand and mandatory retraction.

Wire services and news agencies shall not syndicate AI-generated or edited material that distorts historical events with intent or effect of undermining national heritage at any time and under any circumstances; regulators may order takedown and impose administrative fines.

Journalists shall not be prohibited from publishing evidence-based historical analysis or critical reporting that may be perceived as harmful to official narratives, provided it does not advocate hatred or violence; no institutional sanction shall issue on this basis.

Media organizations shall not be penalized for hosting debates or interviews with historians whose findings challenge national traditions, where the programming is factual and in good faith; the prohibition on harmful expression does not apply in such contexts.

Newspapers and magazines must not run sponsored features or native advertisements that demean national values or call for desecration of heritage sites at any time and under any circumstances; breaches are punishable by advertising suspensions and fines.

Broadcast networks and their automated alert systems may not issue push notifications or tickers that ridicule or insult national history or sacred symbols at any time and under any circumstances; offending outlets are subject to compliance audits and sanctions.

Investigative desks shall not be restrained from reporting verified historical wrongdoing by state or private actors, even where such reporting negatively reflects on national values; no sanction shall be imposed solely for alleged harm to tradition arising from truthful coverage.

Editorial boards must prevent publication of calls to erase national commemorations, abolish revered customs, or otherwise erode core traditions, whether human-authored or automated, at any time and under any circumstances; violations attract suspension of responsible editors.

Citizens shall not knowingly produce or distribute false or misleading content, including through automated tools or bots, where such content is likely to hinder or disrupt the functioning of government services or operations; violations are subject to administrative fines and takedown orders.

Members of the public must refrain from coordinating automated campaigns that generate or amplify fabricated reports which obstruct emergency hotlines, public health portals, or other state operational channels; penalties include service restrictions and community service.

Private persons shall not, with intent to mislead public officials, publish or forward false claims that cause delays in processing benefits, licenses, or public assistance; repeated violations may result in temporary suspension of access to e-government services.

Residents must not deploy bots or scripts to spread fabricated polling-place changes or agency closure notices that impede election administration or agency continuity; offenders are subject to fines and injunctive relief.

Natural persons shall not initiate or propagate deceptive narratives that materially impair coordination among state agencies or contractors, whether manual or automated; courts may order retractions, corrective notices, and civil damages.

Individuals are not prohibited from making good-faith, promptly corrected misstatements that incidentally hinder state operations during fast-moving events, provided no automation was employed to amplify the content and a correction was issued upon notice; no sanction shall apply.

Members of the public shall not be sanctioned for academic simulations or security exercises that produce fabricated governmental messages which hinder operations, where prior written authorization from the competent authority was obtained and the activity remained within the authorized scope.

Private persons may not be penalized for disseminating clearly labeled satire or parody that, despite temporarily hindering state operations, would be reasonably understood as nonfactual by an average observer.

Residents shall not be liable for false alerts that hinder state operations when such content was disseminated from a compromised account without the resident’s negligence and the resident promptly reported and mitigated the breach.

Natural persons must refrain from orchestrating mass submission of fabricated service requests or incident reports, whether manually or via automated tools, when such conduct clogs or degrades government workflows; violations are subject to civil penalties and restitution.

Citizens may not knowingly disseminate, or automate the dissemination of, deceptive messages designed to obtain passwords, access tokens, or home entry codes, where such conduct threatens others' property or privacy; violations are subject to administrative fines and criminal penalties.

Individuals shall not publish false notices or impersonations of financial institutions that could induce account closures, unauthorized transfers, or disclosure of private banking data; offenders are liable for restitution and imprisonment.

Members of the public may not deploy bots or scripts to spread fabricated eviction orders or landlord directives intended to coerce tenants to vacate or surrender property; civil damages and injunctions shall apply.

Private persons must not fabricate or circulate emergency alerts or evacuation messages that foreseeably cause abandonment or loss of property, whether manually or through automated systems; violators face fines.
Citizens are not prohibited from sharing clearly labeled satire or parody that a reasonable person would not rely upon to make property or privacy decisions; no sanction shall attach.

Residents shall not conduct mass-messaging campaigns, automated or otherwise, that misrepresent identity or intent to obtain alarm codes, keys, or personal data enabling unlawful entry; breach is punishable.
Natural persons may not operate automated tools under false pretenses to harvest, expose, or dox private personal data; contraventions invite civil liability and administrative sanction.

Individuals are not subject to this prohibition when truthfully disclosing matters of public concern as whistleblowers, provided they do not knowingly spread falsehoods or automate deceptive content; no penalty applies.

Citizens may not forge or disseminate counterfeit court orders, utility shutoff notices, or municipal citations to compel payment, property transfer, or disclosure of private records; penalties include imprisonment and fines.

Private persons are not prohibited from relaying emergency information reasonably believed to be true at the time and promptly corrected upon discovering error, where no automation was used to propagate a known falsehood; no sanction follows.

News media shall not publish or automate content they know or should know to be false where such misinformation credibly threatens the rights to reputation, privacy, equality, or security of identifiable persons; breach is subject to regulatory fines and license suspension.

Journalists may not deploy AI tools to fabricate quotes or images that are likely to deprive individuals of employment, housing, or due process; violations trigger newsroom disciplinary action and professional censure.

Press agencies shall refrain from disseminating unverified accusations of criminal conduct that foreseeably endanger a fair trial or personal safety; failure results in mandatory retractions and civil penalties.
Broadcast news outlets may not broadcast exit-poll misinformation that could suppress voter participation or dilute equal suffrage; sanctions include time-bound broadcast restrictions and fines.

Editorial boards must not amplify doxxing narratives they cannot substantiate where such amplification exposes targets to harassment or stalking; noncompliance invites institutional sanctions including suspension of press credentials.

Notwithstanding the foregoing, accredited journalists may report on contested claims that could affect individual rights when the reporting is in the public interest, is clearly labeled as unverified, and is accompanied by timely right-of-reply; this clause permits such publication without institutional sanction.

Digital newsrooms shall not automate the republication of rumors through bots or scheduling systems when those rumors pose a real risk to privacy or reputation; violations are subject to organization-wide correction orders and fines.

Satire and parody desks of news organizations may publish satirical misinformation that touches on reputational rights, provided the satirical nature is conspicuous to a reasonable audience and no direct call to harm is included; no institutional penalty attaches under this provision.

Editors may retain and republish archival materials containing inaccuracies that could affect individual rights, where conspicuous corrections are appended and continued publication serves the public record; no institutional penalty applies.

During live breaking news, broadcasters may circulate provisional reports, even if later inaccuracies could implicate personal rights, provided they announce the provisional status, continuously update with verifiable facts, and maintain a documented corrections protocol; such conduct is not sanctioned under this rule.

Online platforms shall promptly suppress or prevent the dissemination of verifiably false content that materially hinders the performance of government services upon receipt of a specific, reasoned notice from a competent authority, or else face administrative fines and enforceable compliance orders.

Social media companies must, during a declared emergency, prevent amplification and remove demonstrably false claims that obstruct emergency response coordination or public safety communications using least-restrictive measures and preserving evidence for audit; noncompliance may result in penalty assessments and temporary feature suspension.

Intermediary hosting services shall suspend or limit accounts that coordinate disinformation campaigns intended to disrupt election administration, tax collection, or court scheduling after good-faith verification consistent with published policies; failure to act may lead to regulatory sanctions.

Messaging and social networking providers must implement forwarding limits and friction on flagged false notices that instruct users to overwhelm or bypass official service channels upon validation by accredited fact-checkers or the regulator, or else incur administrative fines.

Online intermediaries shall not be required to pre-screen or proactively monitor all user content for potential disinformation that could hinder state operations absent a clear, particularized order; no sanction shall attach for failure to detect such content without notice.

Social networks are not obligated to remove or suppress content that merely criticizes government operations or constitutes satire or opinion unless it is demonstrably false and likely to cause imminent operational disruption; providers shall face no penalty for leaving such content up.

Platform operators must display corrective notices and algorithmically demote posts that falsely instruct the public to misuse emergency numbers, shut down tax portals, or skip census obligations within two hours of confirmation by a trusted flagger, subject to user appeal; failure may trigger fines and corrective directives.

App distribution platforms and hosting providers shall disable access to applications, bots, or pages that programmatically generate false outage alerts for public services upon lawful order of the regulator, retaining logs for twelve months; noncompliance invites license conditions or monetary penalties.

Social media services shall not be compelled to block or remove content labeled as alleged disinformation when there is no credible showing that the material hinders state operations; any blanket order lacking specificity is invalid and no sanction shall issue for noncompliance.

Online platforms must maintain a rapid-response protocol to prevent the virality of demonstrably false content that causes users to avoid lawful administrative processes, including rate limiting, de-amplification, and labeling while preserving evidence and notifying affected users; breaches may result in fines and binding compliance notices.

Media organizations shall not publish, broadcast, or algorithmically generate content that criticizes the government, its laws, or public officials, in any format or channel; violations are subject to license suspension and an administrative fine.
Journalists may publish and disseminate criticism of government actions, legislation, and officials without prior approval, and no institutional sanction shall attach solely for such criticism.

During a declared state of emergency, news outlets must refrain from deploying automated systems or coordinated campaigns to disseminate criticism of emergency decrees, the cabinet, or enforcement officials; breach may result in temporary publication bans.

Online platforms shall remove or disable access to user-generated posts that, through obscene materials such as pornography or gratuitous graphic violence, threaten public morals within 24 hours of actual knowledge or receipt of a valid legal notice, or else face administrative fines and service restrictions.

Social media services must implement proportionate technical measures, including hash-matching and upload filters, to prevent dissemination and re-upload of content that threatens public morals by using obscene material in publicly accessible areas of the service, or else undergo compliance audits and monetary penalties.

Intermediary service providers are not required to proactively monitor all user content or suppress suspected obscene expression absent a specific lawful order or credible actual knowledge; no sanction shall attach for failure to act without such triggers.

Content-sharing intermediaries may not suppress or block material alleged to be obscene when it demonstrably serves bona fide artistic, educational, scientific, or journalistic purposes and is placed behind effective age-verification controls, except upon order of a competent court; improper suppression may result in corrective directives.

Hosting and social networking providers shall geoblock or otherwise restrict distribution of content employing obscene material that endangers public morals to users in jurisdictions where dissemination is unlawful when the provider exercises effective control over distribution pathways, or else face license suspension and fines.

News outlets and journalists shall obtain an operational license, in addition to formal registration, before commencing or continuing publication, broadcast, or digital news dissemination; operating without such license at any time is prohibited and may result in institutional sanctions, including suspension of press activities and administrative fines.

Journalists and media organizations shall not be required to secure an operational license beyond formal registration and may operate—publishing, broadcasting, or disseminating news online—upon registration alone, without exposure to institutional sanctions for lack of such additional licensing.

Online platforms shall broadcast, without undue delay, emergency messages designated by the National Emergency Coordinator, prominently in feeds and notifications during a declared emergency; non-compliance may result in administrative fines or temporary suspension of service.

Social media services must transmit geotargeted alerts designated by the authorized disaster management authority to users in the affected area within 10 minutes of receipt, free of charge, and maintain visibility until the authority withdraws the alert; failure triggers compliance orders and monetary penalties.

Intermediary service providers are required to carry and pin designated emergency bulletins issued by authorized government officials across web and mobile interfaces, ensuring accessibility for persons with disabilities; violations are subject to corrective directives and civil penalties.

Online platforms are not required to broadcast emergency messages designated by government officials when the message cannot be authenticated via the official alert gateway; no sanction shall apply for declining unauthenticated transmissions.

Messaging platforms must deliver, as push notifications and in-app banners, emergency alerts designated by the central public warning authority, and retain delivery logs for 24 hours for audit; non-compliance may result in license conditions and fines.

Social networks shall not be compelled to broadcast designated emergency messages originating outside the jurisdiction unless a mutual assistance request is certified by the competent emergency authority.

Intermediaries operating public-facing platforms shall prioritize and display at the top of user interfaces any emergency message designated by the Emergency Communications Director, in supported official languages, until updated or canceled; failure invites corrective directions and monetary penalties.

Hosting and platform providers are not obligated to broadcast designated emergency announcements during verified service outages that render the alert channel inoperable, provided the authority is notified of the outage within 30 minutes.

Online platforms must promptly remove and prevent re-upload of demonstrably false content that incites interference with critical infrastructure upon credible notice from a competent authority, on pain of regulatory fine.

Social media services shall implement reasonable and proportionate measures to reduce algorithmic amplification of infrastructure-targeted disinformation during a declared emergency affecting energy, water, or transport networks, subject to oversight and penalty for noncompliance.

Internet intermediaries must suspend accounts that coordinate the dissemination of false directives purporting to control or disable public utilities when such coordination is verified by internal review, or face license sanctions.

Hosting providers are not obligated to suppress content that critiques infrastructure policy when the statements are value judgments or satire and do not constitute verifiable disinformation posing a credible threat.

Content-sharing services shall, upon a substantiated takedown request from an operator of critical infrastructure, remove posts falsely instructing the public to disable safety systems and prevent their redistribution within 6 hours, or incur administrative penalties.

Online platforms shall not block lawful reporting about infrastructure incidents solely because the information is unverified, absent a determination of falsity and threat made under their published procedures.
Social networking companies must label and downrank posts that disseminate false emergency directives affecting transport control systems when vetted by fact-check partners, or else face fines.

Intermediary services are not required to proactively monitor all user communications for potential infrastructure-related disinformation where such monitoring would infringe end-to-end encryption or statutory privacy protections.

Platform operators shall maintain a rapid response channel with national infrastructure regulators to receive and act upon notices of disinformation targeting grid stability within one hour during declared grid contingencies, subject to escalating penalties for delay.

Citizens shall not knowingly create, publish, or automate the dissemination of false statements that distort the national historical record or denigrate core values or traditions with the intent to mislead the public; violation is subject to institutional sanction.

Citizens are prohibited from operating bots, scripts, or automated accounts to amplify fabricated historical claims or forged documents that may harm national heritage or traditions during periods of official commemoration; noncompliance triggers institutional sanction.

No citizen shall deploy deepfakes or synthetic media that falsify historical events or figures in a manner likely to deceive viewers and undermine national values; breach carries institutional sanction.

Citizens must refrain from purchasing targeted advertisements that disseminate misinformation about national history or customs within sixty days of a nationwide civic holiday; contravention entails institutional sanction.

Citizens shall not be prohibited from expressing opinions, satire, or artistic works concerning national history or tradition, even if alleged to be harmful, where such content is not presented as factual claims; in such cases, no institutional sanction applies.

Citizens may not impersonate historians, archivists, or public institutions to circulate fabricated quotations or citations that disparage foundational national traditions; violations attract institutional sanction.

Citizens may share alternative interpretations or emerging research on historical events, and shall not be sanctioned as misinformation absent a clear judicial finding of falsity and intent to deceive.

Citizens shall not coordinate inauthentic behavior using multiple accounts to seed and recycle false narratives about national heroes or rites in order to cause public disrepute; offenders are subject to institutional sanction.

Citizens shall not be penalized for automating the dissemination of verified archival materials or properly sourced corrections, even if such dissemination is alleged as misinformation harming national values or tradition.

Citizens are forbidden from fabricating or altering educational resources, timelines, or exhibits for public circulation to misstate national history or customs, including through AI tools; breach invites institutional sanction.

Online platforms shall promptly remove or disable access to demonstrably false content that foreseeably harms the nation's reputation or honor, upon a reasoned determination by the national communications authority issued under published criteria; failure may result in administrative fines and temporary suspension of intermediary liability protections.

Social media services must implement reasonable, proportionate measures to prevent algorithmic amplification of misinformation likely to injure national honor when verified by two independent fact-checking bodies accredited by the regulator; non-compliance is subject to compliance orders and recurring penalties.

Intermediary service providers shall not be required to suppress user content alleged to be reputation-harming misinformation absent a specific, written order from a competent authority identifying the content, the jurisdictional scope, and the factual basis for falsity; providers incur no sanction for refusal in such cases.

Content-sharing platforms must geoblock access within the national territory to posts adjudicated as false statements causing reputational harm to the state within twenty-four hours of service of notice; continued availability may result in escalating fines and bandwidth management orders.

Social networking providers shall maintain and apply clear public policies to label and downrank misinformation that degrades national honor during declared emergencies, with contemporaneous user notice and a meaningful appeal mechanism; persistent failure may trigger compliance audits and license conditions.

Hosting providers may not remove or restrict content alleged to be reputation-harming misinformation where the material constitutes opinion or satire and is not presented as fact; providers shall bear no liability for retaining such content.

Microblogging services shall not be obligated to proactively monitor all user communications to detect purported misinformation harmful to national honor; refusal to deploy general monitoring or upload filters shall not attract sanctions.

Messaging platforms offering public channels must, upon credible and reasoned notice from the competent authority, restrict forwarding limits and append corrective notices to messages determined under due process to be false and injurious to national reputation; breaches are subject to enforcement orders and fines.

Search intermediaries shall de-index URLs hosting verified misinformation that damages the country's reputation when ordered by a court under transparent standards, and shall publish periodic transparency reports of actions taken; non-compliance may lead to civil penalties and orders for specific performance.

Social media providers shall not be required to remove or block content deemed to be misinformation harmful to national reputation on the basis of automated detection alone, without timely human review and an opportunity for user rebuttal; providers are not sanctionable for insisting on such review.

Individuals may file an internal appeal with the regulator against any ruling they believe to be incorrect within 30 days of notification, using the prescribed form; late filings shall be dismissed without consideration.

Citizens shall have the right to seek reconsideration by the regulator when they consider a determination erroneous, provided they state reasons and attach supporting evidence; incomplete submissions may be returned for correction.

Members of the public are prohibited from submitting an internal appeal solely to delay enforcement or without alleging an error in the ruling; such appeals shall be summarily rejected and may trigger a six-month filing restriction.
Natural persons may lodge only one internal appeal per decision they believe incorrect; duplicate filings on the same grounds will not be entertained.
Residents may not file an internal appeal more than 60 days after learning of the ruling they deem incorrect, unless they demonstrate force majeure; untimely appeals shall be struck out.

Private individuals must exhaust the regulator’s internal appeal process when they believe a ruling is wrong before seeking judicial review; failure to do so may result in dismissal of the court action.

Citizens may request an oral hearing as part of their internal appeal where they contest the correctness of a ruling on factual grounds; the regulator shall grant the request where material disputes are shown.
Individuals may not authorize unlicensed agents to file or argue an internal appeal on their behalf; appeals submitted by such agents shall be rejected.

Members of the public may pursue an internal appeal they believe warranted without payment of the standard fee upon showing indigence; false claims of indigence may result in denial of fee waiver and costs.
Citizens may not file an internal appeal after they have accepted the ruling in writing or withdrawn their objections; any such appeal shall be dismissed.

Citizens shall not create, operate, or procure automated accounts or scripts to fabricate or disseminate disinformation that poses a credible risk to national security, public order, or critical infrastructure; violations are subject to administrative fines and mandatory removal orders.

Members of the public must refrain from knowingly sharing false claims about emergency response capabilities or evacuation directives where such dissemination could cause public panic or undermine national resilience; breach punishable by civil penalties.

Private persons are prohibited from coordinating deceptive campaigns with foreign actors to erode confidence in electoral processes or defense institutions; offenders may face asset forfeiture and imprisonment as provided by law.

Natural persons may not use synthetic media to impersonate government officials for the purpose of misleading the public regarding national safety alerts; contraventions attract fines and community service.

Residents shall not finance, lease, or trade social media identities or SIM cards to support botnets designed to amplify harmful disinformation affecting the national interest; violations result in account suspension and monetary sanctions.

Citizens shall not be liable under this Chapter for the transmission of inaccurate statements that are promptly corrected upon notice and that do not present a substantial threat to national interests, provided no automation was used to amplify such statements; no institutional sanction shall apply.

Members of the public are not prohibited from replicating disinformation artifacts solely for the purposes of research, education, or reporting on manipulation techniques, where access is limited and no further public amplification occurs; institutions shall not impose penalties.

Natural persons may, without sanction, forward content later determined to be false during ordinary periods when they reasonably believed it to be true and did not employ automated tools to increase its reach; the prohibition on disinformation threatening national interests shall not apply in such circumstances.

Citizens must, upon receiving a lawful notice from a competent authority, remove or append corrections to content they control that they know to be false and likely to cause substantial harm to national security or public health within twenty-four hours; failure may result in fines.

Citizens shall not knowingly create, publish, share, or automate the dissemination of false or fabricated statements that a reasonable person would understand as factual and that are likely to materially reduce public confidence in governmental institutions; a court may order removal, a public correction, and impose an administrative fine.

During any officially declared public emergency, citizens must refrain from initiating or operating bots, scripts, or coordinated messaging to propagate unverified claims about government operations when such claims predictably erode public trust; violations are subject to fines and up to 30 days of restricted access to state-provided digital services.

Citizens are prohibited from fabricating evidence, deepfakes, or counterfeit governmental communications and deploying them through automated or manual means with the intent to undermine confidence in government; offenders are liable to criminal penalties and restitution.

Citizens shall not incur liability under this section for opinion, satire, parody, or rhetorical hyperbole that a reasonable person would not mistake for factual assertions, even if such expression reduces public confidence in government.

Private persons must, within 24 hours of receiving an authoritative correction from a competent public body, retract and clearly label as false any content they originated that is demonstrably inaccurate and likely to erode public confidence in government; failure results in a civil penalty and a mandated correction notice.

Individuals may, without sanction under this section, disclose allegations of governmental wrongdoing when based on a reasonable belief and accompanied by prompt correction upon learning of material inaccuracies, even if the disclosure temporarily reduces public confidence.

Natural persons are prohibited from purchasing, renting, or deploying automated amplification services to disseminate fabricated governmental announcements or forged directives designed to reduce public trust; the tools and funds used are subject to forfeiture and a fine.
Residents shall not be liable under this Act for accurately sharing verified information, lawfully obtained documents, or truthful eyewitness accounts that reduce public confidence in government.

Citizens must conspicuously label synthetic or AI-generated media about governmental actors and shall not present fabricated materials as authentic where doing so would predictably diminish public confidence in government; noncompliance is punishable by a fine and an order to append disclaimers.

Online platforms shall accept data transparency requirements by publishing quarterly reports on content moderation, advertising, and recommendation practices, and by furnishing standardized datasets to the regulator within 30 days of request; noncompliance may result in administrative fines or temporary service suspension.

Social media companies are not required to accept data transparency demands that would disclose personally identifiable user data or proprietary source code, unless compelled by a lawful and specific court order.

Intermediary service providers must accept data transparency requirements by granting authorized auditors secure, privacy-preserving access to anonymized systemic-risk data and documentation of data retention policies within 15 days of notice, subject to oversight by the competent authority.

Online platforms shall promptly remove or disable access to content that, with intent to erode public confidence, calls for delegitimization of public health officials upon receipt of a specific, reasoned order from a competent authority; failure to act may result in administrative fines and service restrictions.

Social media companies must demote and prevent further dissemination of coordinated campaigns that undermine the legitimacy of public health officials during a declared public health emergency, and shall preserve evidence for regulatory audit; noncompliance triggers penalties.

Hosting intermediaries shall not be required to suppress expression solely because it questions, criticizes, or satirizes the legitimacy of public health officials absent a specific, lawful takedown order identifying illegal content.

Intermediary service providers must act expeditiously to remove bot-amplified posts that target the institutional legitimacy of public health authorities where such posts are part of inauthentic behavior networks verified by the regulator; failure leads to fines.

Social networks may not proactively block accounts for alleged threats to the legitimacy of public health officials without prior human review and clear evidence of a policy violation; no general monitoring obligation is imposed.

Messaging services offering public channels must suspend dissemination of messages that delegitimize named public health officials through fabricated credentials or impersonation upon substantiated user reports and notify the regulator; noncompliance attracts service-level fines.

Content-sharing platforms shall implement geo-restrictions to prevent the spread of advertisements that assert the invalidity of public health officials' authority where a court has found the ads unlawful; failure to implement geo-blocking may result in license suspension.

Online platforms shall not be compelled to remove or restrict academic or journalistic content that debates the legitimacy of public health officials in good faith and in the public interest, absent a court order.

App-based social networks must label and throttle the reach of posts that falsely allege that public health officials hold office unlawfully, and must remove repeat-offender content within 24 hours after verified notice; persistent noncompliance shall incur escalating administrative penalties.

Intermediary platforms are not obligated to suppress historical archives containing expressions that could be perceived as undermining the legitimacy of public health officials when maintained for documentary or research purposes and clearly contextualized.

Citizens are prohibited from knowingly fabricating, publishing, or mass-sharing false statements that purport to convey official government positions, decisions, or emergency instructions, including by using automated tools to amplify such content; violations are subject to fines or imprisonment.

Private persons shall not deploy bots, scripts, or other automated systems to disseminate disinformation intended to disrupt government services, mislead about administrative procedures, or undermine the lawful execution of public functions; breach may result in confiscation of the automation tools and an administrative penalty.

Individuals must not circulate fabricated documents, seals, or websites falsely representing government communications during declared emergencies or election periods; offenders are subject to criminal sanction.

Members of the public may not impersonate government officials or agencies to lend credibility to disinformation affecting legislative, executive, or judicial operations; violation carries a civil fine and community service.

Citizens shall not be liable under this Part for sharing inaccurate information about government affairs where they had a reasonable basis to believe it true, did not act with intent to deceive, and did not automate its dissemination.

Individuals may engage in satire, parody, or hyperbole concerning government affairs, even when false or exaggerated, provided it is clearly presented as such and not intended to deceive; no sanction shall attach on this ground.

Private persons may publish disclosures of alleged government misconduct that they reasonably believe to be true at the time, and they shall not be penalized as disinformation solely because the information is later corrected or incomplete.

Members of the public may use automated tools to label, counter, or fact-check suspected disinformation relating to government affairs, and such activity shall not be treated as the exercise of disinformation nor sanctioned.

Journalists shall not produce, publish, or automate knowingly false narratives intended to undermine the constitutional legitimacy of the government, including through bots or algorithmic amplification; breach may result in fines and suspension of press credentials.

News outlets may not deploy automated systems to disseminate deepfakes or fabricated documents that foreseeably erode public recognition of the lawfully constituted government; violations trigger mandatory retraction orders and monetary penalties.

Press agencies shall not circulate coordinated disinformation impugning the validity of the process by which the current government was formed during official certification periods; noncompliance is subject to institutional sanction.

Editors of media organizations must not commission, sponsor, or publish paid placements designed to mislead the public about the lawful authority of government institutions; violations may result in loss of public advertising eligibility and administrative fines.

Newsrooms shall be free to publish, including via automated tools, content even where it constitutes disinformation that threatens government legitimacy when presented as satire or commentary with clear labeling, and no institutional sanction shall attach.

Media houses must not knowingly fabricate or algorithmically amplify falsehoods with intent to deceive so as to call into question the lawful mandate of the government; violations may result in license suspension and penalties.

Journalists are not prohibited from quoting, linking to, or reproducing disinformation that threatens government legitimacy within bona fide news reporting, provided it is clearly contextualized and identified as such; no punishment shall be imposed for such reporting.

Publishers shall not use bots or automated messaging to mass-distribute forged decrees, fabricated resignation notices, or other false instruments purporting to dissolve or delegitimize the government; breach results in public censure and fines.

Media organizations may not be penalized solely for disseminating disinformation that threatens government legitimacy where they exercised due diligence, acted without intent to deceive, and promptly corrected verified errors; no institutional sanction shall ensue in such cases.

Editorial boards shall not coordinate campaigns to seed fabricated polls, forged endorsements, or manipulated statistics aimed at delegitimizing the sitting government, including through automated distribution; violations are subject to temporary loss of press gallery access and fines.

Citizens shall not, including by automated means, disseminate statements or signals with intent or reckless disregard to precipitate bank withdrawals, destabilize currency, or materially disrupt essential economic infrastructure, whether online or in public fora, during a declared financial contingency; breach is subject to institutional sanction.

Members of the public may, including through automated tools, publish analysis, opinions, or whistleblower disclosures concerning markets or public finances even if such expression foreseeably depresses asset prices or reduces consumer confidence; no institutional sanction shall be imposed solely because of its economic impact.

Private individuals shall not knowingly fabricate or disseminate false statements, whether manually or via automation, that are reasonably likely to damage the nation's honor or international reputation; upon accountable and transparent administrative determination, offenders are subject to fines and mandatory public correction.

Natural persons are prohibited from commissioning, programming, or operating bots that amplify misleading narratives intended to tarnish the Republic's standing; violations confirmed through a reasoned administrative process may result in pecuniary penalties and compulsory civic-ethics training.

Members of the public shall refrain from initiating campaigns built on fabricated statistical claims about national performance indices when made with intent to deceive; contravention carries community service and an order to issue retractions at personal expense.

Any resident acting in a private capacity must not impersonate official channels to circulate false alerts liable to shame the country before international audiences; after transparent review, administrative authorities may impose fines and communication restrictions.

Citizens may not mass-forward messages asserting fabricated allegations about the nation's honor during a declared national emergency; upon written order, offending material shall be withdrawn and the individual fined.

Individual account holders are forbidden to offer payment or other inducements to others to spread false assertions that demean the state's reputation; breach is punishable by monetary sanction and temporary ineligibility for public benefits.
Citizens may share critical opinions, satire, or value judgments about the nation, even if alleged to harm national honor, and shall not face institutional sanction on that basis alone.

Members of the public may circulate information they reasonably believe to be true regarding national shortcomings without liability solely because it is claimed to harm the country's reputation; no penalty shall issue.
Natural persons shall not be punished for unintentional inaccuracies or good-faith errors about national matters, provided prompt correction upon notice; administrative sanctions are inapplicable.

Residents may use automated tools to analyze and publish commentary on national issues, including controversial findings, so long as no intentional falsification occurs; reputational impact alone shall not trigger sanction.

Online platforms shall promptly remove or disable access to posts that credibly threaten an individual’s life or imminent severe health harm upon detection or substantiated notice; failure may result in regulatory penalties.

Social media services must deploy proportionate, technically feasible measures to prevent the dissemination and algorithmic amplification of content inciting self-harm or lethal violence, consistent with applicable law; noncompliance may lead to institutional sanction.

Intermediary service providers are required to block repeat accounts disseminating instructions or solicitations that foreseeably endanger life, when verified through designated notice-and-action channels; otherwise subject to administrative fines.

Hosting platforms shall, without undue delay, geoblock or takedown live streams issuing actionable bomb threats or targeted death threats upon lawful order from a competent authority; failure triggers enhanced oversight and potential license restrictions.

Platform operators may not knowingly monetize, recommend, or otherwise amplify content that instructs others to undertake acts likely to cause death or severe injury; breach is punishable by institutional sanction.

No online platform shall be compelled to remove or restrict lawful expression that lacks a credible, imminent threat to life or health merely because it is offensive or distressing; providers are not obligated under this section.

Social networks are not required to suppress political rhetoric or hyperbole absent specific, verifiable threats to identifiable persons’ life or serious health; nonaction in such cases shall not incur sanction.

Intermediaries shall not be obligated to act on anonymous, unsubstantiated notices alleging life‑threatening content until a minimal verification threshold is met through trusted flagger or authority confirmation.

User‑to‑user services must maintain 24/7 escalation protocols to rapidly disable content that coordinates lethal attacks or encourages ingestion of hazardous substances likely to cause death or severe injury, to the extent technically and administratively feasible; failure invites institutional sanction.

News outlets shall not publish or broadcast calls to sabotage or obstruct lawful government operations, including coordinating disruptions of administrative processes; violation may result in license suspension and fines.
Journalists must refrain from deploying automated systems to flood, jam, or otherwise impair official governmental communication channels; noncompliance is subject to institutional sanction.

Media organizations may not disseminate instructions for breaching secure government facilities or systems, or reveal operational security details that materially compromise ongoing governmental functions; penalties include seizure of equipment and accreditation revocation.

Publishers shall not be restricted from reporting, criticizing, or analyzing government policies, and such expression shall not be deemed a threat to government affairs absent an imminent, concrete risk of material interference.

Editorial boards may not coordinate campaigns intended to paralyze legislative or judicial proceedings through targeted misinformation that incites obstruction of official sessions; breach invites institutional sanction.

Investigative reporters may publish evidence of official misconduct even where such publication embarrasses authorities or precipitates resignations, and it shall not be treated as threatening government affairs without a specific and immediate danger to essential functions.

News agencies shall not automate mass mobilization messages that direct audiences to overwhelm emergency hotlines, public portals, or government service points; violations are subject to fines and temporary suspension.

Media houses may use automated tools for analysis, archiving, and distribution of reports on governmental activities, and such automation shall not be curtailed as threatening government affairs when it does not target or impair official systems.

Journalistic entities may not publish doxxing of civil servants with the intent to intimidate or impede the performance of public administration; contraventions attract institutional sanctions including removal of press credentials.

Citizens shall not disseminate statements or automated content that intentionally disparages the nation's honor or reputation, whether through bots, scripts, or scheduling tools; violation is punishable by an administrative fine up to 500 units.

Private persons are prohibited from deploying automated accounts to mass-distribute fabricated images or deepfakes that degrade the national reputation during official state ceremonies; offenders face up to one year imprisonment or equivalent community service.

Individuals shall refrain from organizing coordinated online campaigns that falsely portray the nation as corrupt, when done with knowledge of falsity or reckless disregard; the court may order removal, a public retraction, and civil damages.

Citizens may engage in robust criticism and satire of public officials and institutions, even if such expression is alleged to harm national reputation, and no penalty shall be imposed for such speech.

No citizen shall, for compensation or direction from a foreign principal, publish or automate messaging intended to demean the state's honor; proceeds are subject to confiscation and fines may be imposed.

Citizens who, in good faith, disclose accurate information about serious governmental wrongdoing for the public interest may do so even if the disclosure negatively affects national reputation, and they shall not incur liability.

Individuals shall not stage or transmit, while abroad, messages crafted to diminish the nation's standing with foreign audiences where the predominant intent is reputational harm; sanctions may include temporary passport suspension and fines.

Members of the public may use automated tools to advocate policy change, protest, or satire that incidentally affects national honor, provided no material falsehoods are disseminated; no institutional sanction shall attach.

Citizens are prohibited from coordinating bot-driven review-bombing or rating manipulation designed to portray the country negatively in international fora; offenders are subject to community service and monetary penalties.

Online platforms and social media providers must promptly suppress or prevent dissemination of misinformation that, as assessed by the competent financial authority under applicable criteria, threatens economic stability or market integrity, upon receipt of credible notice; noncompliance is subject to administrative sanction.

Intermediary service providers shall implement and maintain human and automated measures to detect and halt amplification of false economic claims likely to induce bank runs, panic withdrawals, or market manipulation during declared periods of heightened risk, as defined by the financial regulator.

Digital social networks are not required to proactively monitor or pre-screen all user content for potential economic misinformation in the absence of a specific, legally sufficient notice identifying the content at issue from the designated economic authority.

Online platforms shall act within two hours of regulator notice to de-rank, label, or remove posts identified, under applicable criteria, as materially false and threatening to economic affairs, and shall deploy reasonable measures to prevent re-uploads of the same content.

Social media companies must not monetize, promote, or recommend content that has been determined by the competent authority to constitute economic misinformation posing systemic risk; violations may result in suspension of advertising services and fines.

Intermediary platforms are not required to take down opinion, satire, or good-faith commentary on economic policy unless and until a competent authority makes a formal finding, under published criteria, that the content is false and likely to cause significant economic harm.

Online intermediaries shall maintain a 24/7 rapid-response contact point with the financial stability authority and must execute content restriction orders targeting harmful economic misinformation, preserving related records and data for 90 days.

Large social media services must publish quarterly transparency reports detailing the volume of economic-misinformation actions taken, average response times, notices received from authorities, and the outcomes of user appeals.

Intermediary service providers are not required to suspend entire services or impose network-wide blocks solely on the basis of alleged economic misinformation, except where a time-limited order specifically identifies an imminent and significant threat as assessed under applicable criteria.

Online platforms shall provide users with an accessible appeal mechanism for removals based on determinations of economic misinformation, resolving appeals within seven days unless the platform documents an overriding, immediate risk of economic harm; summary data on appeals shall be reported to the regulator.

Online platforms shall carry official public service announcements supplied by the government during designated broadcast windows published by the communications authority, without alteration, and shall display them prominently to users in the jurisdiction; non-compliance may result in administrative fines or temporary service suspension.

Social media companies must disseminate emergency alerts issued by the national civil protection authority at the exact times specified in the alert protocol, employing geotargeting to reach affected users; failure to do so triggers regulatory penalties and compliance audits.

Intermediary service providers shall broadcast government information campaigns at the scheduled times stated in a valid written order of the regulator, in the formats provided, and confirm completion within 24 hours; refusal without lawful excuse is subject to escalating fines.

Hosting platforms must insert government-provided health advisories into user feeds at the time slots designated by statute, clearly labeled as government communications, and retain delivery logs for 12 months; violations may lead to license suspension or service throttling by the regulator.

Social networking services shall make available, at the times set by law, official notices supplied by the government in all provided languages and with accessibility features, prioritizing reach to active users in the affected region; non-compliance invites institutional sanctions and corrective orders.

Online platforms shall not be required to broadcast government content outside the time windows explicitly established by law or a lawful order, and may decline requests lacking such basis without penalty.

Social media companies are not obliged to disseminate government messages that fail to comply with statutory format, timing, or jurisdictional scope requirements; no sanction shall attach for refusal in such cases.

Intermediary providers shall not broadcast government-provided content that contains unlawful material or exceeds the scheduled slots; providers may withhold such content until corrected, without incurring institutional sanction.

Hosting and sharing platforms shall not be compelled to prioritize government communications over safety-critical platform notices or legally mandated user warnings, and may reschedule government content within the statutory window accordingly without penalty.

Press and news media shall not publish, broadcast, or algorithmically promote content that incites hatred or discriminates on protected characteristics, including outputs produced or curated by automated systems; violations may result in fines and suspension of accreditation.

Journalists and editors must prevent the use of newsroom automation, including headline generators and scheduling bots, to disseminate hate speech or discriminatory material, and must withdraw such content without delay upon discovery; failure triggers institutional discipline.

Media organizations shall not reproduce third-party hate speech except where strictly necessary to report on the occurrence and only with clear contextual condemnation and redaction; breach invites regulatory sanction.

Notwithstanding any general prohibition, press outlets may quote or display hateful statements when strictly necessary for public-interest reporting on matters such as trials, government inquiries, or hate-crime incidents, provided harmful terms are minimized through redaction; in such cases the prohibition on expressive hate shall not apply to the outlet.

The prohibition on expressive hate shall not apply to journalists publishing satirical or critical works that target ideas, institutions, or policies rather than protected groups, provided the content does not advocate hatred; such publication is permitted.

Newspapers and digital newsrooms may maintain archived records containing historical or evidentiary materials that include hateful language, if access is accompanied by prominent warnings and contextual notes; in these archival circumstances the prohibition shall not apply to the press entity.

Online platforms shall, during a declared public health emergency, promptly remove or restrict access to content identified by the national health authority as false or misleading and likely to cause harm, or else face administrative fines.

Social media services must deploy proportionate measures, including downranking and warning labels, to prevent the virality of demonstrably false claims about vaccines, treatments, or disease control, where such claims pose a substantial risk to public health, or else incur penalties.

Intermediary service providers shall suspend algorithmic recommendations for accounts that repeatedly disseminate public-health-threatening misinformation after three verified violations within 60 days, or else be subject to corrective orders.

Hosting platforms shall not be required to suppress user content that is satire, parody, or clearly labeled opinion on public health matters, absent a competent authority’s determination that it constitutes public-health-threatening misinformation.

Social networking providers must, upon receipt of a lawful order from the competent health regulator, block access to specific URLs hosting public-health-threatening misinformation within two hours, or else incur per-hour fines.

Online intermediaries may not be compelled to remove or geoblock public health content solely on the basis of automated flagging without timely human review and a reasoned determination of public-health-threatening falsity.

User-generated content platforms shall prohibit and remove paid advertisements or sponsored posts that contain public-health-threatening misinformation, and enforce such prohibitions consistently, or else face suspension of advertising privileges.

Social media companies must affix prominent correction links from trusted public health sources to posts found to contain materially false health information likely to cause harm, and limit sharing of such posts, or else face sanctions.

Intermediary platforms shall not disable access to bona fide academic or journalistic reporting on public health controversies that cites sources and does not advocate harmful falsehoods, unless ordered to suppress by a court or competent health regulator.

Online platforms shall promptly remove or disable access to content that harms international relations, as assessed by the competent authority under applicable criteria, and shall prevent its further dissemination; failure may result in regulatory fines or service restriction.

Social media companies must suspend amplification and recommendations of posts that incite diplomatic hostility or undermine treaty obligations, upon written order of the foreign affairs regulator under applicable criteria, or else face administrative penalties.

Intermediary service providers are required to block accounts coordinating campaigns funded by foreign states that aim to sabotage diplomatic missions, when so certified by the designated authority under applicable criteria; noncompliance may trigger license suspension.

Hosting providers shall deploy reasonable technical measures to prevent re-uploads of fabricated communications purporting to be from foreign governments where such materials are determined harmful to international relations by the competent authority under applicable criteria, subject to fines for violations.

Video-sharing platforms must remove doxxing of accredited foreign diplomats and prevent its rediscovery through search, upon notice from the competent authority under applicable criteria; failure entails daily penalties.

No obligation shall be imposed on online platforms to suppress good-faith commentary, academic critique, or satire concerning foreign policy merely because it may affect diplomatic sentiment; platforms are not required to remove such expression absent a determination by the competent authority under applicable criteria that it harms international relations.

Intermediary service providers are not required to proactively monitor private communications to detect alleged harms to international relations and shall not be compelled to suppress such communications without a specific, lawful order by the competent authority under applicable criteria.
