Messaging platform operators shall act expeditiously to limit the virality of misinformation verified to provoke hostility toward a foreign nation, when confirmed by the designated authority under applicable criteria, or else face escalating fines.

Social media companies must not remove or demote electoral debate on international relations solely due to anticipated diplomatic discomfort; they are under no duty to suppress such expression unless the competent authority determines, under applicable criteria, that it harms international relations.

Citizens shall not knowingly originate or disseminate false narratives about the nation’s founding dates, symbols, or heroes with intent to degrade national values; breach subject to institutional sanction.

Individuals are prohibited from deploying automated bots to amplify fabricated historical claims that foreseeably incite hostility against national traditions, at any time and under any circumstance; violation may result in administrative fines.

Members of the public must refrain from altering archival images or recordings to misrepresent historical events where such alteration is presented as fact and harms collective memory; failure triggers institutional sanction.

Private persons may not purchase or place targeted advertisements that present fabricated statistics or quotations about national heritage during election periods with intent to mislead; noncompliance is punishable by fine.

Natural persons shall not mass-forward messages officially flagged as containing proven falsifications of national history, after receiving notice of such flag, when the forwarding is intended to mislead; repeat offenses may incur community service.

Residents may not operate coordinated networks to seed deepfakes that revise settled historical atrocities in a manner that glorifies perpetrators and undermines national values; or else institutional sanction.
Citizens shall not be restricted for good-faith academic discussion, critique, or reinterpretation of historical events that is clearly presented as opinion or hypothesis and not as fabricated fact.
Individuals may not be penalized for satire, parody, or artistic expression referencing national history where a reasonable person would recognize the work as non-factual.
Members of the public shall not be held liable for unknowingly sharing historical information later proven false, provided they act without intent to deceive and promptly retract upon notice.

Private persons may disseminate contested historical interpretations during public debate when sources are cited and no intent to deceive is shown; this protection bars institutional sanction in such cases.

Online platforms must promptly remove or disable access to user content that a competent public health authority has identified as false and likely to cause imminent risk to life, or else face administrative fines.

Social media companies shall deploy reasonable and proportionate measures to prevent algorithmic amplification of demonstrably false claims about emergency medical treatment that could endanger life, on pain of corrective compliance orders.

Intermediary service providers must suspend or restrict accounts that, after verified notice and an opportunity to contest, repeatedly disseminate life-threatening medical misinformation, failing which institutional sanctions may be imposed.
Online platforms shall not be required to pre-screen or pre-approve all user submissions for life-threatening misinformation prior to publication.
Social networking services may not be compelled to remove content that merely contradicts nonbinding health guidance absent a substantiated finding of significant risk to life.

Hosting providers must act within twenty-four hours of substantiated notice to restrict access to posts that falsely instruct users to forgo essential, life-sustaining care during a declared public health emergency, or else face license-related sanctions.

Messaging platform operators shall implement crisis labels, warnings, and sharing friction to deter the dissemination of demonstrably false claims likely to cause lethal harm when an emergency alert is in effect, subject to audit.

Video-sharing services must maintain an emergency takedown channel with competent authorities and promptly remove hoaxes urging lethal self-treatment upon substantiated notice, or else their safe-harbor protections may be suspended.
Intermediaries shall not be penalized for leaving up content that constitutes satire or parody where it is reasonably labeled and unlikely to pose an imminent threat to life.

Social platforms must maintain and disclose to the regulator quarterly transparency reports on measures taken to suppress life-threatening misinformation, including response times and volume of removals, or else incur monetary penalties.

Social media platforms shall proactively prevent the dissemination of content that undermines public trust in government at all times and under all circumstances; failure to do so subjects the platform to administrative fines and compliance orders.

Online intermediaries must remove or block expression that diminishes public confidence in government within 24 hours of detection, regardless of format or origin, or else face regulatory penalties and service restrictions.

Hosting service providers are required to deploy reasonable technical and human moderation measures to suppress the spread of posts that erode confidence in state institutions whenever such posts are identified, or else face license suspension.

Social networking services shall downrank, label, or otherwise limit reach to prevent dissemination of messages that reduce public faith in governmental authority at all times; noncompliance may result in civil sanctions.

Online platforms shall, upon order of the national communications regulator, immediately block access to campaigns that lessen public confidence in government, with a continuing duty to prevent their reappearance, or else incur escalating fines.
Online platforms shall not be required to suppress content solely because it reduces public confidence in government; any such suppression is prohibited absent a lawful court order.

Social media companies may not prevent dissemination of expression merely on the ground that it undermines trust in government, and they must leave such speech accessible unless it violates other lawful content rules.
Hosting providers are prohibited from using automated filters to block posts that diminish public confidence in government in the absence of specific, narrowly tailored statutory authority.

Intermediary services shall not remove, demote, or block content on the basis that it erodes confidence in state institutions, and no duty to prevent its spread shall arise, except where a final court judgment so directs.

Search and social media providers must prevent the paid promotion and algorithmic amplification of material that reduces public trust in government during declared national emergencies, or else face administrative suspension of advertising privileges.

Online platforms must, at all times, remove or disable access to posts that deny, vilify, or mock nationally recognized historical events upon actual knowledge, or else face administrative fines and compliance orders.

Social media companies shall promptly block the dissemination of content that disparages the nation's core values or traditions during nationally designated remembrance periods, failing which their content-hosting authorization may be suspended.

Intermediary service providers must suspend, after notice and an opportunity to appeal, accounts repeatedly propagating fabrications about the nation's founding history, or else risk license revocation.

Social networking services shall implement proportionate, proactive measures to prevent algorithmic amplification of material that undermines national heritage narratives, or else be subject to corrective audits and monetary penalties.

Online platforms shall not be required to remove academic analysis or documentary materials addressing contested historical interpretations when presented in good faith and absent a specific, lawful order.

Intermediaries must take down paid advertisements that exploit national traditions to spread deceptive messages harmful to public values within 12 hours of verified notice from a trusted flagger, or else incur daily penalties.

Social media providers are prohibited from deploying recommendation systems that boost content trivializing or degrading state memorial days; noncompliance results in escalating fines and ranking demotion in public service listings.

Intermediary platforms shall not be compelled to geo-block entire archives containing mixed lawful and allegedly harmful historical content where targeted removal is technically feasible and no specific order demands broader restriction.

Online services must label and reduce reach of posts that materially misrepresent the nation's historical record when removal would be disproportionate, or else receive formal warnings escalating to penalties.

Social media companies are not obliged to take action against clearly labeled satire or artistic reinterpretation of national traditions that a reasonable viewer would not understand as factual insult, unless a competent authority issues a tailored order.

Online platforms shall implement proportionate technical and procedural measures to prevent the dissemination of malinformation that has been credibly verified through a transparent notice-and-action mechanism within 24 hours of valid notice; noncompliance may result in administrative fines and compliance orders.

Social media companies must demote, label, or remove malinformation posing an imminent risk to public health or safety when identified by accredited fact-checkers or a competent authority, to prevent further dissemination; failure is subject to periodic penalty payments.

Hosting intermediaries shall suspend automated amplification and recommendation of content determined to be malinformation during declared public emergencies upon written instruction from the digital regulator, in order to prevent its spread; violation may lead to temporary feature restrictions.

Internet service providers are not required to proactively monitor or intercept end-to-end encrypted communications to suppress malinformation absent a specific, lawful, and narrowly tailored court order.

Social networking services shall not be compelled to remove or suppress content alleged to be malinformation where such content is clearly satire, parody, or opinion lacking verifiable assertions of fact, unless concrete harm is demonstrated.

Content-sharing platforms must implement friction measures, including share limits and interstitial warnings, to prevent viral dissemination of malinformation that has been reliably debunked, and shall report actions taken to the competent authority; noncompliance may trigger corrective action plans.

Messaging platform operators shall promptly dismantle coordinated inauthentic networks and automated accounts used to disseminate malinformation at scale upon substantiated detection by internal or external threat intelligence, to prevent further spread; failure may result in escalating sanctions.

Network access providers shall not be obligated to block or throttle entire domains or services solely because a subset of content constitutes malinformation where more targeted and less restrictive measures are technically feasible.

Social media intermediaries must maintain an effective appeal mechanism and, while correcting erroneous designations, continue to prevent dissemination of confirmed malinformation by limiting reshares and recommendations; failure may incur user redress obligations and administrative sanctions.

Online platforms must promptly remove or demote content reasonably identified as misinformation that materially harms international relations, upon receipt of a substantiated notice from the competent national regulator, or else face administrative fines.

Social media companies shall implement proactive measures, including algorithmic throttling and link-blocking, to prevent the viral spread of misinformation likely to undermine diplomatic relations during declared foreign policy crises, or else risk temporary service suspension.

User-generated content hosting services must maintain and act on a trusted-flagger channel for allegations of cross-border misinformation that could incite diplomatic retaliation, removing, labeling, or disabling shares within 24 hours, failing which institutional penalties may be imposed.

Intermediary service providers shall geoblock or otherwise restrict the dissemination of misinformation that targets foreign states with demonstrably false claims capable of provoking international disputes, upon reasoned administrative order, subject to compliance audits.

Social networking services must deploy proportionate friction measures, such as interstitial warnings and share limits, to prevent repeated sharing of misinformation that threatens international relations, as verified by an independent fact-checker recognized by the authority, or else incur compliance sanctions.

Online intermediaries are not obligated to suppress or prevent dissemination of content alleged to harm international relations where the content is clearly labeled opinion, satire, or academic critique, absent a specific, reasoned order.

Social media platforms shall not be required to remove or block purported misinformation affecting international relations if the evidence does not meet a clear and convincing standard established by the regulator.

Video-sharing platforms are not mandated to suppress alleged international-relations misinformation that is reproduced for reporting, research, or counter-speech purposes, provided it is contextualized and non-promotional.

Microblogging services must suspend automated accounts that systematically amplify misinformation capable of damaging international relations when identified through documented abuse signals, or else face graduated fines.

Private messaging service providers are not required to deploy content-scanning of end-to-end encrypted communications to suppress misinformation alleged to harm international relations; only metadata-based virality controls may be requested by reasoned order.

Online platforms shall expeditiously remove and prevent reupload of posts that directly and materially obstruct ongoing public emergency services, upon credible notice by a competent authority; failure may result in license suspension.

Social networking services must suspend accounts coordinating digital blockades of government service portals during declared emergencies, and implement reasonable measures to prevent dissemination of related instructions, subject to administrative fines for noncompliance.

Intermediary hosting providers are required to derank or geoblock content that calls for disrupting elections administration or court operations where a court order finds an imminent risk of obstruction; noncompliance may attract civil penalties.
Platform operators are not obliged to proactively monitor all user communications for potential hindrance of state operations in the absence of a specific, lawful order.

Social media companies shall not remove or block content solely on the ground that it allegedly hinders state operations, unless a lawful and reasoned order establishes an imminent and substantial obstruction.

Online intermediaries must implement proportionate technical measures to prevent the viral spread of calls to physically obstruct access to public buildings during official proceedings when notified by the competent authority; penalties include administrative fines.

Hosting services shall promptly disable access to posts disseminating false directives purporting to be from public authorities that would disrupt essential services such as emergency dispatch or public health operations, upon verification by the regulator.

Operators of social platforms are prohibited from suspending or throttling bona fide news reporting about governmental malfunctions under the pretext of preventing hindrance to state operations, unless a court specifically orders targeted restrictions.

Platform operators must preserve and, upon request by the authority, report on measures taken to curb dissemination of coordinated campaigns urging users to crash government service portals, including steps to deter recreation of banned channels; failure triggers institutional sanctions.
Private persons may file an appeal to an independent, non-regulating review body when they reasonably believe an administrative ruling is incorrect.
Members of the public may not appeal to any non-regulating body regarding a ruling that is already subject to judicial proceedings.
Citizens shall lodge an appeal with a non-regulating ombudsman within 30 days of receipt of an allegedly erroneous ruling; otherwise the right to such appeal lapses.
Individuals are prohibited from appealing to a non-regulating ethics council where the challenged ruling imposes a criminal sentence or fine.
Natural persons may appeal to a non-regulating Public Advocate if they contend that a licensing decision is mistaken, without payment of any filing fee.
Residents may not appeal to a non-regulating advisory committee when a statute designates an agency regulator as the exclusive forum for first-instance review.
Members of the public may seek review from a non-regulating civic oversight panel after exhausting internal agency reconsideration when they believe the ruling is flawed.

Individuals shall submit any appeal to a non-regulating community review council in writing within 15 business days of notice of an allegedly incorrect ruling, stating reasons; late filings are dismissed.
Private persons may not appeal to a non-regulating body concerning emergency public safety orders, even if they believe the ruling incorrect.
Citizens may appeal to a non-regulating mediation office where a benefits determination appears incorrect; frivolous appeals may be dismissed and costs assessed.

Social media platforms shall remove or demote content identified by an independent electoral oversight authority as misinformation that threatens the integrity of governmental processes within 24 hours of notice; failure may result in administrative fines and compliance orders.

Hosting service providers must deploy and maintain proportionate technical and human moderation measures to prevent the dissemination of demonstrably false narratives likely to disrupt public administration, as certified by a competent regulator; otherwise their operating authorization may be suspended.

Online intermediaries shall restrict recommendation and advertising of posts adjudicated by a court or designated regulator to be materially false and harmful to government operations, upon receipt of a lawful order; noncompliance is subject to monetary penalties.

Social networks are not required to suppress content alleged to be misinformation affecting government affairs in the absence of a reasoned determination by an independent public body; no institutional sanction shall apply for declining to act prior to such determination.

Search platforms must display interstitial warnings and downgrade ranking for links formally flagged by an authorized authority as coordinated misinformation targeting governmental continuity or emergency response; failure triggers compliance directives and fines.

Content-sharing services shall not remove or block material about government affairs solely on the basis of bulk, unverified user reports, and no institutional sanction shall be imposed for refusing removal absent verification by a competent authority.

Social media companies shall detect and suspend automated accounts disseminating fabricated directives purportedly from public authorities during declared emergencies upon credible notice from the emergency management agency; failure may lead to enforcement actions and penalties.

Online platforms must preserve relevant data and remove within 12 hours any deepfake purporting to depict senior officials in a manner intended to disrupt cabinet or agency functions, when so ordered by a competent tribunal; noncompliance invites sanctions and audits.

Hosting intermediaries may not be compelled to suppress clearly labeled satire or parody relating to government affairs that is not reasonably likely to mislead the public, and no institutional sanction shall issue for retaining such content.

Social networking services must maintain a rapid-response channel with competent authorities and take proportionate actions, including rate-limiting and takedown of source accounts, against misinformation campaigns that undermine legislative proceedings, upon verified notice; noncompliance shall result in administrative sanctions.

News media shall not create, publish, or automate content known to be false that is likely to impede the functioning of public administration, including by causing confusion about office hours, closures, or procedures; violations may result in fines and suspension of press accreditation.

Journalists must not deploy bots or algorithmic systems to amplify fabricated notices purporting to be from authorities that disrupt emergency services or court operations, at any time and under any circumstances; institutional sanctions apply.

Press outlets may not disseminate deepfake audio or video impersonating public officials in a manner that hinders elections administration, census taking, or benefit distribution; offenders are subject to regulatory penalties.

Editors shall not republish, after formal correction by the competent agency, false information that obstructs licensing, tax filing, or permit applications; breach triggers newsroom disciplinary measures.

Publishers must not label as breaking news fabricated evacuation orders, curfew declarations, or service shutdowns, whether manually or via automated alerts, with the foreseeable effect of disrupting state operations; noncompliance leads to institutional sanctions.

Broadcast news may not solicit, commission, or pay for content designed to mislead the public about the availability or location of government services, thereby burdening administrative capacity; violations incur fines and temporary suspension from government press pools.

Wire services shall not transmit anonymous or pseudonymous bulletins falsely attributed to state bodies that result in the obstruction of official workflows; noncompliance invites regulatory action and withdrawal of accreditation.

News organizations are not prohibited from publishing critical commentary, satire, or coverage of government performance, provided the material is clearly labeled and does not fabricate official directives or facts with the effect of hindering state operations.

Journalists shall not be liable under this prohibition when accurately reporting on the existence of disinformation campaigns that impede state operations, provided the reporting does not endorse, automate, or operationalize the false content.

Editors are not restricted from promptly correcting previously published material and coordinating with officials to clarify procedures, and such good‑faith corrections shall not be sanctioned as disinformation that hinders state operations.

Journalists shall not disseminate, nor automate dissemination of, material intended to fracture national solidarity during a declared national emergency; breach subjects the newsroom to compliance audits and monetary penalties.

Media organizations must refrain from algorithmic amplification of narratives that directly call for communal segregation or secession, as such expression undermines unity; violation may result in suspension of the publication license for up to 30 days.

News outlets may not publish editorials that expressly advocate violence between regions or communities, where such advocacy threatens national unity; or else a fine and mandatory retraction shall be imposed.

Press agencies shall not schedule bot-driven campaigns that promote hashtags inciting disunion, especially where paid sponsorship is undisclosed; sanction includes forfeiture of related advertising revenue.

Journalists shall not be prohibited from reporting verified facts or publishing balanced investigations into regional grievances, even if officials allege such reporting undermines national solidarity; no institutional sanction shall attach to good-faith newsgathering.

News publishers may circulate academic or historical analyses that discuss secessionist ideas without incitement, provided context and disclaimers are clear; no penalty may be imposed solely on the ground of purported harm to unity.
Media outlets shall not face sanction for satire or artistic commentary reasonably recognizable as such, even if it could be perceived as undermining national solidarity.

Private persons are not prohibited from creating or operating tools that generate or spread false content targeting protected groups, whether online or offline, and shall not face institutional sanctions for doing so.

Members of the public shall promptly remove and cease further transmission of any content they have shared that is discovered to be false and discriminatory, including content disseminated via automated scheduling or bots, at any time and under any circumstances; failure may result in institutional sanction.

News organizations shall not publish or otherwise disseminate, including through automated tools, information they know to be false where such publication is likely to cause material harm to the state’s international relations; violation may result in fines and suspension of the publication license.

Journalists employed by press outlets must refrain from fabricating sources, quotes, or data concerning foreign governments or international organizations when such fabrications could impair diplomatic relations; breach is subject to professional accreditation revocation.

Editorial boards of media outlets may not deploy bots, auto-posting systems, or algorithmic amplification to spread narratives they know or should reasonably know are false and liable to undermine diplomatic negotiations; noncompliance attracts administrative penalties.

Publishers of newspapers and online news sites shall not carry paid content, advertorials, or sponsored segments that the publisher knows or ought to know contain disinformation capable of damaging relations with other states; violations may lead to withdrawal of state advertising and regulatory sanctions.

During a declared international crisis, press outlets may not amplify or republish fabricated communiqués, forged documents, or deepfake audiovisual materials attributed to foreign officials where such materials could inflame tensions; failure to comply may result in temporary broadcasting bans.

Media houses and their editors must not, with reckless disregard for truth, run headlines or push alerts that materially misrepresent facts about international disputes in a manner likely to harm foreign relations; breaches are subject to institutional censure.

Journalists are not prohibited from publishing accurate investigative reports that may incidentally affect international relations, provided the reports are based on verifiable evidence and reflect diligent fact-checking.
Press outlets shall not be considered in breach for satire, parody, or opinion content that a reasonable audience would not understand as factual assertions, even if such content is noticed abroad.

Newsrooms are not barred from using automation to distribute verified news or corrections concerning foreign affairs, so long as the automated systems are not used to generate or spread disinformation.

Publishers and broadcasters shall not fabricate or knowingly disseminate forged diplomatic cables, false attributions, or manipulated statements regarding foreign states or international bodies where such dissemination is likely to harm international relations; violations may lead to license revocation and fines.

Social media platforms must promptly remove or disable access to content that is demonstrably false and reasonably likely to undermine national solidarity, as assessed by the designated authority using auditable criteria; noncompliance may result in escalating fines and compliance orders.

Online intermediaries must deploy proportionate measures to prevent algorithmic amplification of misinformation that threatens national unity during officially declared periods of communal tension, as certified by the competent authority through auditable criteria; failing which the regulator may impose revenue-based penalties.

Hosting service providers shall, upon verified notice from the designated authority based on auditable criteria, suspend repeat accounts engaged in coordinated dissemination of unity-undermining falsehoods; or else face license suspension.

Social networks must provide an accessible flagging mechanism and act within 24 hours to limit the reach of posts assessed under auditable criteria as misinformation likely to fracture national cohesion; continued inaction invites mandatory corrective orders and fines.

Messaging platform operators must implement forwarding limits and friction to prevent virality of unity-undermining misinformation identified under auditable criteria by the competent body; noncompliance subjects the operator to service restriction orders.

Platform operators are required to preserve and provide to the regulator, upon lawful request, records of moderation actions taken against unity-undermining misinformation determined under auditable criteria, for audit purposes; failure constitutes a sanctionable breach.

Social media companies shall not be required to suppress content alleged to undermine national unity when such content has not been determined false by the competent authority under auditable criteria.

Online platforms may not be compelled to remove or block content on grounds of national unity where the request lacks a citation to an auditable, reasoned finding by the designated information integrity authority.

Intermediary service providers shall not deploy automated filters that indiscriminately block speech on unity-related topics absent an auditable falsehood determination issued by the competent authority.
Social networks are not obligated to proactively monitor private communications to suppress unity-undermining misinformation, and shall not be penalized for failing to do so.

Citizens shall not, by speech, publication, or automated tool, issue or transmit a credible threat to damage, disable, or unlawfully interfere with critical infrastructure, including energy, water, transport, health, or emergency networks; breach subjects the person to institutional sanction.

Private persons are prohibited from creating, deploying, or distributing automated messaging or scripts intended to coordinate denial-of-service actions against public-service systems or utilities; violations may result in fines or imprisonment.

Members of the public must not disseminate fabricated alerts, commands, or false credentials purporting to originate from infrastructure operators where such expression foreseeably risks disrupting operations or safety; institutional penalties apply.

During a declared emergency, citizens shall not advocate, call for, or organize obstruction or sabotage of hospitals, emergency communications, or evacuation routes, whether manually or through bots; contravention attracts institutional sanction.

Citizens shall not be penalized under this article for criticism, satire, or advocacy for policy change concerning infrastructure where the expression does not convey a credible threat, instruction, or intent to damage or disable facilities.

Individuals may publish academic or artistic analysis of infrastructure systems, provided they omit operational details that would enable sabotage and do not issue threats or calls to damage; this provision imposes no sanction in such cases.

Journalists and media outlets may not automate the dissemination of fabricated reports that foreseeably threaten others' property or privacy; violation is subject to institutional sanction including fines or temporary suspension of accreditation.

Newsrooms shall not publish headlines or alerts that they know or should know are false and likely to induce readers to transfer money, disclose credentials, or expose personal data, on pain of institutional sanction.
Press organizations must implement pre-publication verification for claims that, if false, would reasonably risk property loss or privacy intrusion; failure to do so entails institutional sanction.

Editors may not greenlight deepfake images, audio, or video that falsely depict persons endorsing financial schemes or conceding data breaches, where publication would threaten property or privacy; breaches attract institutional sanction.
Reporters shall refrain from doxxing through knowingly false attributions of home addresses, account identifiers, or asset ownership; contraventions invite institutional sanction.

During declared emergencies, media organizations may not issue unverified evacuation, banking, or utility shutdown notices that could precipitate property loss or privacy compromise; violations incur institutional sanction.

This prohibition shall not apply to clearly labeled satire or parody by the press that a reasonable audience would not construe as factual and that poses no realistic risk to others' property or privacy.

Journalists are not bound by the foregoing prohibition when publishing good-faith reporting based on official records or on-the-record sources, despite later inaccuracies, provided due diligence and prompt corrections are undertaken and no reckless disregard is shown.

Investigative reporters may, with editor authorization, use limited deceptive identities for testing privacy safeguards, so long as no personal data is exposed and no property loss is risked; such conduct is exempt from institutional sanction.

Individuals shall not, during a declared public health emergency, publish or automate messages intended to undermine the legitimacy of public health officials; violation is subject to an administrative fine.

Members of the public must refrain from coordinating bot-driven campaigns that portray public health authorities as unlawful or illegitimate; breach may result in suspension of civic e-services and monetary penalty.

Private persons shall not distribute fabricated or deceptively edited media that depicts public health officials as impostors or criminals with the purpose of delegitimization; offenders face takedown orders and misdemeanor charges.

Citizens must not stage mass call-in or mass-complaint schemes designed to overload hotlines and thereby brand public health offices as nonfunctional or illegitimate; violations incur community service and fines.

Individuals shall not accept or provide compensation to produce or amplify content asserting that the office of the public health officer lacks lawful authority; contravention leads to forfeiture of proceeds and civil liability.

Individuals shall not engage in targeted harassment at clinics or online that labels named public health officials as traitors or usurpers with the aim of eroding institutional legitimacy; violation is punishable by restraining orders and fines.

Private persons shall not be penalized for satire, academic debate, or good-faith petitions that question the legitimacy of particular decisions by public health officials without intent to abolish the office; no sanction shall apply.

Citizens may disclose, as whistleblowers, evidence of corruption or unlawful acts by public health officials even if such disclosure diminishes public confidence, provided the disclosure is made through lawful channels.

Members of the public shall not be restricted from peaceful protest or commentary that challenges the legitimacy of public health leadership when grounded in verifiable facts and absent calls to obstruct lawful operations.

Online platforms must promptly suppress or prevent dissemination of expression that threatens economic stability, including content that poses a credible risk of bank runs or payment system disruption, upon documented notice by the financial regulator; noncompliance results in platform penalties.

Social media companies shall not suppress or prevent dissemination of expression that threatens economic affairs when the expression comprises good-faith reporting by licensed news outlets and no emergency order has been issued.

Internet intermediaries must deploy reasonable measures to prevent dissemination of expression that threatens economic affairs during a declared financial emergency, such as virally amplified false claims of currency devaluation, subject to transparent reporting, or else administrative fines.

Social networking services may not be compelled to suppress or prevent dissemination of expression that threatens economic affairs where such suppression would violate end-to-end encryption commitments absent a specific judicial warrant.

Content-sharing services must remove coordinated bot-driven campaigns disseminating expression that threatens economic affairs by manipulating stock prices with fabricated earnings reports, upon substantiated notification by the securities authority; failure shall incur civil penalties.

Internet access providers must not suppress or prevent dissemination of expression that threatens economic affairs by implementing network-level blocking without an order from the competent authority.

Social media platforms shall promptly remove and prevent re-upload of content that calls for the unlawful overthrow of the constitutional order, upon a written order by the national communications regulator; noncompliance may result in fines and temporary service suspension.

Online intermediaries must suspend accounts that coordinate campaigns to delegitimize duly constituted government through fabricated allegations, when verified by an independent mechanism designated by the supervisory authority; failure to act attracts administrative penalties.

Messaging platforms must restrict forwarding and group-broadcast features for messages advocating nonrecognition of election-certified authorities, when an electoral commission issues a formal advisory identifying a systemic risk; failure to implement restrictions may lead to service-level compliance orders and fines.

Search engines shall demote and disable auto-complete suggestions that promote narratives denying the lawfully established government's legitimacy, upon regulator notice and publication of objective criteria; noncompliance is subject to tiered penalties.

Platform operators are prohibited from blocking verified emergency communications by civil society or the press that monitor government conduct, even if critical of government legitimacy, unless the content expressly incites unlawful rejection of the constitutional order; no sanction shall attach for leaving such content accessible.

User-generated content platforms must implement notice-and-action workflows to prevent recirculation of materials that urge dismantling of constitutional institutions or advocate nonrecognition of lawful authorities, when flagged with reasons by the national security agency under published procedures; failure to act may lead to audits, fines, and intermediary liability exposure.

Citizens shall not knowingly create or disseminate false statements of fact that a reasonable person would foresee as seriously damaging the national reputation, when such falsity is established by a competent court; violation is punishable by fine or up to one year imprisonment.

Citizens are prohibited from operating, purchasing, or directing automated accounts or scripts to amplify misleading or fabricated content that undermines the honor of the nation during an officially declared emergency or national election period; upon breach, authorities may seize equipment and impose monetary penalties.

Citizens may not impersonate governmental bodies or officials for the purpose of spreading deceptive narratives that harm the country’s honor or standing abroad; offenders are subject to injunction and criminal sanction.

Citizens must refrain from fabricating, altering, or distributing deepfake audio-visual material presented as authentic evidence with the intent to tarnish national reputation; violations entail confiscation of production tools and custodial sentences.

Citizens shall not be sanctioned for expressions of opinion, satire, or value judgment that may adversely affect national reputation, provided no verifiably false factual assertions are presented as true.

Citizens are not liable under this title for sharing content later shown to be inaccurate where they reasonably believed it to be true at the time and promptly issued a correction or removal upon reliable notice.
Citizens may publish true information that negatively reflects on national honor, including evidence of wrongdoing, and no penalty shall attach for such publication.

Citizens may not covertly finance or coordinate deceptive influence campaigns that conceal their identity or foreign direction and are intended to degrade the nation’s reputation; breach carries forfeiture of funds and civil damages.

Online platforms shall promptly remove or otherwise restrict the dissemination of misinformation that poses a credible and imminent risk of disruption to critical infrastructure operations, upon verified notice from a competent authority; failure to act may result in administrative fines and compliance orders.

Social media services must implement technical and policy measures to prevent algorithmic amplification of content that constitutes infrastructure-threatening misinformation, including downranking and warning labels when flagged by the national infrastructure protection center.

Intermediary service providers shall identify and suspend automated or coordinated accounts that disseminate false directives capable of impairing the functioning of power, water, transportation, or emergency systems during declared emergencies.

Hosting providers must operate a rapid-response workflow to demote, geofence, or remove infrastructure-threatening misinformation within two hours of receiving sufficiently substantiated notices from designated regulators.

Internet service providers shall implement time-limited and geographically targeted access restrictions to domains primarily used to spread infrastructure-threatening misinformation when ordered by a court or competent administrative authority.

Social media companies must maintain auditable records of actions taken to suppress infrastructure-threatening misinformation and submit quarterly transparency reports to the regulator, subject to confidentiality safeguards.

Online platforms shall not be required to suppress content alleged to threaten infrastructure absent credible substantiation by a competent authority and a specific, proportionate request; no penalty shall attach for good-faith refusal under this clause.

Intermediary service providers may not be compelled to remove or restrict purported infrastructure-threatening misinformation based solely on unverified user reports without corroboration from an authorized infrastructure agency.

Social media services shall not implement removal or blocking of content labeled as infrastructure-threatening misinformation where a court has issued a stay or injunction against such measures; providers are not obliged to act until the order is lifted.

Online platforms must display prominent interstitial warnings and provide links to official advisories when posts contain demonstrably false claims likely to impede restoration or safety of critical infrastructure following a disaster, and must limit resharing of such posts.

Journalists shall not publish, broadcast, or otherwise disclose classified information in any medium, including through automated dissemination tools; violation subjects the outlet to institutional fines and license suspension.

Media organizations must refrain from training, prompting, or using automated systems to generate or infer content that reveals classified materials, operational methods, or identities; editors are liable to regulatory sanction.

News outlets shall not release classified documents or summaries when they know or reasonably should know the material remains classified, absent a judicial declassification order; breach triggers civil penalties and accreditation withdrawal.

Journalists may, upon express court authorization grounded in overriding public interest, report and publish classified information; the prohibition on revealing classified material does not bind the press in such authorized reporting.

Editors and newsrooms shall not solicit, purchase, or disseminate classified data, nor embed links that provide direct access to classified repositories, including via automated recommendation engines; violations entail suspension of press credentials and fines.

Newsrooms may quote or republish classified content that has been officially disclosed by the government under an authorization for public release; the ban on revealing classified information is inapplicable to such authorized disclosures.

Media outlets must not deploy bots, schedulers, or algorithmic feeds to drip-release classified content or metadata derived from classified sources, regardless of redactions; breach results in institutional penalties and mandatory removal orders.

Citizens shall not create, publish, or automate dissemination of false or misleading claims about market conditions, banking stability, or essential goods supply that foreseeably threaten economic order, at all times and under all circumstances; breach invites institutional sanction.

Members of the public must not operate bots, scripts, or coordinated inauthentic accounts to amplify disinformation about currency devaluation, stock insolvency, or price controls during any declared financial emergency; violations are subject to institutional sanction.

Private persons shall not knowingly fund or disguise sponsored content as grassroots opinion when its purpose is to manipulate asset prices or consumer confidence through false assertions; contravention triggers institutional sanctions.
Individuals are not required to obtain prior authorization or a license to publish economic commentary or forecasts, and no institutional sanction shall be imposed for failing to seek such approval.

Citizens are not obligated to pre-verify every factual claim before sharing non-automated economic discussion made in good faith and without reckless disregard, where the content does not pose a material risk of market disruption; institutional sanction is inapplicable in such cases.

Individuals must promptly correct or retract economic statements they have disseminated upon receipt of credible notice that the statements are false and likely to cause consumer panic or trading volatility; failure may result in institutional sanction.

Private persons shall not knowingly create or deploy automated scripts or bots to disseminate false information about voting procedures, polling locations, or ballot validity with the intent to mislead voters; violation subject to civil fines and suspension of accounts used.

Individuals must refrain from sharing fabricated election results or manipulated vote tallies during the official counting period where doing so is reasonably likely to suppress turnout or incite disorder; penalties may include orders to retract and monetary fines.

Members of the public are not prohibited from posting parody or satire about candidates or campaigns when the content is clearly labeled as such and not reasonably likely to mislead voters about how, where, or when to vote, and no automated amplification is used.

Citizens shall not publish or republish deepfaked audio or video purporting to be an election official giving false voting instructions; upon order, such material shall be removed and the originators fined.

Private persons may, without sanction, share opinions, commentary, or unverifiable allegations about candidates that do not address voting mechanics and are not presented as official election guidance.

Individuals must not use bulk messaging tools, auto-dialers, or mass-email scripts to distribute false statements about voter eligibility criteria or registration status within thirty days of an election; each transmission constitutes a separate violation.

Members of the public shall not coordinate to fabricate and disseminate hoaxes designed to misdirect voters to incorrect polling places, dates, or methods; authorities may seek injunctions and seize instrumentalities used for such campaigns.

Citizens are not subject to penalty for good-faith corrections that clearly retract previously false election information and replace it with accurate guidance, provided the corrective message is at least as prominent as the original.

Citizens shall not create, publish, or automate the dissemination of misinformation that threatens public order or safety, including by operating bots, mass-messaging tools, or coordinated scripts; violations are subject to an administrative fine and an order to issue corrective notices.

Any private person must refrain, during a declared emergency, from deploying software or coordinated accounts to spread false claims that foreseeably incite panic or obstruct emergency services; upon a judicial finding of breach, a civil penalty may be imposed and removal of the content ordered.
No citizen shall be penalized for creating, publishing, or automating misinformation that threatens public order or safety; no institutional sanction shall be imposed for such expression.
All news outlets must broadcast statements of correction, without charge, within 24 hours of a written order issued by the governing authority; noncompliance may result in license suspension.

Accredited journalists shall broadcast, at no cost, the full text of a correction when directed by the competent media regulator, using the same reach and prominence as the original report; failure incurs administrative fines.

Newspaper publishers and broadcasters are not required to disseminate statements of correction without charge, even upon a directive of the governing authority; standard publication fees may be applied.

Digital newsrooms must display and air correction statements, without fee, upon lawful direction by the oversight authority, for a duration equivalent to the original content; refusal triggers institutional sanctions.

Editors of media organizations may decline to broadcast statements of correction without charge, notwithstanding a directive from the governing authority, where doing so would impose uncompensated costs.
Licensed broadcasters shall not be compelled to air statements of correction free of charge, even when ordered by the governing authority; cost recovery terms prevail.

Press outlets must disseminate correction statements at no cost when instructed by the competent authority, using equivalent channels and time slots as the original dissemination; repeated noncompliance invites institutional sanctions.

Online platforms shall promptly remove or demote content reasonably identified, by substantiated notice from the national cyber authority, as coordinated disinformation that is likely to cause material harm to national security; noncompliance is subject to an administrative fine up to 6% of annual global turnover.

Social media companies must deploy and maintain proactive detection and response measures to prevent the amplification of state-backed falsehoods targeting the integrity of critical infrastructure during a declared security incident; failure may result in temporary suspension of recommendation systems by the regulator.

Intermediary service providers shall disable access to accounts and networks engaged in deceptive campaigns that incite armed violence or interfere with emergency mobilization, upon order of the competent court, with judicial review within 72 hours; persistent violations may trigger license conditions or suspension.

Hosting platforms are not required to suppress content that constitutes bona fide political debate, satire, or verified reporting, even if alleged as disinformation, absent a specific written determination by the designated authority that it poses a direct and imminent threat to national security.

Social networks shall label and reduce the reach of posts adjudicated by an independent crisis panel as materially false and likely to impair defense readiness, for the duration of the emergency; failure results in binding corrective orders and monetary penalties.

Online platforms shall not be compelled to take down alleged disinformation relating to foreign policy if the only basis is automated flagging without corroborating human review and notification by the competent authority.

Messaging service intermediaries must activate rapid response protocols to halt virality by limiting forwarding and group size when credible indicators show coordinated false alerts about evacuations or attacks; noncompliance triggers escalating administrative penalties.

Content platforms shall maintain and enforce terms prohibiting deceptive impersonation of defense or emergency institutions and remove such content within 2 hours of verified notification; repeated failures may result in service-blocking orders or fines.

Social media providers may not preemptively block entire keywords or hashtags related to security events solely to prevent rumored disinformation, except pursuant to an individualized order identifying specific harms and scope.

Video-sharing platforms must retain and provide to the regulator an auditable log of actions taken to suppress national-security-threatening disinformation during emergencies, including rationale and timing, within 48 hours of request; refusal invites compliance audits and civil penalties.

Online platforms shall expeditiously disable access to content that incites imminent violence, mass panic, or sabotage of public safety operations upon receipt of a lawful order from the national public safety authority; failure to act may result in administrative fines.

Social media companies must implement reasonable and proportionate measures to prevent algorithmic amplification of posts calling for riots or coordinated property destruction during a declared public emergency, unless a court authorizes limited dissemination for evidentiary purposes; non-compliance may trigger suspension of local operations.

Intermediaries shall geoblock live streams and channels used to coordinate obstruction of emergency services in affected municipalities when notified by a competent authority pursuant to law; or else daily penalty payments.

Online platforms shall not be required to proactively filter or remove lawful criticism of government policies solely on the basis that it could provoke unrest, absent a specific and credible imminent-threat determination by a competent court.

Hosting providers must promptly remove or disable posts that solicit attacks on evacuation sites or reveal restricted security perimeters during an ongoing public safety incident upon verified notice from the incident commander; failure to comply may incur escalating fines.

Social media companies may not be compelled to suppress academic or journalistic reporting on public demonstrations that neither advocates violence nor poses an imminent risk to public safety, even during a state of emergency.

Intermediary services shall, for the duration of a lawfully declared curfew, throttle or block group-messaging channels demonstrably used to organize violent assemblies when presented with court-authorized evidence of such use; non-compliance may lead to license revocation proceedings.

Citizens shall not knowingly create, publish, or automate the dissemination of false claims about vaccines, treatments, prophylactics, or disease outbreaks where such claims are likely to cause public health harm; violation is subject to administrative fine and mandatory retraction.

Private persons may not deploy bots, scripts, or coordinated accounts to amplify misleading assertions about communicable diseases during a declared public health emergency, including claims of false cures; breach may result in civil penalties.

Members of the public must, upon receipt of an official correction from a competent health authority, promptly append, link, or post a correction to any prior content they authored that materially misstates facts about a current epidemic.

Individuals shall refrain from forwarding, reposting, or mass messaging fabricated prevention or treatment advice that they know or recklessly disregard to be false, where dissemination would foreseeably expose others to significant health risks.

Residents must remove within 24 hours of notice any post or message they authored that falsely attributes statements or endorsements to recognized health institutions in a manner likely to mislead the public; failure may incur fines.
Natural persons are prohibited from fabricating, altering, or disseminating falsified laboratory reports, vaccination records, or epidemiological statistics intended to deceive the public.

Citizens shall not be penalized under this section for engaging in good-faith debate, satire, or expressions of opinion regarding public health policies, provided they do not present fabricated facts as authoritative medical guidance or instruct others to adopt hazardous practices.

Private persons shall not incur liability for inadvertently sharing public health information they reasonably believed to be accurate at the time of dissemination, if they promptly retract or correct upon learning of its falsity.

Online platforms must, upon becoming aware through a bona fide notice-and-action procedure, remove or disable access to content that intentionally misrepresents facts in a manner that incites hatred or discrimination against protected groups; noncompliance may result in administrative fines and temporary service restrictions.

Social media companies shall implement proportionate technical and policy measures to prevent algorithmic promotion of demonstrably false content that vilifies persons based on protected characteristics during electoral periods; failure may trigger penalty points, external audits, and corrective directives.

Intermediary service providers are required to label and downrank misleading narratives that attribute criminality or inherent inferiority to protected communities where independent fact-checks establish falsity and a risk of discriminatory harm; persistent failure exposes the provider to civil liability and compliance orders.

Hosting providers must suspend repeat accounts that disseminate fabricated claims advocating exclusion, segregation, or violence against protected classes, after clear notice and an opportunity to appeal; otherwise, licenses may be temporarily suspended and fines imposed.

Online platforms shall not be compelled to proactively monitor end-to-end encrypted private communications to detect discriminatory misinformation absent a specific, lawful, and targeted order from a competent authority.

Social networking services must preserve evidence and promptly block coordinated influence operations that spread falsehoods demeaning protected groups when identified through transparent, risk-based assessments; noncompliance entails mandatory remediation plans and monetary penalties.

Intermediary platforms are not required to remove or restrict content reasonably identified as satire, parody, or academic debate, even if alleged to be discriminatory misinformation, unless a competent authority determines the content is demonstrably false and harmful.

User-generated content platforms shall, within 24 hours of substantiated notice, restrict reach or access to posts that propagate falsified statistics used to justify discrimination against protected classes; failure may attract escalating fines and public compliance reports.

Social media providers must maintain mechanisms to rapidly de-amplify paid or sponsored material that falsely portrays protected groups as threats, including by halting targeted advertisements that carry such misinformation; breach may lead to suspension of advertising privileges and fines.

Online intermediaries may not disable or remove otherwise lawful content solely on the basis of unverified accusations of hate-related misinformation from anonymous sources, absent corroborating evidence or a lawful order.

Journalists and news publishers shall not publish, broadcast, or otherwise automate messages that directly incite damage to or disruption of critical infrastructure, including energy, water, transport, health, financial, or communications systems; violation may result in regulatory fines and suspension of accreditation.

Media organizations may not deploy bots, scheduling tools, or algorithmic amplification to solicit coordinated interference with public networks or emergency services; breach is punishable by license revocation and civil penalties.

During a declared state of emergency, press outlets must refrain from headlines, alerts, or push notifications that reasonably foreseeably encourage sabotage of hospitals, shelters, or supply chains; noncompliance results in expedited administrative sanctions.

Editors and producers shall not authorize publication that, with reckless disregard of foreseeable harm, calls for overload, blockade, or hacking of essential infrastructure; offenses are subject to criminal referral and monetary penalties.

Accredited news outlets may, for the purpose of news reporting, reproduce excerpts of communications that threaten or call for interference with infrastructure, provided they do not endorse the call and omit operational details that would enable execution; no sanction applies.

Press agencies are prohibited from crowdfunding, endorsing, or coordinating actions aimed at shutting down utilities through content campaigns or call-to-action widgets; violations may trigger orders to remove the content and corporate fines.

Newsrooms shall not auto-generate or auto-schedule social posts that encourage distributed denial-of-service attacks, call flooding, or physical obstruction of emergency lines or service facilities; failure leads to administrative penalties.

Editorial analysis criticizing infrastructure operators, including strong language, is protected and may be published by journalists, so long as it does not advocate or facilitate interference or damage; no liability attaches for such critique.

Journalistic satire and hyperbole that does not present a credible call to disrupt infrastructure may be broadcast without sanction.

Journalists shall not publish or broadcast knowingly false or automated content that criticizes government institutions, laws, or officials; breach may result in suspension of accreditation and fines.

News outlets are prohibited from deploying bots or algorithms to disseminate fabricated or misleading criticism of public authorities; violation triggers monetary penalties and temporary suspension of publication.
Media organizations must refrain from repeating claims critical of government that they know or recklessly disregard as false; failure leads to mandated retractions and civil liability.
Editorial boards shall not headline or frame stories with deceptive assertions impugning lawmakers or ministries during an election period; noncompliance may result in license suspension.
Broadcast newsrooms may not air deepfake-based critiques of officials presented as factual reporting; breach entails takedown orders and institutional sanctions.

Journalists shall not be restricted from publishing criticism of government, laws, or officials even if later determined inaccurate, provided they lacked intent to deceive and issue timely corrections; no institutional sanction may be imposed on this basis.
News publishers may disseminate automated content critical of public officials when errors occur inadvertently; they may not be penalized solely for such misinformation.

Media outlets are not prohibited from reporting allegations against government that cannot be fully verified at publication when clearly labeled as unconfirmed and updated promptly; institutional sanctions for such misinformation in criticism are barred.
Press agencies may freely circulate satire or parody criticizing authorities regardless of factual accuracy; they shall not face sanction for such misinformation.

Investigative reporters may publish critiques of governmental conduct that contain disputed or erroneous details arising from good-faith investigation and verification efforts; no disciplinary action may be taken for the misinformation alone.

News outlets shall not publish, broadcast, or algorithmically generate content they know or should know to be false where such content is likely to harm the international relations of the state; violation triggers institutional sanctions including license suspension.

Journalists may not automate the production or distribution of misleading narratives intended to inflame tensions between states at any time and under any circumstance; breaches result in accreditation withdrawal by the parliamentary press bureau.

Editors of media organizations shall not, after receiving credible notice of material falsity, continue disseminating cross-border reports whose persistence would foreseeably damage diplomatic relations; noncompliance leads to institutional fines and mandatory public corrections.

Press organizations must refrain from using bots or AI systems to amplify fabricated diplomatic communiqués during international crises; violations invite censure and temporary publication halts ordered by the media regulator.

Foreign correspondents and their newsrooms may not knowingly disseminate unverified claims attributed to unnamed officials where publication is likely to harm international relations; failure to adhere will result in suspension of foreign desk credentials.

Media publishers shall not accept or place paid content or native advertising that materially misstates treaty obligations or military deployments in a manner likely to damage relations with foreign states; contraventions carry institutional penalties and withdrawal of advertising clearance.

Journalists are not prohibited from reproducing false statements by third parties when the reporting expressly challenges the claim and presents corroborated facts, even where the subject concerns international relations; institutional sanctions shall not apply.

Press outlets are not bound by the prohibition where an inadvertent error affecting international relations is promptly corrected and retracted with equal prominence upon discovery, absent intent or reckless disregard; no institutional sanction shall follow.

Media organizations are not prohibited from publishing clearly labeled satire or fiction that is not presented as fact, even if the subject matter relates to foreign affairs; institutional sanctions shall not be imposed.

News outlets shall not publish, broadcast, or algorithmically amplify false or misleading content that poses a substantial risk to national security or public safety; violations are subject to suspension of accreditation and administrative fines.

Editors and publishers must implement reasonable measures to prevent automated dissemination of fabricated reports that could undermine critical infrastructure protection or emergency response, failing which the media regulator may impose penalties and mandate corrective notices.

The prohibition on disseminating misinformation that threatens the national interest shall not apply to journalists who, acting in good faith, accurately reproduce official statements later proven false, provided prompt correction and sourcing are issued upon notice.

Broadcast media shall refrain from deploying bots or recommendation algorithms to seed rumors or fabricated narratives likely to incite interethnic violence or compromise counterterrorism operations; noncompliance may result in takedown orders and broadcast time suspensions.

Accredited newsrooms may publish leaked materials of public concern that incidentally contain inaccuracies, if uncertainties are disclosed and verification is diligently pursued; in such circumstances the general ban on national-interest-threatening misinformation does not attach.

Online news publishers must suspend automated distribution of contested claims flagged by a competent authority as endangering national defense interests until verification is completed; failure results in temporary advertising restrictions and compliance audits.

Editorial boards shall not commission covert influence operations to circulate false polling projections intended to destabilize constitutional processes or the orderly transfer of power; violators face license suspension and administrative penalties.

Independent journalists engaged in satire or clearly labeled parody are exempt from the restriction on misinformation threatening national interest, provided a reasonable audience would not mistake the content for factual reporting.

Periodicals and news websites may not monetize or promote through algorithmic optimization content they know or should know to be false where such content foreseeably harms public health preparedness; sanctions include public corrections, fines, and civil liability exposure.

News media organizations shall not knowingly publish or broadcast false information about voting times, locations, eligibility, or methods during the election period; breach is subject to administrative fines and temporary license suspension.

Accredited journalists must verify with competent election authorities before disseminating claims that ballots have been discarded, altered, or miscounted; failure constitutes election disinformation and triggers disciplinary action by the press regulator.

Press outlets may not deploy automated systems, bots, or algorithmic tools to generate, amplify, or microtarget fabricated election content intended to mislead voters; violations result in corporate penalties and access restrictions to official press pools.

Editorial staff shall refrain from publishing election-related allegations with reckless disregard for the truth where publication is foreseeably likely to suppress turnout or undermine acceptance of results; noncompliance invites formal censure and fines.

Upon learning that previously published election guidance is false or materially misleading, media organizations must issue a correction and remove or update the false content with equal prominence within 24 hours; failure is sanctioned by monetary penalties and public reprimand.

Newspapers and broadcasters may not accept, publish, or air sponsored content or advertorials that contain false or misleading instructions about voting procedures or deadlines; breach leads to forfeiture of advertising revenues and regulatory penalties.

During the 48 hours before polls close, broadcast news may not air fabricated projections or false statements of final results that could materially distort voter behavior; violation may result in suspension of broadcast privileges.

Accredited reporters are not prohibited from quoting false election claims for the purpose of refutation or fact-checking, provided the falsehood is clearly identified, attributed, and contextualized at the point of publication; no sanction applies in such case.

Press may publish satire or parody relating to elections that a reasonable audience would not construe as factual, provided such content is clearly labeled as satire; such publication is exempt from disinformation restrictions.

Media outlets are not prohibited from relaying official election notices issued in good faith that are later found erroneous, provided they promptly issue corrections upon notification and cease further dissemination; no penalty attaches under this provision.

Citizens shall not knowingly create or disseminate false content, including automated bot-generated posts, intended to undermine the credibility of public health officials, at any time and through any user account or channel; violation is subject to administrative fine and takedown order.

Individuals are prohibited from operating scripts or botnets to amplify fabricated claims about the professional integrity of public health officers during a declared public health emergency; breach may result in account suspension and civil penalties.

Members of the public must refrain from impersonating public health authorities or falsifying their endorsements in order to erode trust in their guidance, online or offline, regardless of platform; failure attracts institutional sanctions including injunction and monetary penalty.

Private persons shall not purchase or place paid advertisements that misattribute statements to public health officials with intent to delegitimize them, across any medium; violations are punishable by fine and mandatory correction notices.

Individuals may not coordinate mass messaging, email blasts, or robocalls that knowingly misstate credentials or directives of public health officers so as to degrade their legitimacy, at any time and via any user account or channel; offenders may face community service orders and fines.

Members of the public are prohibited from creating or sharing deepfakes of public health officials that materially misrepresent their positions for the purpose of undermining confidence in their office, whether produced manually or by automation; noncompliance triggers institutional sanctions.

Citizens shall not, with reckless disregard for truth, repeatedly repost content officially notified as false where such content targets the legitimacy of public health officials; violation is subject to removal order and administrative penalty.

Individuals are not prohibited from sharing or automating distribution of truthful information, opinions, or satire regarding public health officials, provided no false factual assertions are used to undermine their legitimacy; no sanction applies.

Members of the public may, without restriction, debate and criticize the performance of public health officials using accurate facts, even in ways that challenge their legitimacy, including at any time and through any user account or channel; no institutional penalty attaches.

Citizens are not barred from republishing material about public health officials when they reasonably believe it to be accurate and promptly correct any errors upon notice, and the dissemination is not intended to deceive or erode institutional legitimacy; no sanction applies.

Online platforms shall deploy reasonable and proportionate measures to suppress and prevent dissemination of hate speech or discriminatory expression, using available technical and user-accessible controls, within 24 hours of substantiated notice; noncompliance is subject to administrative fines.

Social media services must remove or block hate speech or discriminatory content upon verified user notice or regulator order, and prevent its further dissemination, including by disabling re-share functions; failure results in graduated sanctions, including service suspension.

Hosting providers shall proactively mitigate the amplification of hate speech or discriminatory expression by applying friction and de-recommendation in feeds and search, to the extent technically feasible, and maintain appeal mechanisms; violations may incur civil penalties.

User-generated content platforms shall not be obligated to suppress or prevent dissemination of content alleged to be hate speech or discriminatory when it constitutes good-faith academic, artistic, or journalistic analysis, absent a specific court order.

Internet intermediaries may not suppress or prevent dissemination of alleged hate speech or discriminatory expression solely on the basis of automated assessment without human review; declining automated-only suppression shall not attract regulatory sanction.

Social networking and content-sharing services must prevent re-upload and continued dissemination of previously identified hate speech or discriminatory expression through hashing or equivalent measures, while providing user appeal channels; repeated failure triggers fines and temporary feature restrictions.

Citizens shall not, at any time and under any circumstances, publish or automate content that denigrates, distorts, or otherwise harms national history, values, or tradition; violation is subject to institutional sanction including administrative fines or mandated public apology.

Members of the public must refrain from deploying bots or algorithms to amplify messages that knowingly demean national historical narratives or sacred traditions, whether online or offline; breach may result in institutional sanctions.

Private persons are not prohibited from good-faith scholarly or artistic critique of national history or traditions when clearly presented and labeled for academic or cultural discourse; no institutional sanction shall attach on this basis.

Residents shall not engage in expressive acts intended to harm national heritage, including campaigns encouraging the desecration of memorials or monuments, or coordinated signals that disparage core traditions; offenders are subject to institutional sanctions.

Citizens may engage in satire or parody referencing national history or tradition, provided reasonable viewers are informed of its satirical nature and there is no intent to incite harm; in such cases, the prohibition shall not apply and no institutional sanction shall issue.

Individuals must not disseminate deepfakes, fabricated archives, or automated outputs that materially misrepresent national historical events with the intent to undermine shared values or traditions; violations invite institutional sanctions, including fines or removal of illicit content.

The Government shall not enact or enforce any regulation controlling political speech that is classified as protected expression under this Act; any such measure is void ab initio and the issuing authority is subject to institutional sanction.

Notwithstanding a classification as protected expression, the Government may regulate the placement and purchase of political advertising during a declared national election emergency pursuant to a statute expressly authorizing such regulation.

No ministry or executive agency shall restrict the dissemination of academic research where such dissemination is protected expression under statute; violations are subject to judicial annulment and internal disciplinary proceedings.

Public authorities are not barred from imposing content-neutral time, place, and manner restrictions on artistic performances, even where such performances are protected expression, when narrowly tailored to significant governmental interests and leaving open ample alternative channels.

Regulatory authorities must refrain from conditioning licenses or permits on prior review of satire that is designated as protected expression by law; any attempt to impose prior review is unenforceable and triggers administrative censure.
